urn:contentItem:4P7G-YMJ0-TXN5-R2XF-00000-00SOON, THE ROBOTS THAT THINK FOR THEMSELVES1989-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 45SOON, THE ROBOTS THAT THINK FOR THEMSELVESFrom MARGARET HARRIS in London

WHEN Arnold Schwarzenegger tracked his prey in The Terminator, his terrifying abilities were governed by one thing - artificial intelligence.

Around the world, governments, companies and universities are spending vast amounts of money, time and manpower on research into artificial intelligence -they see it as the way industry and technology must go.

Edinburgh University has a whole department devoted to the subject. Science students can now graduate with a degree in Artificial Intelligence and Computer Science.

Professor Jim Howe, head of Edinburgh University's department of artificial intelligence, said the main thrust of his work was to move from machines with"low-level intelligence" - ones whose ability to make decisions is still heavily dependent on a human operator - to machines which can make their own decisions.

Such research seems sinister to those who don't trust scientists but Professor Howe scoffed at such an idea and said machines would only be useful once they could be trusted to react to changing conditions.

He said the areas where machines are most useful are those where it is too unpleasant or dangerous for humans to work.

"Forest fire-fighting is a good example," said Professor Howe, who witnessed the bushfires which killed so many people, including fire-fighters, in the Dandenongs in 1983.

He said artificial intelligence could be used to program robot firefighters to fight fires in the most extreme sections of a bushfire so that humans could control the blaze from safer, strategic positions.

The aim is not necessarily to lose robots - they will be given the artificial intelligence they need to react as effectively as possible - but to eliminate the need to risk human life.

Deep-sea diving is another area where robots should be used extensively, once they have high enough levels of artificial intelligence to replace a human operator.

Robot submarines are used extensively to check deep-sea drilling sites and pipelines and for exploration but they all require a human operator because they have low-level intelligence.

Making clever robots is only a small part of the artificial intelligence field.

Much of the work at Edinburgh is directed towards intelligent language teaching and translation systems.

Scientists are developing an artificial interpreter - a computer system which translates from English to Japanese and from Japanese to English as two people talk to each other.

CONVERSATION

As a Japanese speaker holds a conversation with an English speaker, each will be given an interpretation of what the other is saying through an earpiece or a computer screen.

Such a system can also be used over the telephone. Someone in Tokyo can plug in the system when talking with a business contact in Sydney and each person can discuss business in his own language and hear or read the answers in his own language.

Other language research is looking at how we use language to communicate.

Much of what we say and do when communicating is difficult to put into pedantic, mechanical form, yet a machine or a computer will be very limited if it cannot use language the way we use it.

Anyone who has used computer dictionary systems knows just how limited and stupid a computer's attitude to written language can be.

Spoken language is even less precise, so a truly intelligent system has to be ready to understand and interpret an enormous variety of words and images.

Computers can ask questions but they must receive exactly the right answer. If they receive something even slightly out of keeping with what they have been programmed to expect, they simply reject it.

An intelligent system will not do this - it will listen, learn and ask more questions.

Studies of how humans - especially children - learn are yielding many clues to how machines can be made to learn.

One project at Edinburgh University is a study of why some children, despite being intelligent, fail to learn to spell.

The researchers have produced intelligent spelling systems which teachers can use to help poor spellers.

They found the children did better with the computers than with teachers because they were less afraid of failing.

Education is an area where intelligent systems have obvious potential. They will never, said Professor Howe, replace teachers but they allow the pupil to work at his own pace without feeling his performance is being critically assessed.

Systems for teaching physics and languages and for giving explanations which the user can interrupt are being studied at Edinburgh.

In the explanations research, the user can tell the machine to stop when he is losing track of the explanation and the computer can then find a simpler way of putting it, based on its interpretation of how much the user has understood.

Medical diagnosis is another area of enormous potential for artificial intelligence. Researchers have found patients give more honest answers to machines than to family doctors because they don't worry about what the machine thinks of them.

EMBARRASSING

Doctors say it will remove the personal relationship between doctor and patient but that, said Professor Howe, is its advantage.

It can be used by doctor and patient to cover areas both may find embarrassing or time-consuming.

All these uses of intelligent machines have been suggested before but now they are happening it will be threatening for many professionals who might fear a mechanical invasion will lead to loss of professional mystique.

However, Professor Howe said professionals should use intelligent tools the way firefighters and factory managers use them - to do the time-consuming or dangerous things allowing humans more time or scope to do their jobs better.

urn:contentItem:7TYV-F0C1-2RYX-1077-00000-00Curse of a sunburnt land2009-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 14Curse of a sunburnt landJamie Walker

As Black Saturday joins Ash Wednesday in the grim historical record, experts are warning that mega-fires are something we'll have to get used to, writes Jamie Walker

WHEN bushfires turn lethal, the terror begins long before the burning embers and flames arrive, and the sky glows orange in the heat. At their most hellish, these firestorms are like a giant runaway train: out of control, all but unstoppable, indiscriminately destructive. They move so fast that any poor soul fleeing at the last minute risks being engulfed.

The only saving grace is they don't happen more frequently in this great, sunburnt land.

But tell that to the loved ones of the 12 people who died on Black Saturday in Victoria around the mountain hamlet of Kinglake.

Or to the families of the four victims in StAndrews, the once-leafy enclave north of Melbourne where this newspaper's Gary Hughes only just got himself and his family away as their home of 25 years burned around them. And to the black-faced, bone-weary fire crews who were searching for bodies in the charred ruins of devastated Marysville or in the destroyed homesteads dotted around the Bunyip State Forest, east of the Victorian capital, where a conflagration came roaring out of the trees on Saturday night, defying every effort to stop it.

The overall death toll was 76 last night, with the potential to rise further, as authorities warned they still did not have a complete picture of who was caught in the fires that ripped through a deadly arc north and east of Melbourne, in the worst such disaster to strike since the Ash Wednesday outbreaks nearly 26 years ago.

The scars of that disaster on February 16, 1983, which claimed 47 lives in Victoria and another 28 in South Australia, remain raw and led to an overhaul of firefighting practices as well as better engagement with householders to battle bushfires. Central to this was the concept of fight or flight: people in vulnerable areas were encouraged to prepare fire plans on how to evacuate or defend their property when bushfire threatened.

The key was to make the choice early: if the decision was to go, they were told to hit the road well in advance of the flames.

One of the lessons of Ash Wednesday was that people could protect their homes and survive if they did the required preparation. Gutters, combustibles in the yard and overhanging foliage needed to be cleared. When the time came, hoses were to be set up, sinks and tubs filled with water to damp down spot fires ahead, and after the passage of the front.

The worst option, firefighters emphasised, was to be semi-committed: if a bushfire bore down there would be no halfway house for vacillators: to flee then was to risk death.

``There has been over 30 years of debate among fire experts as to whether people should stay and defend their property or leave early when there is a real risk of bushfire approaching,'' says Robert Heath, a psychologist and crisis management expert at the University of South Australia.

``Personally, my feeling is that most people should evacuate in the case of mega-fires -- that is, when you have multiple spotting of fires ahead of a large firefront.''

Authorities put increased emphasis on aerial suppression of firefronts, especially with the giant sky crane helicopters that are now a fixture of summer bushfire fighting in Australia. However, it made little difference during those fatal hours on Saturday night in Victoria. Why? In this case, the threat was known and emergency services were mobilised. The change in weather conditions that sparked the emergency had been predicted well in advance.

History provides a guide. It's no accident that mega-fires, once started, turn into infernos that defeat the heroics of firefighters and claim lives. In the lead-up to Ash Wednesday in 1983, Victoria had endured 10 months of drought; the warning signs had been apparent for months after a total fire ban was declared across the state the previous November, until then the earliest in the fire season such a measure had been imposed. On the day itself, Wednesday, February 16, 1983, the temperature soared to over 40C while relative humidity dropped to 15 per cent.

Fast-forward to Saturday. Melbourne baked in record 46.5C heat as northerly winds drew in blistering air from the deserts of central Australia. It was even hotter outside the city: in the paddocks around Avalon, the mercury had hit 47.9C by mid-afternoon.

Relief was to have been brought to the city by a cooling wind change but, as in 1983, this proved to be a hydra-headed monster for those in the fire zone. The temperature, after dipping in Melbourne, began to rise again as bushfires took hold on its northern outskirts. A smoke haze drifted across the city, imparting a sense of surreality to the unfolding emergency.

To put the threat in perspective, the forest fire danger index for the Adelaide Hills on Saturday was 111, against 50 for Ash Wednesday. The South Australian capital got off lightly when the temperature topped out at a relatively moderate 41C on Saturday, and because the cool change that came through in the early afternoon did not pack the punch of the wind shift that blasted into Victoria a few hours later.

That turned the prevailing wind direction from the north to southwesterly outside Melbourne, pushing the flames east, on to the Kinglake area, Marysville and St Andrews. In east Gippsland, the fires in the Bunyip forest burst through containment lines. In many cases, there was little firefighters could do except save themselves.

Questions are sure to be asked about whether more could have been done to warn communities in danger. Inquiries have inevitably followed bushfire disasters and this one in Victoria will be no exception.

The parallels between Black Saturday, 2009, and Ash Wednesday can be traced further along the timeline. It's no coincidence the heat records broken in Victoria over the weekend had stood since January 1939, when the Black Friday fires killed 71 people in logging communities in the state's high country (on the day of the Black Friday outbreaks, the temperature topped 45.6C in Melbourne).

A subsequent royal commission blamed the careless use of campfires and land clearing; supervised burning techniques that endure today were subsequently developed.

The 2003 Canberra fires, which killed four, raised searching questions about co-operation between the ACT and NSW fire authorities and whether more could have been done to have stopped the inferno before it broke into the national capital.

The inquiry recommended increased emphasis on controlled burning as a fuel-reduction strategy in national parks, and improvements to training for volunteer and fire crews. Crucially, more emphasis was to be placed on informing the public of emerging bushfire threats, especially in urban areas.

After the Eyre Peninsula disaster in South Australia in January 2005 claimed nine lives, a coroner found that fire authorities had wrongly assumed the deadly blaze had been contained, resulting in a crucial delay in issuing warnings.

But Victorian fire authorities insist no amount of preparation could have coped with the deadly conditions on late Saturday. ``You couldn't fight it, nobody could,'' one tearful survivor says.

``It rained fire,'' says another.

Raylene Kincaide of Narbethong, near devastated Marysville, northeast of Melbourne, thought she would never go through another bushfire as bad as Ash Wednesday, but this was worse. ``Everyone we know has lost everything they had,'' she says.

The term mega-fire was coined in the US, but fire experts say Australians may need to get used to it. Rod Incoll, a fire management consultant who was formerly a chief fire office responsible for Victoria's state forests and national parks, says such blazes go off ``like a nuclear release ... you're talking about megawatts of energy''.

As was the case on Saturday, these are typically formed by several fires, covering a huge area, converging. They exhibit complex behaviour, create their own weather and burn on and on, brushing aside the most intense and sophisticated efforts to contain them.

Kevin O'Loughlin of the Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre points out that the worst fires in recorded history in the US have occurred in the past decade, and Australia is likely to be no exception as the drought drags on in the southern half of the continent. There, lower rainfall and higher temperatures associated with global warming threaten to intensify the bushfire menace.

The scenes described by survivors of the Black Saturday blazes in Victoria are salutary. As the firefront approached, the sky blackened. Spotfires broke out as blazing embers fell from the heavens. The heat intensified and a blistering wind, whipped up by the change of air pressure caused by the fire sucking in oxygen, sounded like a ``freight train'', according to one account.

``Most people are not psychologically prepared for the noise and heat of a mega-fire,'' Heath warns.

Phil Cheney, an honorary research scientist with the CSIRO, says the tips of flames in a firestorm burn at 300C, while at the base of the fire the temperature can climb to 1000C. Radiant heat reaches out to kill long before the fire itself arrives.

Incoll fears that there is only so much fire crews can do in the face of a monster conflagration. ``The fuel loads are so high because there has been no strategic burning done,'' he prophetically told The Australian in December 2006. ``Those large fires just get going and once they get going you can't stop them because the fire intensity, the heat generated by the fire, exceeds the fairly puny efforts that human intervention can exert.''

University of Tasmania bushfire management expert David Bowman agrees. ``This is a truly terrible situation,'' he says.

And let's not forget something else: this hot, dry summer in southeastern Australia still has a long way to go. South Australia and Tasmania are tinderboxes, and NSW is feeling the heat, too.

There may be more black days to come.

Jamie Walker is The Australian's Adelaide bureau chief.

RAVAGED: AUSTRALIA'S TRIAL BY FIRE

* January 13, 1939: ``Black Friday'' fires in Victoria claim 71 lives after burning through almost 2 million hectares

* February 7, 1967: Tasmanian fires kill 59 people and burn through 264,270ha in the state's south.

* February 16, 1983: The Ash Wednesday bushfires claim 47 lives in Victoria and 28 in South Australia. More than 3700 buildings destroyed.

* January 1994: Four people killed and a million hectares of bushland destroyed when fires from rural NSW hit Sydney.

* January 18, 2003: Firestorms fanned by high winds hit Canberra, killing four people and razing almost 500 homes.

* January 11, 2005: Nine lives lost in South Australian Eyre Peninsula bushfires.

* December 30, 2007: Blaze kills three truckers on a highway near Coolgardie in Western Australia.

* February 7, 2009: At least 76 people confirmed killed and fears of more fatalities in bushfires across rural Victoria.

Unusual items, net of taxation and minority interests, in the latest period comprised: a gain of $113 million on the sale of Natural Gas Corporation, a loss of $10 million on the sale of the Tasman eucalypt forest estate, a gain of $11 million relating to the receipt of Chile forest fire insurance proceeds, and restructuring costs of $10 million relating to direct costs associated with the proposed merger of Fletcher Challenge Paper and Fletcher Challenge Canada. Excluding net unusual items, net earnings were $135 million, compared with $34 million and $87 million for the two immediate preceding six-month periods. Operating earnings (EBIT) excluding unusual items rose from $138 million in the June 1999 half year, to $365 million in this period - a 164 per cent improvement, and a $107 million increase over the $258 million reported in December 1998. Cash flow from operations was up 31 per cent on the $527 million in the June 1999 half-year to $690 million, in line with the $696 million in the December 1998 period. The ratio of debt to total capitalisation improved even further from the 36.7 per cent recorded in December 1998, to 32.3 per cent, and represents the lowest ratio the Group has recorded in more than a decade. This improvement was also reflected in the ratio of the cash flow coverage of interest, which increased from 3.79 times in the June 1999 half-year to 4.63 times this period. As a result of the overall financial performance improvement and favourable business outlook, dividend increases for Building and Energy have been announced. Building has increased its interim dividend by 33 per cent, from 6.0 cents to 8.0 cents per share. Energy shareholders will receive a 1.0 cent (14 per cent) increase to 8.0 cents per share. Given the current Paper separation process, Directors have decided to hold the current level of dividend for Paper shareholders at 1.5 cents per share. Consistent with past periods, Forests has not declared a dividend. All dividends will be fully tax credited. urn:contentItem:4F1Y-C080-015G-S3KD-00000-00<published>2004-12-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Letters; Pg. 28</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Letters to the Editor</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Child carers blameless in sunburnt episode</p><p nitf:lede="true">My daughter attends the childcare centre in question ("Rebecca screamed for a week", Daily Telegraph, December 17) and I am 100 per cent sure Rebecca's sunburn did not happen while at child care.</p><p nitf:lede="true">My daughter is as fair-skinned as Rebecca and has never come home "light pink", let alone sunburnt. The workers who care for my daughter are of the highest quality and are vigilant in ensuring that my child is safe, healthy and happy.</p><p nitf:lede="true">I would even go as far as saying that they care for her as if she were their own child.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In 18 months I have never had one instance of my daughter being injured, neglected or harmed in any way while at child care.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>She loves and adores every staff member and they treat her and every other child with the love and respect that our children deserve.</p><p>Not only that, as soon as this "complaint" was made, the childcare centre fully disclosed every aspect of it to the parents, including the fact that the Department of Community Services (DOCS) had been called.</p><p>They have absolutely nothing to hide from the parents of the children attending their centre and we know they have done nothing wrong.</p><p>What you have failed to include in your article is the fact that DOCS has attended the centre and found no grounds for the allegation whatsoever and most importantly the fact that the "complaint" was made by a family member of a former employee.</p><p>Karyn Devaney, Erskine Park</p><p>Crossing needed at dangerous spot</p><p>I am not a betting person but I would definitely put money on a pedestrian being injured by a vehicle in Waverley St, Bondi Junction, at the new exit of the Westfield car park.</p><p>This has become a high traffic area, with many elderly or infirm pedestrians because of the large number of doctors and diagnostic clinics in the vicinity.</p><p>Vehicles exit the Westfield car park at speed around a blind corner, often putting their foot down to catch the green light at the Hollywood Ave intersection.</p><p>Every day I watch pedestrians avoiding cars, illegal parking and stopping, and vehicles running red lights. A zebra crossing is desperately needed across Waverley St.</p><p>This small strip of road gets my vote as the most pedestrian-unfriendly area in Waverley, only just beating Bondi Rd. Also, why isn't there a 10km/h bus zone on Oxford St through the Westfield site? This stretch of Oxford St is a busy route doing a great job masquerading as a carefree pedestrian walkway.</p><p> Where are the barriers? Where are the measures to ensure pedestrian safety?</p><p>Madeleine Walker, Tamarama</p><p>Trail to fire disasters</p><p>A result of the closing of National Park and State Forest fire trail access to four-wheel-drives and recreational vehicles in recent years was the degradation of these trails as they fell into disuse.</p><p>It would seem the (largely unheeded) warnings from the recreational 4WD community have been validated by the NSW Deputy State Coroner's finding that poorly maintained fire trails were a major contributing factor in hampering recent bushfire-fighting efforts (Daily Telegraph, December 15).</p><p>Perhaps now the various government agencies can fully engage with initiatives to reopen these areas and trails to 4WDs for the mutual benefit of park management, rather than caving in to the anti-4WD lobby.</p><p>Programs such as the current arrangements at Menai, where drivers contribute to rubbish removal and track maintenance, offer a more long-term trail-management option for many of our parks and forests.</p><p>The misconception that all 4WD who go off-road are bush-bashing yobbos who should be kept out is inhibiting fire-trail management.</p><p>Paul Kretschmann,</p><p>Northmead</p><p>Time of joy</p><p>From the excitement and enthusiasm radiating from Christmas shoppers, it seems that it is the giving rather than the receiving of gifts that creates so much of the joy at Christmas time.</p><p>Mary Julian,</p><p>Woollahra</p><p>More patrols can cut road toll</p><p>Along with many other people, I also feel that one of the best ways to deter drivers from speeding is the presence of police vehicles.</p><p>Instead, over the years, there has been a huge increase in the number of speed-related signs and an increase in the number of speed cameras.</p><p>To make matters worse, instead of increasing the number of patrol cars on our major roads to suit the changing traffic conditions, the police have reduced the number of patrol cars.</p><p>Therefore, it seems to me, that the State Government must be very happy with the latest proposal to reduce P-plate accidents because it has to outlay very little.</p><p>Once again, it will be the learner drivers and their parents who have to foot the bill.</p><p>Come on Premier Carr, if you want to make road safety a priority, use some of the revenue from speed camera fines and put more police patrols on our roads.</p><p>Peter Blanton,</p><p>Elermore Vale</p><p>Education assets</p><p>Maralyn Parker's piece, "Funds wasted on unnecessary inquiry" (Daily Telegraph, December 15), asserts: "Brendan Nelson's committee will instead waste the money finding new ways to denigrate teachers."</p><p>Such an assertion could not be further from the truth. Rather, a key objective of the National Inquiry into the Teaching of Literacy is to support teachers via the identification of best practice in the teaching of literacy, and how best to train teachers.</p><p>I draw attention to just two objectives of the Committee of Inquiry's work, namely:</p><p>Review and analyse recent national and international research about literacy teaching approaches, particularly approaches that are shown to be effective in assisting students with reading difficulties;</p><p>Identify the ways in which research evidence on literacy teaching and policies in Australian schools can best inform classroom teaching practice and support teacher professional learning.</p><p>Since literacy is the foundation of lifelong learning, teacher training and capacity-building is vital so that all children, adolescents and adults are able to read, write and communicate competently.</p><p>For the sake of Australia's social and economic future, let alone our children's, I trust Ms Parker understands the importance of investing in Australia's most valuable educational resource -- our teachers.</p><p>Dr Ken Rowe, committee chair, National Inquiry into the Teaching of Literacy,</p><p>Camberwell, Victoria</p><p>Erosion of values</p><p>My daughter, a single parent with two small children, lost her purse while shopping at Eastgardens. I told her to go to the centre's management the next day and ask whether the purse had been handed in as she was panicking about the money in it and her Medicare card, etc.</p><p>A day later the centre handed back her purse and my daughter was overjoyed but that soon dissipated when she realised the money that was in it -- which she was going to use to buy the children's presents -- had been removed.</p><p>Why are people like this? Nobody cares about anybody else. Road rage, robberies and violence are on the rise, yet more and more people are coming into the country and eroding that community spirit Australia used to enjoy.</p><p>Leonie Williams, Maroubra</p><p>Kind words</p><p>Over the four weeks that I attended the Cancer Therapy Centre at Campbelltown Hospital recently, I found the doctors and staff helpful, co-operative and efficient in their expertise and their work. I can only say thank you to the people in the unit for the treatment I received.</p><p>P. Rich, Moss Vale</p><p>Thank you to a sweet Chinese lady, Natalie, who inspired us all, especially me at 66, to get fit again with her encouragement. She will never be forgotten by our community of early-morning exercisers at our local park.</p><p>Geoff Hinds, Merrylands</p><p>I caught the XPT from Strathfield last Sunday. I was 30 minutes early, so I had time to observe rail staff and train guards going about their work. They were nothing but professional and polite, without exception.</p><p>The facilities at the station have dramatically improved since I used to catch trains to work in the 1970s and '80s -- from digital clocks to TV monitors showing train arrivals/destinations. Once on the XPT, again the staff were faultless and kept us informed along the way as to why we stopped and also on approaching stations.</p><p>My experience was most enjoyable and I look forward to another trip. They get 10 out of 10 from me. Keep up the great work. They also make a good cup of coffee.</p><p>Robyn Bate, Laurieton</p><p>_____________________________</p><p>Mail</p><p>PO Box 2808, GPO Sydney, NSW 2001</p><p>Fax</p><p>Letters Editor, Daily Telegraph, 01-9288-2300</p><p>Phone</p><p>1900-969545. ARIAS OF SPECIAL INTEREST

* Not unless it is a bit rusty: Not only might he have a suspicion of critics who don't pay for their tickets, the biggest third of the three tenors, Luciano "Big Lucy" Pavarotti, has a superstition: rusty nails.

So our roving opera eye, Ava Hubble, discovered yesterday at the his news conference. Big Lucy recognised the ABC arts reporter, Sally Begbie, instantly, and promptly informed everyone that she had changed her hairstyle. Ms Begbie hit back quickly, asking him if he had found any rusty nails lately

Excuse us?

The Big P will not go on stage to sing unless he finds a rusty nail, Begbie explained later. This little idiosyncrasy is so well known in opera houses around the world that Covent Garden assigns a stagehand to make sure a few rusty nails are strategically dropped backstage whenever the Big P is appearing there.

Begbie, however, was at a loss to explain the tenor's skills in observation. The change in her hairdo since they last met was slight.

Pavarotti will give free outdoor concerts in New York in June and in Hyde Park, London, in July. The Hyde Park gig will be simulcast later, on August 24, by Channel 10 and 2UE.

INFAMOUS FIVES

* You're the top, you're Mahatma Gandhi: After seeing the catlike crooner Eartha Kitt last week, the Herald music critic Bruce Elder said her concert definitely made it into his list of top 10 concerts. So we asked him which gigs rated at the very top in his 20 years of critical concert-going. His choice:

1. Bob Marley and the Wailers, 1976, London. Bruce was not a huge reggae fan at the time, but the king of reggae was a "mesmerising" live performer.

2. Sweet Honey in the Rock, 1990, Sydney, a fabulous a cappella band.

3. Jane Siberry, the Canadian singer of the inspired Everything reminds me of my Dog, at the Real Ale Cafe, Sydney, 1990. A consummate live performer.

4. Lonnie Brooks, Paddington RSL, Sydney, 1990.

5. Pink Floyd, Knebworth, England, 1976.

Tomorrow, the five worst.

POET'S CORNER

* There was a young man and a shoe: Today, in our occasional series, the writer Cathy Peake shares with us her "favourite lines of poetry I never learnt in school".

The Firbanks of Bairnsdale asked

me to tea

and were as kind as kind could

possibly be

but their rumbles abdominal

were simply phenomenal

and everyone, even Caroline,

thought it was me.

Ms Peake reads tonight at the Harold Park Hotel from Speaking with the Sun, an anthology of stories from contemporary Australian and New Zealand women writers.

IDIOT BOX BLUES

* Like the trees in the forest, so are the days of our lives: OK, so one of the mysteries in the small-town-makes-weird (and damn good coffee) soap is solved. You may know who killed Miss Glad Wrap 1991, but frustrated detectives can try this quick quiz.

1. What is Agent Cooper's middle name and in what city did he grow up?

2. What was Maddy Ferguson returning home to do?

3. What is the mascot for Twin Peaks High School and what is the local paper called?

4. What was Laura's favourite drink at the RR diner?

5. How did the Log Lady's husband die?

ANSWERS

1. Bartholomew; Philadelphia.

2. Work in an insurance company.

3. A steeplejack; Twin Peaks Gazette.

4. Brown Cow (cola and vanilla ice-cream).

5. Fighting a forest fire.

Quote of the day: "I sang in Voices That Care and stood next to Tom Selleck. I actually sang but Tom didn't. His lips were moving but nothing was coming out." - The football player turned thespian Brian Bosworth, on the cable show Entertainment Television.

Voices That Care was the recording made in support of United States troops in the Gulf and gave celebrities the chance to demonstrate how warm and fuzzy they really are.

Oops, the devil did it: Somehow the word "yuppie" fell out of our column yesterday when we had hoped to call Bret Easton Ellis's American Psycho a publication about the designer yuppie from hell. We hope we didn't offend any designers anywhere.

SPIN US ANOTHER ONE

A honkin' and a screamin' and a cookin': Big Jay McNeely is back in town to play some rampant rhythm and blues on his glow-in-the-dark saxophone and analyse his audience by their clothing.

The Go Go Man says he plays differently according to who's there (so for a wild night leave the beige bodyshirt at home). It's the shoes, the hats and the hairstyles that are the real giveaways, he says.

Why a fluorescent saxophone? It all happened back in 1986 in Los Angeles. "I started playing on the floor; I got down on my knees and lay on the floor and the audience responded and it became a really big thing and a couple of others started copying my thing. I went into a club and a girl stripper came out in fluorescent clothes and I said this is it and went down and had my horn painted - chartreuse and red, but on this tour it's orange and lime green."

Big Jay, now 64, first made it big with live audiences in 1949, in the days when his music was called race music and the radio stations wouldn't touch it

Then Pat Boone came along and sang Little Richard numbers and Elvis and Carl Perkins et al joined in and turned rhythm and blues into rock'n'roll.

Miles Davis, Teddy Edwards, Keith Compton and Charles Mingus are his heroes but he's not a big fan of rap. "I like everything but I think rap is more of a visual thing," he said.

urn:contentItem:4P8R-2DG0-TXN5-S4JY-00000-00The ten sports people with natural disadvantages2007-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 23The ten sports people with natural disadvantagesRod Curtis

1. Oscar Pistorius

KNOWN as the fastest man on no legs, Oscar Pistorius was born without fibula bones, and had both legs amputated below the knee when he was 11 months old. Raised on prosthetic legs, Pistorius soon discovered he could run faster on his carbon fibre blades than most people could on two good legs and duly claimed the world record in the 100, 200 and 400 metres for athletes with a disability events. Last weekend, the "Blade Runner" took part in the 400 metres of the ablebodied British Grand Prix - the first time a disabled athlete had competed against the world's best in a top international meeting - in an attempt to reach the 45.95-second mark he needs to qualify for the able-bodied Olympic Games. In driving rain, the South African struggled with the puddles and finished last in 47.65, then was disqualified for running out of his lane. But he'll be back.

2. Ian Thorpe

WHEN a seven-year-old Ian Thorpe followed his older sister into swimming, the young tyro was quickly diagnosed as being allergic to chlorine. "You could say it was like my Kryptonite," a humble Thorpedo told the Impossible is Nothing adidas ad campaign. "I just had huge sinus headaches in chlorine pools. It helped me develop my passion and my drive in the pool - I was willing to get constantly sick." The first time Thorpe competed, he swam with his head out of the water, his nose clamped shut with a clip, and won.

In time, he outgrew the allergy, grew to 195 centimetres (six-foot-five) with size-17 feet. But the legend of the allergy lives on - there's even an online game to prove it: go to http://thorpe.ggg.com.au/ where you can "help Thorpie overcome his chlorine allergy and conquer the pool by avoiding harmful enemies while collecting medals, trophies and using thorpedo boosts to finish in the fastest time!".

3. Steve Elkington

ALTHOUGH Elkington is blessed with what has been dubbed golf's "sweetest swing", the Elk is cursed with a severe allergy to grass. Bummer, really, considering his workplace.

Bermuda grass, bent grass, rye grass, poa annua, bluegrass, it doesn't matter. He has had sinus surgery twice and suffered viral meningitis - and accompanying spinal taps - three times, which he describes as having "a forest fire in your head". In 1994, the New York Times reported that each day, Elk took 800 milligrams of antibiotics (one dose in the morning, one at night), an antihistamine and five applications of three different nasal sprays. Twice weekly, he gave himself an antihistamine injection.

He still won the 1995 US PGA championship, the 1992 Australian Open, and a further nine US tour events. The surgeries and the antihistamine Allegra - which became a personal sponsor - have improved things in recent years, including his sense of humour.

Of Tiger Woods, he says: "I'm afraid Woods is a very one-dimensional golfer. He wins all the time."

4. Bart Cummings

CUPS king Bart Cummings hardly ever made it to the track. When a child, a doctor told young Bart's folks that he was allergic to horse hair, oats, chaff, lucerne and hay. "All those things I was allergic to," Cummings told the ABC. "And the chap said, 'Oh you're easy to fix, son', he said, 'Keep away from horses and you'll never look back.' " Bart, who will be 80 in November, ignored the advice, embracing a lifetime of taking antihistamines on his way to training 11 Melbourne Cup winners among his 247 group 1 winners. Intriguingly, last year his leading Cups contender Accumulate also had an allergic reaction to lucerne, and was given a similar antihistamine to the drug Cummings takes.

5. Steven Arnold

AT 175 centimetres, Arnold is probably the tallest flat race jockey in Australia. He's certainly the best tall jockey in Australia.

Arnold is two centimetres taller than West Coast Eagle David Wirrpanda and yet rides at 55.5 kilograms - almost 30 kilograms lighter than Wirrpanda plays. Arnold eats just one light meal and a non-fattening bite - literally, a bite - a day. Known for his horsemanship and soft hands, the jockey from Alice Springs remains a favourite with trainers - when he can make the weight. He couldn't do it in last year's Melbourne Cup, when he gave up the ride on the third-placed Maybe Better, carrying 50kg. From limited opportunities, he's nailed nine group 1 winners, including the Oaks on Magical Miss, the Doomben 10,000 on Undue and the SAAB Quality on Maybe Better. Arnold will ride a "tick lighter" than his 55.5kg in a big race: "If I've got the desire, and I still have at the moment, I can hold it. I've been doing it long enough."

6. Tyrone "Muggsy" Bogues

IN THE NBA, where the average player is 200 centimetres, Muggsy dominated, despite being 160 centimetres. Muggsy, so nicknamed because a coach likened his playing style to a mugging, grew up in housing projects in Baltimore, Maryland.

Selected 12th in the first round of the 1987 NBA draft by the Washington Bullets, the little point guard made his name at the Charlotte Hornets, played in the play-offs three times, and finished his career as the Hornets' all-time leader in assists (5557), steals (1067) and turnovers (1118) - and in the NBA's all-time top 20 players for assists. Although able to jump more than 115 centimetres into the air - in 1996, he blocked a shot attempt by New York Knicks' 213-centimetre center Patrick Ewing - Muggsy was a demon when the ball hit the ground. "The ball's on the floor more than it's in the air. And down there is Muggsyland," he wrote in his autobiography."

That's where I rule. On the floor, you gotta watch out for the little fella."

7. Azeem Hafeez

A TALL, strong left-arm quick, Azeem Hafeez took 63 wickets in 18 Tests for Pakistan despite the fact he was born with two fingers missing on his right hand.

With limited first-class cricket behind him, Hafeez was rushed into the Test arena as a 20-year-old when Imran Khan went down with a shin injury. He debuted against India in 1983-84, then toured Australia, where he bowled marathon spells, took 19 wickets, including five-wicket bags in Adelaide and Perth. He also became a crowd favourite, with satirist Billy Birmingham (The 12th Man) none-too-subtly adopting him as the character "Hafeez Andmissin". At home against India, he then took 6-46 on a lifeless pitch, and 22 wickets in six Tests against New Zealand. Then in 1984-85, aged just 21, Hafeez gave way for Wasim Akram and, with Waqar Younis and Imran ahead of him - supported by Abdul Qadir - the luckless youngster never played Test cricket again.

8. Bhagwat Chandrasekhar

INDIAN leg spinner Bhagwat "Chandra" Chandrasekhar was stricken by polio aged five and despite his withered right arm became a genuine matchwinner. With a characteristic long run-up and a whippy action, the lanky Chandra didn't turn the ball much, but his googlies and top-spinners claimed 242 wickets in 58 Tests from 1964, with best figures of 8-79. "I had a different grip, like a seam bowler's with my fingers spread across, so I could get bounce off the deadest pitch - I didn't do too much thinking," he said. "I couldn't flight the ball - everything I bowled was fast - it was like asking (Dennis) Lillee to flight the ball." Chandra fielded and threw left-handed, and was a terrible batsman, finishing with 23 ducks and an average of four. Touring Australia in 1977-78, he was presented with a special Gray-Nicholls bat with a hole in it to commemorate his four ducks. Then he bowled India to victory in Melbourne. Named Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1972, he retired in 1979.

A road accident a decade later left him partially paralysed. But cricket lovers will always remember him charging in, his long-sleeved shirt buttoned at the wrist whipping over, with the edges flying to Eknath Solkar at forward short leg.

9. Geoff Blethyn

HUNDREDS of league footballers have played with contact lenses, but Essendon great Geoff Blethyn was rare in that he played in glasses. Slim and agile, the bespectacled Bomber kicked 216 goals in 84 VFL games, mostly at full-forward. Debuting in 1968, he was rushed into the grand final against Carlton in only his second game after Essendon skipper Ken Fraser was ruled out with injury, the then 17-yearold kicking four of Essendon's eight goals to lose by just three points. In 1972, in his trademark black-rimmed specs, Blethyn became only the second Bomber to top the ton - in one game he kicked 11 of 13 goals in a losing side to Footscray - and finished the year with 107. The Encyclopedia of AFL Footballers reports that when he booted his 100th, the police horse protecting him "slobbered all over his glasses".

10. MacKinzie Kline

AMERICAN golfer MacKinzie Kline was born with a congenital heart defect and her parents were told that with groundbreaking surgery at eight weeks old, their single-ventricle daughter could live until she was five. Now 15, and with only 80 per cent of the average person's oxygen and no aerobic capacity at all, she is ranked No. 1 for her age group in the world.

Unable to walk a golf course, she rides in a cart and breathes oxygen from a cylinder between strokes. "I just need a little extra help so I can play," she told the Observer.

In her spare time, she's the national spokesperson for the US' Children's Heart Foundation. She hit a hole in one aged eight, was hitting 72 aged 10, and the only handicap she takes seriously is the one she writes on her card. "I never really thought I couldn't do things that a normal person can do," she said. "I didn't think the heart condition was that big a deal."

WHAT DO YOU THINK?

Have any suggestions about sports people with natural disadvantages that should have been on the list? Write in and tell us. We'll publish a selection next Sunday. Please keep your responses to no more than 50 words and send them to the address at the top of the page.

R21</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Trapped in a soap bubble</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Evan Williams</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Truman Show (PG)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> National release</p><p nitf:lede="true">.</p><p nitf:lede="true">THE irony at the heart of Peter Weir's very funny and very clever new film is signalled in the opening lines. "We've become tired of pyrotechnics and special effects," intones Christof (Ed Harris), the evil mastermind of the story, fixing us (the audience) with a confiding gaze.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> There is, as it happens, no shortage of pyrotechnics and special effects in The Truman Show: even something as blandly spectacular as a forest fire is readily accommodated to the film's demands, and the sets include a gigantic control room like something from Lost in Space. But isn't the whole story about the use of special effects on a giganticscale -the creation of an artificial world indistinguishable from the real one?</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Truman Burbank (Jim Carrey) is the star of a long-running TV soap, transmitted round the clock to a devoted audience. We join him on Day 10,909 of the show -it has been running for 30 years -as he leaves for work one typical morning in the pretty white-picket-andtimber-frame town of Seahaven. But Seahaven in reality is an enormous studio set and all the people in it (except Truman) are actors and extras. Truman doesn't know this. He was born in Seahaven ("the only child ever legally adopted by a corporation") and has lived his life believing that his familiar world, enclosed by a gigantic invisible dome, is the real one.</p><p> Jaques's words in As You Like It are for Truman the literal truth: "All the world's a stage / And all the men and women merely players . . ."</p><p> Everything is done to keep Truman in ignorance of reality.</p><p>His every movement is filmed by hidden cameras. The movements of the players ("their exits and their entrances") are directed by the allpowerful Christof from his console in the sky; even the weather can be regulated with rain machines and sunlamps. If something by chance goes wrong, and Truman catches a glimpse of something he shouldn't see, a benign explanation is provided on a subsequent newscast. One such incident occurs at the start of the film: a floodlight from the set drops from the sky like a bomb. Truman picks it up and has no idea what it is, but a newsflash soon afterwards talks of an aircraft breaking up in flight.</p><p> Although Truman spends his life in a prison, it is a far from uncongenial one.</p><p>This is a secure and comfortable world in which everyone maintains a mask of geniality and nothing too unpleasant is allowed to happen. The sponsors' product placements -the beers, the clothes and kitchen gadgets -are so unobtrusive that Truman is scarcely aware of them, and when a character makes a brief pitch to camera ("That is a beer!"), it is accepted as a natural part of conversation.</p><p> All this is very funny -everything in the film shines with wit and intelligence -but the mood becomes gradually darker. Truman, though living with a wife of Donna Reed-like sweetness and practicality (Laura Linney), spends his nights in virginal seclusion; the universe of sexual experience is closed to him. Occasionally he suspects that something is wrong with his world, even that he is under surveillance. And one day an actor in the show (Natascha McElhone) tips him off and urges him to escape.</p><p> But escape is impossible. His dreams of travel to faraway places are thwarted or discouraged. Even the posters in tourist offices warn of the likelihood of aircraft disasters; and escape by sea is ruled out by Truman's phobia for water, a state of mind conditioned by the show's producers.</p><p> Weir has worked from a screenplay by New Zealander Andrew Niccol, and what makes The Truman Show at once sinister and hilarious is the seamless ingenuity of its construction and the confidence of Weir's direction. Audiences can be privy to the secrets of the show while Truman remains in ignorance. But the artificiality of Truman's world is never so extreme that we cannot accept it ourselves as some sort of alternative to the real world of stress and squalor. This calls for exquisite timing and judgment from the cast, and all of them deliver.</p><p>Even the extras manage to behave like extras, walking too purposefully around the fringes, a shade too eager and conspicuous.</p><p> And Carrey's presence is a masterstroke of casting: he has always been funny to watch and our readiness to discern a higher pathos in the antics of a familiar clown guarantees him a measure of sympathy. His features -buoyantly fresh and trusting, a study in unsullied gullibility and openness suggest the dimness and exuberance that enable Truman Burbank to survive.</p><p> More than 40 years ago, Frederik Pohl, one of the century's great science fiction writers, published a story called The Tunnel Under the World. I read it in a Penguin anthology in 1963 and it has stuck in my mind ever since. The hero, an innocent called Burckhardt, lived in an ideal, picture-postcard city called Tylerton ("the sky was cloudless, the buildings were clear and inviting") which turns out to be an artificial environment, devised and constructed by a millionaire advertising guru, Dorkin, who manipulates Burckhardt's entire waking life from an overhead control room. Burckhardt has no idea that he is being used to test advertising techniques. One day in Tylerton is exactly like another; all the people around him are fakes; and, of course, there is no escape.</p><p> I mention this coincidence to make the point that the fears explored in The Truman Show are part of a familiar contemporary nightmare: the sensation that none of us is truly master of ourselves, that our lives are regulated by endless pressures to conform, and to that extent we are less than human.</p><p>This is the stuff of countless dystopian fables. There is no great distance between the worlds of Seahaven (or Tylerton) and the world of Nineteen Eighty-Four. People are controlled by technology in the service of political or commercial ambition; the individual is crushed; everyone is subject to Big Brother's scrutiny. Electronic snooping shows such as Candid Camera have been a TV staple from the beginning. Today, when there is no privacy even for a president of the US, Weir's film has a special urgency.</p><p> There is no particular logic in the story. The TV show might be just as popular if Truman, too, were played by an actor. Why does he have to be deceived? But that is the point. Watching The Truman Show is to be reminded fleetingly of many films -The Manchurian Candidate, Groundhog Day, The Stepford Wives, Logan's Run, Westworld, Capricorn One. All were about illusion, simulated states of reality. But most of them were more or less conventional scientific thrillers. Where Weir excels is in creating a mood of humorous fantasy that leaves us both charmed and anxious. The message isn't rammed home but is impossible to avoid. It gives this wholly enchanting entertainment its weight and relevance. Its pleasures fall as lightly as the Mozart piped from the Seahaven sky; and when we walk in the street, it wouldn't surprise us to hear an off-stage voice calling "Stand by all extras!" and discover a familiar doorway with nothing behind it.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier He shakes his head.</p><p>"It is very sad to fly over East Kalimantan on a daily basis," he said.</p><p> "Everywhere you go you see wildlife running out of the jungle with nowhere to go. They are getting trapped, sold or killed."</p><p> Randolph, 33, is on one of his regular water-bombing runs, missions that involve dumping a mixture of water and retardant on fires from a large bucket tethered to the helicopter.</p><p> He is one of a handful of pilots helping efforts to control the hundreds of fires in East Kalimantan. Many of the blazes are deliberately lit by plantation owners and farmers clearing the land, while smouldering peat and coal seam fires spark others. Peat and coal fires can burn for years just below ground level.</p><p> Adding to the gloom is a prolonged drought that has made the province tinder dry. Water for fire-fighting is also scarce and a choking smog has enveloped much of the area, making thousands of people ill.</p><p> Neighbouring South-East Asian nations fear smog from the fires, and those burning in Brunei and the Malaysian side of Borneo island, will create a repeat of last year's smoke haze which blanketed the region, sparking a health scare and casting a pall over the tourism trade. The haze has already crept over Singapore.</p><p> Randolph said the situation had become so desperate in East Kalimantan that he and his colleagues, an Australian and two Indonesians, worked for free to battle the blazes. An Indonesian company, National Utility Helicopters, provides the aircraft and pays for the water-bombing sorties.</p><p> "We're not trying to save the world, just a piece of it. I've just seen too much of this area burning and I decided with some friends that we can't let it happen any more," Randolph said.</p><p> "The point is that the fires, economic crisis and drought have made this a terrible year," he said.</p><p> Since January, fires have scorched 224,000 hectares of forest, plantations and brushland, official figures show. Last year, fires destroyed about 30,000 hectares of the province.</p><p> Environmental agencies and government officials say plantation companies are most to blame as they take advantage of the dry conditions and poor law enforcement to clear forest for new palm oil, rubber and timber plantations.</p><p> Wildlife, including the endangered orang-utan, have suffered badly from the fires, which have destroyed their habitat, while the drought means many animals are starving and vulnerable to villagers hunting for food to replace failed crops.</p><p> Yesterday, an Indonesian environmental official said dozens of deer had burnt to death in the forest fires.</p><p> "We have found about one tonne of charred deer carcasses in the forest," said Awang Faroek Iskak, head of East Kalimantan Environmental Impact Management Agency.</p><p> Iskak said by telephone from Samarinda that the forest fires had also killed other animals, including orang-utans.</p><p> Last week, the local press reported about 60 orang-utans were saved from the fires while four orang-utans that ran into a village were killed by villagers.</p><p> Newspaper reports said some of the baby orang-utans had been captured and sold for 500,000 rupiah ($ A100) each.</p><p> Klaus Toepfer, head of the United Nations Environment Program, recently said the fires were potentially one of the greatest ecological disasters of the millennium.</p><p> At the weekend, Randolph was playing his part in controlling the fires, even though the scene looked like David and Goliath.</p><p> The pilot who used to help film Hollywood productions and ferry television news crews reduces altitude to just above the trees, plunges into a thick column of smoke and releases the water.</p><p> A small curtain of water-retardant mix rains on the blaze but seems to have little impact. As he pulls up to return to base near the city of Balikpapan other forest fires come into view and it seems he is tackling a lost cause.</p><p> The problem, he says, is that there are not enough trained fire-fighters or money and that the fires are simply too numerous to tackle. Forecasts of rain being months away depress him further.</p><p> But he explains his efforts are not a waste of time. It is all about coordinating water-bombing with ground fire-fighting crews and concentrating on one area to try to save what is left. Often, though, it was difficult to link up regularly with local ground crews, frustrating his, and his colleagues' efforts.</p><p> "We have to prioritise," he said.</p><p> "We decided to coordinate as much as we can and try to combat specific areas that we might be successful in," he added. One of those areas was the Sungai Wain forest reserve near Balikpapan.</p><p> A large area of the forest in the reserve has already been destroyed and fires late last month nearly burned down the park's Wanariset Orang-utan Rescue and Rehabilitation Centre, said to be the world's largest rescue project for the primates.</p><p> The park is also home to many orang-utans, although local environmentalists say the fate of the primates there has not been fully determined.</p><p> Saving the park's orang-utans has become another of Randolph's projects.</p><p> With the help of National Utility, the Balikpapan Orang-utan Society and locals donating money, he and his colleagues have set up an organisation called East Kalimantan Forest Fire Rescue, which in part aims to douse fires in Sungai Wain, but also air-lift threatened orang-utans.</p><p> The animals would be sent to the Wanariset centre, although the scheme, in its infancy, relies heavily on donations and volunteers, said Yindra Rusmiputro, National Utility's direction.</p><p> "We are funding all our own helicopter operations now but of course it is not unlimited, so we are expecting help from foreign agencies," he said. Locals were doing much to help, he said.</p><p> Back at the base, Randolph is preparing for another run and, despite the fire disaster, says he values the experience.</p><p> "I ended up in East Asia because of the adventure and opportunity that comes with helicopter flying. Before I came to Indonesia nearly two years ago, I had 4,000 hours of flight time doing various jobs from shooting films for Hollywood productions and television news, to sling work and putting up Christmas trees.</p><p> "I came here to have another life experience and it's been incredible, diverse," he said, adding that his work had taken him to Sulawesi and Irian Jaya as well.</p><p> Now he is battling some the worst forest fires in the region and they show no sign of stopping. But neither does he.</p><p> "We wanted to start someplace, to win one small battle, not win the overall war because the war is pretty big," he said.</p><p>REUTERS gr</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SFT-NXC0-0048-T2PK-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1183"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P85-1CP0-TXN5-R22P-00000-00Waiting to breach the barricades1998-03-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 25Waiting to breach the barricades* ANGER ON CAMPUS IndonesiaLOUISE WILLIAMS Herald Correspondent in Jakarta

IT WAS a symbolic act of desecration when hundreds of chanting students from the prestigious University of Indonesia hung a white cloth of mourning across a giant city billboard commemorating President Soeharto's New Order Government and the key role

of the student movement in bringing it to power.

In the chaos of the 1960s, it was along these same city streets that thousands marched against President Sukarno, and when the students of 1998 formally launched their anti-government movement last week, scores of past graduates were in the crowds.

The road which sweeps past the front of the university's Salemba campus is now choked with crawling, jostling vehicles; the large trees and colonial buildings dwarfed by mirrored office blocks and car showrooms. However, the historical parallel has not been lost.

Over the past week hundreds, and even thousands, have gathered daily on campuses across Java and in the major port city of Ujung Pandang, on the island of Sulawesi, unfurling anti-Government banners and calling for an end to the same New Order the student movement helped usher in.

In Bandung, west of Jakarta, two students were injured and two arrested when hundreds clashed with police this week as they attempted to march through the city. In Ujung Pandang, the military watched on as thousands from two campuses gathered to rally in the city. In the industrial city of Surabaya, the rector joined students in a major demonstration. In at least three cities, several students announced hunger strikes.

In Jakarta, where 25,000 troops are deployed to secure the People's Advisory Assembly meeting, which is due to re-elect President Soeharto for a seventh five-year term next week, rallies have been confined to university grounds. Rows of trucks of armed soldiers, police with rattan canes, and anti-riot squads have remained at the gates.It is still unclear whether the re-emergence of the student movement will be a turning point in the anti-Soeharto movement or whether it will be stamped out by the security forces before it even breaches military road blocks.

The outgoing Defence Minister, Mr Edi Sudradjat, said this week that he had no objections to the student demonstrations and to a string of key former New Order figures, such as a former Cabinet minister, Mr Emil Salim, appearing on campus to discuss their opposition to the Soeharto Government.

A former student leader, Mr Hariman Siregar, said: "These universities are the national centres of excellence; the students are mainly from the middle class. These are the princes in the palaces and once they go out on to the streets, I think the people will join them.

"They have seen that this Government is too corrupt and in power for too long and they are united around a real issue, the economic crisis, and so the students can again become the vanguard for change."

WHAT the students' agenda is and how far their network extends remains vague.

So far, protests have called for a total reformation of the political and economic systems. Student leaders say they will step up their actions in coming weeks.

However, three decades under the Soeharto Government's tight controls weigh heavily on political activists of any kind. In 1974, when Mr Hariman led student demonstrations against foreign investment, the protest spun out of control and scores were killed and injured when the military opened fire in city streets. He spent three years in jail.

Four years later, the Campus Normalisation Law was introduced, effectively banning political activity and supposedly sending students back to their books. Several underground anti-Government organisations have survived on the most progressive campuses, but students were again hit by a 1996 security crackdown on the leftist People's Democratic Movement which began on campus in the central Javanese city ofYogyakarta.

A commentator and former editor of the banned magazine Tempo, Mr Goenawan Mohamad, said: "It should be expected that students will take to the streets because of the economic crisis and the sluggishness of the Government to respond.

"The student movement has been blunted, but over the past five years discussion groups have been created and links across campuses set up and the students have quietly begun to hone their political skills."

At the moment, he said, "there is no direct danger to the Soeharto Government".

"In 1965, Jakarta was a small place and 5,000 people in the streets was a revolution. Nowadays the city is huge, so it would be visible and significant but localised.

"IF YOU engage with the enemy too early, you lose and in this case the enemy is a well-equipped army. But the middle class which gained so much economically in the past is losing a great deal because of the economic crisis, so in the future the students may be significant."

In the smokey student union meeting room on the Depok campus of the University of Indonesia, banners are piled up for the day's "free-speech forum", a series of thumping lectures about how people have had enough of the Soeharto regime.

In the lunchtime heat several hundred endure the sun to clap and cheer. Apart from the 10 trucks of troops, riot squads and scores of police posted outside the campus gates, a police helicopter circles overhead. It may seem like security overkill for a bunch of young idealists.

"The Government has failed in channelling the people's aspirations," say two young men, predictably perhaps.

However, of more importance is the immediate impact of the economic crisis on their personal political motivation. The middle-class academic elite of this university can no longer afford to buy books, photocopy their lessons or get by ontheir old lunch allowances, they complain.

A 22-year-old social-science student said: "We feel we don't have anything to lose now. It will be difficult to finish our studies anyway, in the current economic conditions.

"Our families are worried about our activities but we have to do this."

The new wave of activism on campus began last year with the economic crisis and forest fire outbreak, which sent a pall of smoke across the region. Before the economic crisis, the students said, they held token demonstrations on issues such as human rights or stuck to discussion groups.

NOW, they say, they are contemplating breaching military road blocks.

"It is not easy to do," one student said.

"We don't want our actions to be premature and to help form another regime like this one. We are also afraid of infiltrators provoking violence and the whole thing becoming a riot.

"But we feel at this university we have an historical burden."

However, like the disparate array of anti-Government groups, there appears to be no tight network holding the students together. Mr Goenawan said: "The tragedy of Indonesia is we don't have potential leaders because of the habit of fear and the fact that those who have broken the habit are in jail.

"Unless you have a good organisation that can mobilise students at the same time in different places, then the armed forces can still control sporadic uprisings."

However, Mr Hariman said: "If you have 10,000 workers protesting in the factory belt then the Government can dismiss it as `just a riot', but if you have students not going to lectures from the middle class, that is another thing; they are the country's future.

"The Government doesn't need to be afraid of radicals; it needs to be afraid of the middle ground."

urn:contentItem:7V0X-08W1-2RR2-D1VG-00000-00Feedback2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisINSIGHTLettersPg. 10FeedbackHELPING OUT

After the shock, the rebuilding

IF YOU are frustrated that your offer of help for those affected by the fires is not welcome at present, please write yourself a diary entry against random dates in your calendar for the following months. Detail how you feel. After the phases of shock, grief and anger pass, and the hard work of rebuilding commences, I am certain communities will welcome support.

By this stage you may have forgotten how you felt, and the media attention will have moved on. The journey to rebuild lives and communities will have only just begun, and at this stage your renewed concern and support will be seen as kindness rather than charity. Simple things such as providing cuttings to plant out a community garden, or supporting charity events, will no doubt make a difference to friends we are yet to meet.

Glenda Key, Upwey

Tireless heroes

MANY people who work for the Department of Sustainability and Environment are stars. They spend their time in the bush fighting fires non-stop, saving the lives of people and animals and caring for the broken-hearted. Nothing is too big or too small. Our in-law is one of these. He has had one day off in three weeks. We must pay full respect to these heroes.

Genevieve and David Ross, Myers Flat

ABC radio a lifeline

IF EVER again there is a side of politics intent on undermining the role of the national broadcaster, they should be reminded of the role our ABC has played in the bushfire tragedy of the past week. Without exception, everyone on air, and I am sure those behind the scenes, have reported on this most horrifying time in our state's history with sensitivity, responsibility and humanity.

ABC radio 774 has been quite literally a lifeline for many affected directly by the fires and a source of critical information for the rest of us that has helped our understanding of the scale of this disaster and so framed our personal response.

Mary Dalmau, West Brunswick

A hand of friendship

I AM wondering, in relation to the fire disaster, whether a buddy system could be put into operation? A family in the city could be paired with a family in the bush fire area and the city family, their friends and larger family could help that family in a specific way. It may already be too late for this to work for this disaster, but perhaps in the future?

Mary Squires, Kooyong

Pity the animals

IT IS wonderful to see the number of people donating to support those who have suffered as a result of the recent bushfires. Perhaps people might also consider donating to some of the organisations supporting animals which have similarly become victims of the fires, like the RSPCA and Wildlife Rescue.

It is estimated that up to one million domestic and wild animals perished in the recent fires. Even more have been left seriously injured and without their natural habitat, and it is important that we also consider them.

Caroline Spry, South Yarra

Caring for others

THE Victorian bushfires have shown us how sick of being greedy and selfish we are. People are so hungry to help one another and work as a community again like they did in past times of hardship (such as World War II and the Great Depression). It makes life more meaningful and valuable to care for others.

Linda Pearson, Eltham

Spare us the ivory tower advice

DON Driscoll (Letters, 13/2) should come out of academia and have a look! Surely he cannot really believe that fuel-reduction burning has not proven effective. Anyone who has fought a forest fire knows how much simpler and safer it is to attack once it enters a fuel-reduced area. There is loads of empirical data and experience to demonstrate that beyond any possible doubt.

He goes on to propose "engineering solutions around our infrastructure" as an alternative to fuel reduction. What on earth does that mean? Surely not that fuel can be allowed to build up in the forest hinterlands and fires allowed to build up there until they come roaring out to destroy whatever puny defences we might have been able to place around every farm, house, hospital, school, road, railway line, bridge and transmission line?

We need a sensible dialogue on this crucial issue rather than academic obfuscation.

Peter Sheehan, Camberwell

Left in the dark

OUR niece, in her 30s, was staying at our Marysville house when fire threatened the town. Anticipating hazardous weather, we had impressed on her that the emergency assembly area was Gallipoli Park. Fortunately, from previous visits, she knew where it was. However, would a casual visitor have known or been advised of this important information? Could this have led to people's deaths?

No prominent signs advise where to evacuate to in an emergency, and, even if people knew the name of the assembly area, there are few signs directing them to it. Marysville was undoubtedly not alone in these deficiencies.

Furthermore, apart from being told by a neighbour to leave our house, there was no recognisable warning to advise evacuation and, having assembled at Gallipoli Park withabout 100 others, it seemed, at least for some considerable time, that nobody knew what they should do.

It cannot be assumed that an adequately trained leader will be there in a timely manner, therefore such emergency assembly areas require obvious instruction notices. Besides town signs, should every house/cottage/room be given a fridge magnet with appropriate advice? These things need to be seriously considered for the future. Incidentally, our house, like most others in Marysville, did not survive.

John Vietz, Macleod

Tune in, stay safe

MY WIFE was in constant mobile phone contact with friends on that horrific Saturday night in Kinglake. They had lostall other communication with the outside world. On Sunday morning they lost that also. They had to defend their homes (successfully) after the mobile service failed with no information from outside theirpatch. May I suggest thateverybody at risk should buy what we used to call a transistor radio and set it to ABC radio 774.

Barry Norman, Armadale

Have a heart

IMAGINE you are a firefighter and after a long day risking your life to save others, defending wildlife, treasured bushland and homes, you hear you are being accused of not notifying some residents early enough about approaching fires.

If I recall, weren't people in threatened towns specifically told to stay alert and judge for themselves? Come on, firefighters are only human. Sorry, they can't be everywhere. I am appalled at the people who have the audacity to accuse them of this absurd "crime". I'd like to see you out there fighting monstrous flames. Just give them a break.

Taissa Usatoff, Emerald

Siren no substitute

for good preparation

I WAS at the Healesville residents' meeting on Thursday night, when there were impassioned calls for fire warning sirens. The emotion, especially after the swift and utterly tragic obliteration of Marysville, is easy to understand. But the logic needs to be examined.

A large town such as Healesville, which extends for kilometres in all directions over varying terrain and along arterial roads, would be impossible to fully service with a single siren. As also evidenced by the Donnelly's Weir fire, some parts of the town may be in danger while others are quite safe.

Most significantly, if alerting by siren were possible, what would happen next can only be imagined. Panic-stricken householders taking to the reduced number of roads still open or safe to traverse could conceivably result in far greater tragedy than if they had calmly adopted the fire plan that basically remains viable today: monitor the situation by radio, internet or phone and stay anddefend your house if you feel capable, or leave of your own volition (as many here havealready done) well beforethere is any imminent danger.

David Johnston, Healesville

Words worthless without action

WHERE is the morality in the Brumby Government, which expresses public sympathy in the face of this devastating fire tragedy, yet makes it illegal for people to take such fire safety measures as tree, shrub, bush and ground fuel removal to lessen the fire risk? This is a joke, Mr Brumby.

Peter Baulch, Baxter

Safety in suburbs

IF PETER Mitchell (The Age, 13/2) wants to be safe from bushfires, why doesn't he live in the suburbs? People who choose to live in forest take the risks.

We can't just go on clearing trees to reduce the risk of fire for those people, otherwise there will be no forest left. Mitchell says that when he rebuilds he will clear the forest around his home regardless of whether he has permission. He has already lost his house, why must countless animals lose theirs as well?

Graham Castles, Chelsea

Cradle of love

THE wooden cradle that Reg Evans made (The Age, 13/2) provides a beautiful legacy for his community. My son Simon was one of the babies who slept in the cradle (1980). Perhaps some of the families who used it might come together to mourn those who died in St Andrews.

Joanna Baevski, Clifton Hill

Symbols of sorrow

AS I DROVE past Parliament House this morning, I wondered why the steps weren't covered with flowers as they had been soon after the Bali bombings. Has our State Government banned this commemorative recognition of deep trauma? Or do we simply care less when the many bushfire victims are our fellow Victorians?

I hope it is, instead, that we have put our personal funds towards providing practical services to those in need.

Elizabeth McDowall, Hawthorn

Selective facts

ALAN Barron (Letters, 13/2) says the fires were not caused by global warming but by arsonists. He then tells us we have "not experienced anything outside normal weather patterns". Is this why the Bureau of Meteorology issued a special climate statement for January and February in which it lists all the temperature records that have been broken and tells us that Melbourne has experienced its driest start to a year on record?

For years, climate scientists have been warning of more extreme weather conditions. It is absurd to suggest that recent conditions have not been extreme.

Barron makes the usual denier claim that average temperatures have declined since 2002. One only needs to look at a graph of global temperatures to see that the relentless upward trend is within a highly variable year-to-year pattern. Short-term trends are meaningless.

Indeed, given that we are at a low in the solar activity cycle and a low in the El Nino cycle, we should expect lower-than-normal temperatures. In a few years we will be at a high in those cycles. What then?

Keith Burrows, Fairfield

Taking advantage

SHAME, shame, shame on animal rights extremists for exploiting Victoria's bushfire tragedy to push their anti-hunting agenda (Letters, 13/2) . Most appalling of all is that the handful of zealots who oppose duck season are the same vocal minority who oppose fuel-reduction burns in areas at risk of bushfires.

Brett Parker, Creswick

Let's provide a roof for all

THE general homeless in Victoria and around Australia, living in cars or squatting in other people's lounge rooms, can only wish that they were bushfire refugees - with no disrespect meant to those who are. It is time we realised that all Australians are entitled to a good roof over their heads (and good food in their bellies) and widened our concern to all who are caught without a place to call home. The Federal Government's stimulus package is just the beginning.

Loucille McGinley, East Brighton

Extend a hand-out

I WILL be donating my portion of the stimulus package to the bushfire relief appeal. This money should be used to rebuild the devastated communities in an environmentally sustainable manner - solar systems, grey-water recycling - combating the effects of climate change and hopefully preventing another catastrophe as has been witnessed this week. My thoughts are with all those who have been touched by this tragedy.

Chiara Centra, Sale
