urn:contentItem:7VP9-T490-YBDY-R0WD-00000-00AT SEA IN THE CITY2009-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 1AT SEA IN THE CITYPeter Mandel

New York harbour proves to be challenging territory for kayakers, reports Peter Mandel

WARM, full of puffing sailboats and washing-machine clean: I am having a hard time believing this is New York harbour and I am kayaking. It is early July, and three friends and I are determined to see the Statue of Liberty by sea. Not by ferry, though. We want to paddle there, and we've found a pocket-sized outfit, Manhattan Kayak Company, willing to guide us to Liberty Island from Pier 63 on New York's West Side.

None of us knows a spray skirt from a rudder (only my wife's brother, Bill, has kayaked before) but we're happy about our adventure and feel confident as we make the rounds to buy disposable cameras and boxes of energy bars.

Paddling day dawns with an eerie smog that is like nothing I remember from growing up here. The newspaper blames forest fires in Quebec and at the top of the front page there's a warning from the New York City Department of Health to ``refrain from strenuous outdoor activities''. As it turns out, we've got more pressing worries. We find out that, due to the ever-present threat of terrorism, there is a 138m exclusion zone around Ellis and Liberty islands. Manhattan Kayak founder Eric Stiller tells me that when kayakers accidentally got too close a few days ago, army Black Hawk helicopters buzzed in out of nowhere and circled the little craft until they paddled off.

``They'll be watching us today,'' warns Stiller as we get fitted for life jackets at the pier and check out the Necky Amaruk two-man sea kayaks. I knock on the flank of the baby blue one that Bill and I will be piloting: it is solid plastic.

Stiller and his colleague Ray Fusco roll out an oversized map of New York City's rivers, bays, inlets and islands. To get to the Statue of Liberty we will have to pull off a 10 nautical-mile round trip while wrestling with two and three-knot currents. ``The Indians called it Great Waters Constantly Moving,'' Stiller says. ``Twice a day the Atlantic shoves saltwater almost 100 miles [161km] up the Hudson.''

What really worries me is Stiller's passing remark that he used this harbour trip to train for his recent kayak circumnavigation of Australia. Then it's time to load up the boats.

Pushing off from the dock, our Amaruk moves slowly at first, like a clownishly scaled-down version of the ocean-going ships that used to sail from here. When Bill barks at me from his seat directly behind, I realise our slow progress is because I'm drenching him with river water instead of digging in with my blades as I dip down and backward.

I can see this is not the Hudson I knew as a kid: that swirling mass of yellow bubbles, empty boxes of Cracker Jacks, and bobbing bottles and cans. I don't see any fish, but, according to Stiller, shad and striped bass started coming back after the Federal Clean Water Act of 1976, and someone he knows is trying to grow oysters by hanging a net off one of the Manhattan piers.

As we bounce around, trying to get used to the chop, I am staring into the haze to see if I can get a look at the Statue of Liberty. ``There she is,'' shouts Fusco, who is leading the flotilla. When I follow his finger, I can just make out a sculptural smudge in the direction of JerseyCity.

Fusco herds us expertly, like seagoing broncos, and we buck and wobble south past Manhattan's Chelsea Pier, with its gigantic golf range aimed out over the river, and powerful fireboats such as the John McKean which, we are told, pitched in with plumes of well-aimed water on September 11, 2001. We paddle past abandoned Pier 54 where the Titanic would have docked if it had made it and where you can still make out the sign, Cunard White Star Lines. Five avenues east into Manhattan, I find the turreted brick building where I grew up. Once, when I left the city aboard a ship, my mum waved goodbye by flapping a red-white-and-blue sweater from up there.

Fusco is yelling orders all of a sudden and we turn to see a Circle Line ferry bearing down hard to starboard. We've got the right of way, but sometimes boats can't see kayaks and we paddle furiously towards shore. We get the wake full blast and I shake water off my sunglasses and out of my ears.

We are at the place where we will have to power across the busy Hudson to New Jersey, and I am impressed to find Bill is ready. ``Fifteen strips of bacon,'' he keeps saying, referring, I guess, to breakfast, and the bacon must be working since we are moving fast. Fusco instructs us to aim for Jersey's Lackawanna Ferry Terminal, but we can barely see it and we are keenly concerned about other boats. Fighting the current, our kayaks snake between garbage barges, tugboats, sailboats, cigarette boats, another Circle Line ferry and, looming out of the smog, a ghost-pale cruise ship, the Nordic Empress.

Making it to the Jersey side of the river gives us a sense of accomplishment and, since we're out of the two-lane nautical highway, we take a break. Here in Hoboken and Jersey City the only landmark is the Ferris wheel-sized Colgate-Palmolive clock. Our cameras come out for snapshots of the Manhattan skyline.

Fusco is worried the Hudson's mighty tides may turn against us if we don't push on. That would mean not making it to the Statue of Liberty, so we stash our snacks and grab our paddles again, working closer to what I think is Ellis Island with a Victorian-looking brick building and tree-dotted grounds. Then I realise I have been admiring an abandoned train station at the end of a spit of land.

We do reach Ellis Island, but I'm distracted by blobs of sunscreen that are melting off my forehead and blurring my eyes. And here are the restricted area buoys we were promised, keeping us back, with an insignia that reminds me of the 1960s civil defence signs that used to point out bomb shelters in Cold War New York.

We are coming close. I am eager and my strokes are getting splashier and even less efficient as my forearms tire. I can hear Bill grunting, paddling harder to make up for this, and then, out of the blue, our kayaks pull upshort.

There is the pointed crown, suddenly clear of smog, and Liberty's torch reaching and stretching higher than I could remember. The sea-green statue is glowing in the sun, staring down and beyond our knot of boats, clutching its tablet, thinking quiet copper thoughts.

We say nothing. This is not the Liberty we know from ferries and from spiralling up the staircase inside. It is as if we've discovered her ourselves, finding an artistic shape in some wild and remarkable place.

It is time for congratulations. We try to arrange the kayaks to allow everyone to shake hands. I chug a ginger ale I've been saving in my spray skirt, and one of the guides, Theresa, yanks out her bilge pump and fires off a couple of festive rounds. For a second, with these salvos of water, it feels like a holiday.

To Page 2

From Page 1

The flame of Liberty's torch is gold leaf and as we paddle around to the south, then the west side of the island, it is a bright and perfect focus of our arc. At one point Bill and I are between buoys and forget about the restricted zone until Fusco yells. We have not gone far into it, but Fusco is frantically pointing at the coast guard cutter Bainbridge Island, which is anchored nearby.

We hear Fusco's command to paddle back hard and, as we struggle and tug our blades, we can just make out white-uniformed officers and a mounted machinegun on the cutter deck. A US Park Police boat comes screaming out of the haze on our port side and for a second we are sure it's coming for us.

But the target is a motorboat that has whizzed way past the buoys and gone all the way in. The US Park Police take only seconds to get to it and as we paddle away we keep turning back to see what the cops will do. ``Yep, they're being arrested,'' reports Fusco, who has sharp eyes. ``Now they're towing the boat.''

Bill and I paddle harder and harder, churning north, leaving the statue and the buoys behind. A breeze kicks up to escort us up past Ellis and along the Jersey coast and, like a wand, it changes the Hudson into fat and lazy swells. The skyline is clear now, catching the first red edge of evening and spreading it out from sharp piers to ships along the shore. Finally, as we move across the Hudson, it tints our tiny kayaks in alien colours.

We have made it to Liberty, in the teeth of barges and cruise ships, despite coast guard cutters and police boats and forest fire air. And as I search for a certain turreted building five avenues deep within the city, I am aware of one thing: that if mum were still alive, she would be watching from her terrace, scanning the river to pick out our plastic flecks of blue and orange and green. She would be watching us float slowly home along the coast of Manhattan and slip into our pier.

______________________________

&t;&t; Peter Mandel is an author of children's books, including Boats on the River and My Ocean Liner. He lives in Providence, Rhode Island.

HAVE KAYAK, WILL TRAVEL

Getting there: Manhattan Kayak Company operates out of a boathouse at Manhattan's Pier 66 at 26th Street and 12th Avenue, along the Hudson. There is parking (that you must pay for) in a lot near the pier, or go by taxi, subway or bus. Instruction and rentals are available year-round but there is more to choose from in spring, autumn and (especially) summer. www.manhattankayak.com.

New York Kayak Company operates from Pier 40 farther downtown on the West Side. Although it primarily sells kayaks, basic tours are offered. More: www.nykayak.com.

Also on the menu: Manhattan Kayak Company runs adventures such as the so-called Sushi Paddle across the Hudson to Edgewater, New Jersey, where kayakers dock and fuel up with maki rolls at a waterfront Japanese restaurant.

There's also a gruelling all-day Manhattan Circumnavigation which, as the name suggests, lets kayakers do battle not only with Hudson River and harbour currents but with those in the East and Harlem rivers. Other tours include paddles to the George Washington Bridge, Governors Island, Coney Island and the Tappan Zee Bridge.

Dressing up: In summer or early autumn, most New York-area paddlers are warm enough wearing shorts, T-shirt and rubber-soled or running shoes, but prepare to get sprayed and, quite possibly, soaked through. A windbreaker is a good idea if it's breezy or in case of rain. If you're kayaking in spring or late autumn, add layers and, in winter, thicker layering: wetsuit, wool or fleece hat, neoprene socks and gloves, and wetsuit booties.

In all seasons, it's best to avoid cotton since it doesn't provide much warmth when wet. Kayak firms rent wetsuit and paddling top for $US10 ($13.70) an outing.

Stow away: Take dry clothes to change into after your paddle; for the trip, you'll need a bottle of water, sunscreen and a snack. There's a handy little pouch in the top of most sea-kayaking spray skirts to zip these items in, along with, say, a waterproof disposable camera or small, inexpensive pair of binoculars. One well-prepared kayaker I know always carries a compass and a paddler's version of a pedometer, which lets him know exactly how far he's gone.

Peter Mandel

urn:contentItem:457Y-DSW0-0197-528P-00000-00<published>1996-09-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE / SPORT; Pg. 29</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tyson laughs all the way to bank as fans are mugged </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>HUGH McILVANNEY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A succession of ludicrous mismatches for pay-TV is rapidly degrading the status of the world heavyweight title, writes HUGH McILVANNEY </p><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON: Pay-per-view television has enabled the two most famous ex-convicts in America to pick a million pockets simultaneously without breaking the law.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The series of legalised robberies recently perpetrated by Don King and Mike Tyson was, of course, made possible by the fact that the victims had already allowed their brains to be burgled, and left stripped of any trace of the capacity to judge value for money.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> When Bruce Seldon decided - after sharing the ring with Tyson for all of 109 seconds in Las Vegas last weekend - that he would rather be branded a coward and an abysmal actor than hang around and get beaten to a pulp, it was only the barefaced alacrity of his surrender that could be considered remotely surprising.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He had gone through the ropes with less chance of winning than a teaspoonful of spit has of putting out a forest fire.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Sunday Times</p></bodyText></section><p>Yet ringsiders among the 9000 spectators in the arena at the MGM Grand Hotel paid as much as $US1000 ($1250) for a seat and the pay-per-view fee charged to a wider public for bringing the bad smell into their own homes averaged $45.</p><p> The good news is that early indications are of sales well down on the market reached by Tyson's comeback exhibition match with the pathetic Peter McNeeley and the subsequent obliteration of a hopelessly unnerved Frank Bruno.</p><p> But such consolation is diluted when we are told (admittedly by the salesmen) that the McNeeley farce was bought by a record 1.6 million households, and Bruno's embarrassment by 1.4 million.</p><p> Now there is confident talk of conning more than two million into buying Tyson's next performance in November, though it will involve Evander Holyfield, who is so thoroughly used up that some of the old lyricists of the game would have felt obliged to describe him as a pale shadow of an empty vessel.</p><p> What do purchasers of such packages imagine they will see? A snuff movie?</p><p> Eight days ago, the prospect of a serious fight cannot have figured anywhere in their expectations.</p><p> Seldon, whose brief tenancy of the WBA title was due largely to King's manipulative influence on the sanctioning bodies of the world's worst regulated sport, was blatantly incapable of delivering that.</p><p> His antics in Las Vegas suggested he would have struggled to beat the first man he met at a bus stop. He started by going down from a punch that did not connect and then responded to a respectable left hook with a thespian simulation of delayed disintegration.</p><p> It was behaviour that declared a simple truth about the current attitudes of heavyweight contenders. Where once a challenge for the championship was an opportunity, now it is an end in itself.</p><p>Getting into the ring with Tyson and then getting out of it quickly (and in good health) has become the limit of ambition for countless large men in dubious possession of a boxer's licence. And given the determination of the Tyson-King alliance to reap maximum rewards for minimum risk, the halt, the weak and the helpless are assured of a warm welcome to the abattoir.</p><p> Seldon made sure he took his $5m bloodlessly.</p><p> These days the majority of heavyweight aspirants, while maintaining the traditional familiarity with most of the seven deadly sins, are conspicuously short of wrath.</p><p> Tyson himself exhibits plenty of anger. But there are signs that the element of it traceable to his resentment of what he sees as American society's maltreatment of him, and above all his imprisonment for rape, is being expressed through his contemptuous accumulation of wealth from ridiculous mismatches.</p><p> "Up yours," is what Mike seems to be saying to all the people who are clamouring for him to prove himself in real fights, one perceptive student of Tyson's conduct told me from California last week.</p><p> "All the stuff he used to give us about wanting to beat the best out there and establish himself as a true great in the history of boxing has been put on hold while he has averaged something like $20m-$25m a shot for knocking aside four stiffs.</p><p>It is easy to believe there is some gloating in the exercise."</p><p> One certainty is that the present script owes as much to Tyson's inclinations as to the virtuoso deviousness of King.</p><p> The popular misconception that King is the ringmaster and Tyson little more than a brutal strongman performing to order can be dismissed by those of us who have monitored the latest phase of their relationship at first hand.</p><p> "Shut up, Don," the fighter said on one occasion in Philadelphia, instantly damming a verbal Niagara and taking over the microphone.</p><p> He has the unmistakable demeanour of the man in charge and the selection of Holyfield as his next opponent proves that he has no objection to grave-robbing when the price is right. The WBC is moving to strip Tyson of the title he won from Bruno, which will leave him with just the WBA belt, but he is the dictator of the division and preservation of that status is made easier by two crucial factors.</p><p> One is the extent to which his prison sentence reversed the decline as a fighter that was threatening his career before his conviction. In addition to imposing a rejuvenating physical discipline, the jail experience may have recharged the rage that was fundamental to the violent supremacy of his youth.</p><p> Perhaps he will never again be quite as devastating as he was then, but that is where the second helpful factor comes in.</p><p> Tyson may not find it necessary to recapture all of the old ferocity, since he has returned to a heavyweight era populated almost exclusively by men lacking either the talent or the will (in some cases both) to alarm him. Examine the list of those who are set to scramble through eliminators for the right to earn off his drawing power: Michael Moorer, Frans Botha, Lennox Lewis, Oliver McCall, Riddick Bowe and Andrew Golota.</p><p> Astonishingly, the only one with impressive recent form is Golota.</p><p>But most Americans refuse to believe that a true heavyweight champion can come out of Poland.</p><p> Is there no hope, then, of a prolonged and dramatic conflict?</p><p>Perhaps.</p><p> There are powerful rumours in the US that, at the conclusion of his six-fight deal with the MGM Grand, Tyson will seek to break with King.</p><p> In the past such stories have always turned out to be groundless but this time it is said he has hired Johnnie Cochrane, the black lawyer who became notorious as the low-blow specialist of the O. J. Simpson trial, to check his contract with the promoter for loopholes.</p><p> Cochrane versus King. That could be worth the pay-per-view fee.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49K0-22J0-01S8-G0TR-00000-00<published>1986-08-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A FEW ANNUALS CAN GIVE A DAZZLING DISPLAY OF COLOR</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CAULFIELD H</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A few annuals can give a dazzling display of color C OLOR brightens our lives among plants, and annuals have the ability to provide desirable color in a very short time. Not all gardens have space where annuals can be planted to achieve the maximum effect. However, they can be presented in containers such as hanging baskets, small tubs, window boxes and ground-level planters, provided the growing mix is first-class. It only takes a few annuals to provide a dazzling display. The depth of soil need be only 25cm as the roots of annuals seldom extend further. The soil should be well enriched with decomposed organic matter to help conserve moisture evenly, as annuals are intolerant of a wet then dry situation. Commercial soil mixes are useful as a base material, to which additional compost or peat moss can be added. Blood and bone-based fertilizers are excellent, although slow-release granules also can be used to maintain the level of available nutrients. Liquid formulas are useful as a supplement as annuals reach the last stages of growth before flowering. The containers for growing annuals need to be sited in good light for most of the day. However, there are a number of varieties which will grow sheltered. These include Impatiens, Browallia speciosa major, and bedding begonias. All three are short-lived perennials used for seasonal displays. Annual plants which can be placed in containers at this time of year include any of the following: Ageratum _ seedlings only, best suited to window boxes; Begonia semperflorens _ ideal for shallow containers in a semi-shaded situation, also useful for small hanging baskets; Browallia speciosa major _ ideal for sun or semi-shade, looking much like a blue petunia but more dainty; Celosia plumosa _ for window boxes use the dwarf to semi-dwarf range, for tubs try the tall strains such as pampas plume mixed or forest fire and golden triumph; Cleome _ a little known plant, it is ideal for large tub presentation, thrives in hot weather and can reach 1m; Cockscomb _ a stiff plant best suited to window boxes; Impatiens _ can make a wonderful splash of color, small varieties suit hanging baskets or shallow troughs in semi-shaded situations while tall forms suit tubs; Marigolds _ both African and French are hardy plants for warm high light situations, with the French varieties being most suited to hanging baskets; Nasturtiums _ dwarf forms can look very attractive in either baskets or window boxes, high light and a lower than average soil nutrient level is recommended otherwise plants will make foliage to the exclusion of flowers; Petunias _ recognised for the brilliance of their display over a long period, but do not make the mistake of planting them too close as one petunia of the dwarf or compact varieties can spread further than most other annuals.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>In a 30-40cm diameter basket one petunia would be adequate, in troughs or window boxes space at 40cm; Phlox _ another spreading plant but it grows much lower than petunias, two or three plants would be sufficient in a basket with spacings in a trough of 30cm; Salvia farinacea; Blue bedder, Salvia splendens _ varieties such as the tall bonfire and the mid-size red rocket are excellent in tubs, the smaller St Johns fire and scarlet pygmy are ideal for troughs; Zinnia _ suited to open, sunny sites with the persian carpet variety and Z. linearis being the best for baskets. ] ] ] YOUNG plants in containers will quickly bush up if finger pruned early. The tips are pinched out to encourage lateral branching and sturdier plants. It is possible to have up to three distinct flower displays each year by using annuals in containers. Containers also allow the gardener to experiment and appreciate a wide range of plants at little expense, as few plants are needed to create an impact. ] ] ] GREVILLEAS are among the most popular Australian native plants, each year seeing new hybrids for sale. Recently Queensland nurserymen had two new varieties, both outstanding in their class, on display at a trade fair. A tall growing variety, Majestic, with rich burgundy red flowers, is going to please gardeners and birds alike as it is a prolific bloomer. A hybrid between the red form of Grevillea banksii and the cultivar misty pink, it grows to about 5m. However, with pruning in early growth it could be trained to stay smaller. Both parents adapt to a wide range of soil types, therefore this variety should prove reasonably easy to grow. A dwarf compact cultivar, rhondeau, will appeal to gardeners looking for a plant for a well-drained open situation. They are a light rosy red. Many dwarf forms of grevillea have a limited life along the coastal fringe. A clipping after the main flush of bloom will keep the bush shapely and help prolong the life span. Grevilleas have a low nutrient requirement and are intolerant of phosphorous, except in small amounts. The best means of establishing plants is to see that the soil is well drained, with nutrients coming from compost or some blood and bone. Sulphate of ammonia can be applied around established plants for supplementary feeding. Wherever grevilleas are grown care must be taken not to unduly disturb the root system. ] ] ] SOMETIME during the next few weeks well-established hibiscus plants can be pruned. The operation is simple and is undertaken mainly to keep the bushes shapely and induce vigorous lateral growths, upon which the new blooms will develop. Shortening back the bush overall by one third, then eliminating all weak growth, is a sound practice. It also pays to remove any branches which may be growing close to the ground. August-September pruning is followed by a tip pruning in mid-February. About one month after pruning, apply a liberal amount of complete fertilizer to the surrounding soil. ] ] ] EARLY in the life of a young garden, it may become apparent the shrubberies have been overplanted. Should this be so, surplus plants can be lifted readily and transplanted. Overplanting is the most common mistake. From mid-August to the end of October is ideal for lifting shrubs. A light pruning prevents wilting due to the shock from severed roots.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">QCOUML-CML8608092016P202951</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">COURIER-MAILLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49K0-22J0-01S8-G0TR-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244788</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1025"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>COURIER-MAIL</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1986 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="09" month="08" year="1986"><dateText>August 9, 1986 Saturday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="75"><classCode>ST000DSFS</classCode><className>SOIL HEALTH</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="50"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem score="77"><classCode>ST0009FAV</classCode><className>FERTILIZERS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="75"><classCode>ST000DSFS</classCode><className>SOIL HEALTH</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

BUSHFIRES

Lack of knowledge fuelled tragedy

THOSE who know about forests and fire would have understood the meaning in the warnings given by the CFA, the weather bureau and John Brumby on the Thursday before the tragedy. Yet, for the majority, February 7 was just another hot and windy total fire ban day. What they needed to understand was just how extreme the danger was.

The agencies calculate a fire danger index (FDI) that incorporates not only temperature and wind speed but humidity and a measure of how dry the forest or grasslands are. Over summer, the forest FDI generally ranges from about 10 to 80. If it gets above 50 the consensus is that, due to fire spotting behaviour, it is nearly impossible to fight a running forest fire front.

On February 7 the FDI was well over 200. No matter how many fire bombers or tankers were on hand, if a fire got into the forests it would run until the fuel ran out or the weather changed. If the weather forecast had included a fire danger index that was understood to be four times that of a controllable event, the community might well have acted differently.

This would be a simple and cheap recommendation the royal commission can make and something we can all learn to appreciate before it happens again.

Rowan Reid, forest scientist, University of Melbourne

Lives too valuable to lose

I WOULD never allow my family to stay and fight again. My husband and three sons saved our house and sheds. Everything else was destroyed. I left just before to take my daughter and dogs to safety and then proceeded to return to help. I felt that if four members of my family died in this fire, I would want to die with them.

On my way back my phone rang. My youngest son tried to tell me the fire had hit but the reception was so bad I could not understand him. He realised this and jumped in his car and drove through three to four-metre-high flames for 150 metres to stop me. The temperature gauge in his car went as high as it could. He got to me as I was about to turn into our road and saved my life.

My husband and two of my sons stayed, fought and saved our home. In doing so they thought they were going to die. There was a period of 40 minutes that I thought they were dead, a feeling I never want to live through again.

We are all going to need emotional support to eventually heal. Life will go on, but it is too valuable. My advice in future is go early while it is safe.

Sharyn Canobie, Drouin West

Safety in truth-telling

ROYAL commissions on fires and their effects can make massive improvements to safety. There is a real need for the media, politicians and the community to recognise the need to identify mistakes and fire-fighting methods that don't work without the need for unnecessary blame.

Groups such as the CFA, police and others will need to be highly critical of their response to the fires to ensure they are well prepared for the inevitable future fires of the same ilk. They may feel the need to hide problems if the community starts a witch-hunt over the issue. The bipartisan response in Victoria shows the way forward for us all. Let's identify what went wrong, and prepare a better defence against such fires in the future.

Peter Baxter, Ararat

Racism the problem, not Indian students

INSPECTOR Scott Mahony says it's crucial for Indian students to overcome their distrust of police and to "not openly display signs of wealth with iPods and phones", nor talk "loudly in their native language" (The Age, 19/2). This blame-the-victim response will further decrease the trust of Indian students in the police.

His statement is equivalent to telling women not to wear mini-skirts to avoid being raped or Muslim women to take off their hijab to avoid being called terrorists. The crime is people's violent and racist reaction to difference, not the difference itself. Next police will be advising Indian students to go back to India to avoid racism here.

While it is shocking that police treat the victims of racially motivated crimes in this way, of greater concern in terms of changing this practice is that in 2009 police openly admit to it without a clue of the racism that underlies their approach.

Tamar Hopkins, Brunswick

Shame, my country

I WAS saddened and ashamed to read of criminals targeting Indians in Australia. This is just the latest in the post-White Australia policy cycle of xenophobia that began with the vilification of Indo-Chinese asylum seekers in 1975.

During the 1980s, my family and I lived for seven years in India, where we travelled extensively, occasionally to areas where the people had rarely if ever seen Westerners.

Our kids roamed the town on their bikes, and rode Indian trains and buses by themselves. We often experienced frustration and irritation, but never, despite the fact we stuck out and were better off than most of the Indians we met, did we ever encounter prejudice, hatred or threat of violence.

On the contrary, we remember regular instances of friendliness and assistance.

Of course, countless appalling things go on in India, including attacks on foreigners. However, India's best, which we were fortunate enough to experience, is something Australia should work to emulate.

Bill James, Bayswater

Blaming the victim

RE "INDIANS told to keep low profile". Wow, so instead of increasing policing in the affected areas to keep the crime rate low, Indians should just be quieter. Why did I not think of that before?

Ammu Ruby, Wheelers Hill

Kosky must go

YOU have to feel for John Brumby at times like this. As Premier at a time of a horrendous disaster, he is doing as much as he can to deal with all of the issues that have arisen. What he does not need is for one of his ministers to again publicly demonstrate that she should not be left in charge of the transport portfolio.

Lynne Kosky's close ties to the union that was mainly responsible for the disgraceful nine-hour closure of the Sandringham rail line on Wednesday (The Age, 19/2), and her failure to act quickly to use her influence to fix the matter, shows she should be sacked immediately. The Premier must put the interests of the public ahead of internal Labor Party factional dealings.

Robert Cooper, Mount Eliza

Right on the money

THE comments by Professor Mick Dodson (Comment & Debate, 19/2) should be read and endorsed by every Australian. The first building block for indigenous Australians is education. Let's not stint with the dollars, because every dollar spent thereafter will be far better spent than now and in the past.

Lionel Parrott, Croydon

Some revolution

THE Federal Government removes $2.5 billion from future education spending (The Age, 18/2) so we can buy consumer goods, just as unemployment turns people to further education as a way out. Not the education revolution we expected!

Julia Thornton, Surrey Hills

Bump or thump?

THE gabardine overcoat brigade are beating their chests over the Nick Maxwell case, claiming that the bump has been outlawed and that football has been turned into a non-contact sport (Sport, Letters, 19/2). What a steaming pile of ordure. Maxwell was not suspended because he executed a fair bump. He was suspended because he executed a bump to the head.

It is against the laws of football to make contact with the head of an opponent. When the contact to the head is made with considerable force and vigour, it is not only illegal but highly dangerous - witness the broken jaw in this case.

If you believe that charging into the head of an opponent who is trying to win the ball, while making no effort to win the ball yourself, is an act that exemplifies toughness, then your definition of toughness needs a lot of work.

Scott McIntyre, St Kilda

Taken for granted

THE farce of the Edgars Creek parkland in Coburg is symbolic of the disregard elected representatives have for constituents of super-safe ALP state and federal seats. The argument for the public ownership of the parkland is overwhelming but will not be advanced one iota by a letter from Kelvin Thomson, who is hardly acknowledged byhis own party, given the safety of his political position in Wills.

Electors in safe ALP seats never get a fair slice of government support from either party. The Liberals know they can never win the seat and the ALP knows it will always win. If Edgars parkland was in a swinging electorate, it would be acquired, beautified and handed over at a gala event presided over by the PM.

Peter Robertson, Coburg

Wishes to fishes

THE letter by Janine Bjorkman (19/2) stirred a memory. As a young fisherman off the west coast of Scotland one winter's day, I said something to the effect that I wished it wasn't so cold. The old skipper rolled his eyes and replied: "Aye, Stuart! And if wishes were fishes, we'd all be rich!"

At one time we had many of the communities that Bjorkman wishes for, and I am fortunate enough to still live in one. We have a wonderful health system in place, and although we have a few characters around, not too many suffer from mental disorders.

My comfortable cottage is a mere eight or nine squares in size and my car is hardly in the luxury class. But the community spirit is strong and supportive. This is where we translate wishes into fishes.

W. Stuart McCann, Swifts Creek

Speaking of dogma

RE CATHERINE Deveny's "Fear of God, or just fear of a difference of opinion?" (Metropolis, 18/2), you laugh at other people's belief in a God whose existence you cannot disprove any more than they can prove. Yet somehow you take the intellectual high ground and hope to enlighten others if they cannot "be intelligent enough to work it out". Are you sure you don't work for the church? You seem to share such similar condescending, arrogant and closed-minded arguments.

David Hegan, Kensington

Say 'no' on troops

AUSTRALIAN troops are in Afghanistan simply because of John Howard cosying up to George Bush. Since these two men are no more (politically speaking) and because we are not even a member of NATO, Australia can safely say "no additional troops for Afghanistan".

Jim Banks, Yarrawonga

Threatened species?

DR GREG Moore is so right when he states just how important trees are in our gardens and the danger all trees are in due to the drought (The Age, 19/2). The drought is not the only cause of the lack of trees. The area I live in was once full of lovely trees and gardens but now is being taken over by huge houses and hideous extensions to existing homes that take up the whole block. No room for trees or shrubs, just plenty of concrete.

No wonder they all need noisy air-conditioners running day and night.

Linda Jarvis, North Balwyn

Forecasting fantasy

I WOULD humbly and respectfully like to suggest that the most profoundly useless and fundamentally misleading piece of information printed on your website daily would have to be the 28-day rainfall outlook for Melbourne (theage.com.au).

We all know that the Bureau of Meteorology struggles to get precipitation predictions even 24 hours out correct, so why persist with these preposterous 28-day fantasy forecasts? Much better that I receive a text message from the bureau when they can actually see the rain falling from their office windows.

David Coorey, Brunswick

urn:contentItem:4P0N-6D00-TXN5-S2JT-00000-00A balance for our cut-price nature2002-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1A balance for our cut-price natureDavid Elias

What is mother nature worth to the world? A team of international scientists has dared to put a $US33 trillion a year price tag on the critical life support systems that provide us with air to breathe, clean our water, break down waste and maintain the fertility of the soil.

They started a forest fire of debate that is still burning with great intensity. Detractors described it as bad economics and bad ecological science.

Mostly the critics were fearful of the effect that a figure nearly twice the size of the world's GDP would have on the provision of goods and services should they ever be required to take the cost of these ecosystem "services" into account.

The scientists, mostly American university academics, published their findings in the magazine Nature in 1997 because they thought it would be useful to ecologists, economists, policy makers and the general public. They said ecological systems contributed to human welfare, directly and indirectly, and therefore represented part of the total economic value of the planet.

So what is nature worth in Australia, where salinity threatens vast tracts of agricultural land and passions raised by logging native forests obscure the economics of the debate?

Don Henry, chief executive of the Australian Conservation Foundation, has complained about the low priority assigned to the other values and services that forests provide, such as biodiversity habitat, water quantity and quality, and employment in tourism and recreation industries.

Mr Henry raised the issue last year in a foreword to an ACF-commissioned report on the application of national competition policy to forestry. The report found that the playing field was tilted against plantations and farm forestry in favour of the exploitation of state-owned native forests.

He said other values had been under-stated relative to timber. And, although water, telecommunications, electricity and gas had to stand on their own, forest departments remained insulated and protected from competition.

Work on the economics of nature seems to be in its infancy. Comparative studies have been able to pinpoint instances in which the water from forests left standing might have a greater value than the timber felled. However, the abandonment of the Kyoto protocol on greenhouse emissions has retarded efforts to put a dollar value on carbon sinks vital to the development of market-based carbon trading systems.

Dr John Wamsley, managing director of the eco-company Earth Sanctuaries, proved a point by using the international accounting standard AASB 1037 on self-generating and regenerating assets to value his wildlife. It let him book an operating profit of $2 million in 2000, but later the debt-laden company had to sell some properties and change its structure.

Bureau of Tourism Resource surveys of visitors as they leave Australia show that over 50 per cent visit a national park, but it has been left to researchers like John Ward, a lecturer in eco-tourism at Griffith University to flesh out the details. He has surveyed people in forest car parks to establish comparative values of logging and tourism.

The CSIRO division of wildlife and ecology is midway through the most ambitious research of all, a $1 million project funded by the Myer Foundation that seeks to put a dollar value on Australia's ecosystem services.

The project co-ordinator, Dr Steven Cork, says that in economic analyses, close to zero value has been put on filtering, purifying, stabilising and revitalising processes that would be hugely expensive to replace with technology even if such capacity

existed.

Conservation seems not to pay when compared with the economic return that society gets from converting natural assets into commercial ones. People believe they would be better off by giving up natural assets for pastures, roads and other developments.

Professor Pearce, in a Naturearticle, says this is an illusion that stems from the fact that services provided by ecological systems are not usually traded.

"Because we do not buy and sell clean air, tranquillity, watershed protection, nutrient cycling or carbon storage, the value of such services is naturally perceived to be zero (or nearly so) and conservation loses. Governments everywhere make the odds against conservation even worse by subsidising irrigation water, energy, fertiliser, pesticides, agricultural output, fishing and transport. Few subsidise conservation on any significant scale."

The most obvious and most contentious environmental economic arguments in Australia centre on the forests, from which more than 23 billion cubic metres of timber is cut each year from 164.4 million hectares of native forest and woodland, and 1.5 million hectares of plantation.

According to the latest figures from the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics, Australia's forest production is valued at almost $14 billion a year and provides about $2.27 billion in wages for nearly 9000 workers.

However, Australia's consumption runs well ahead of production, and the nation remains a net importer of timber products to the value of almost $2 billion a year.

Victoria's contribution is about one-third - 794 million cubic metres of timber from 7.7 million hectares of native forest and woodland, and about 320,000 hectares of plantation.

The State Government says the native-forest industry is worth $540 million a year and creates direct employment for 4000 people. Indirectly it creates another 6000 jobs, mainly in regional industries that in 1999 contributed $1.8 billion to the state's total output of $151 billion.

The native-forest industry is contentious because the most desirable trees for timber cutters - particularly for furniture but also flooring and some house framing - are also the most aesthetically desirable and environmentally sensitive. Virtually all of Victoria's sawn hardwood is grown on public land, an important element for the tourism industry.

The 2001 National Forest inventory shows that Australia has 42.5 million hectares of open forest, of which 5.4 million hectares are in Victoria. Only 5.13 million hectares of closed forest remain, of which 3 million hectares are in Queensland and only 19,000 hectares, the smallest figure for any state, are in Victoria.

Under its new forestry policy the Victorian government has reduced the area of public land it considers suitable for timber harvesting from 1.2 million hectares to 700,000 hectares and, having established the biologically sustainable yield at 567,500

cubic metres a year, it is trying to cut logging licence levels by 30 per cent.

Among a range of industry reforms it has set up a new commercial forest service entity, VicForests, to achieve an ecologically sustainable management regime.

The state has committed up to $80 million to its reforms which Judy Clark, a post-doctoral fellow at the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies at the Australian National University, describes as unusual. She says the timber industry has been undergoing a big structural change prompted by the development of private plantations. She says the government is compensating an industry as it enhances its competitiveness.

The Bracks Government is trying to walk a fine line between the timber industry workforce in the electorally sensitive regions and media-savvy environmentalists.

During a recent clash over clear-fell logging, the Otway Ranges Environment Network made the most of the alternative economics argument, using research on the West Barwon and Gellibrand water catchments serving Geelong and Warrnambool respectively. The global engineering consultancy Sinclair Knight Merz predicted improvements of 10.5 per cent and 28 per cent in long-term water flow if the forests were left standing.

It found that royalties from logging in the West Barwon catchment at present value would yield $2.1 million between 2000 and 2100. The additional water from the uncut forest, at $800 a megalitre, would yield $11.8 million. Value-added, the timber would be worth $9.2 million, but the Otway group argued that in a catchment, where water is already scarce, additional supplies to water-reliant industries would have an equal, or even greater, multiplier effect.

Before John Ward became a lecturer in eco-tourism at Griffith University he ran his own timber business, and he claims to know forest economics from both sides. He has surveyed 4000 motorists in the car parks of NSW state parks and national forests to find out how much people are ready to spend travelling to a forest for a fishing trip or a walk in the woods.

He says his surveying will show that the value of recreation is statistically and significantly greater than logging in five sites while in six other sites it is difficult to discern the difference.

Meanwhile, an analysis of global timber needs by Judy Clark at CRES in Canberra suggests that the real price for wood is likely to fall.

She believes this will discourage plantation investment on agricultural land, intensify forest management and increase the clearing of native forest for plantation.

She fears biodiversity will be the loser.

urn:contentItem:457M-P7K0-015H-929N-00000-00<published>2002-02-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LETTERS TO THE EDITOR</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Ministers and their bureaucrats</p><p nitf:lede="true">Richard Davoren in his letter (February 18) on plans to bulldoze a new entrance for the Prosser River highlights a significant failing in our governmental processes.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He says: "There is a woeful inadequacy in the communication process and the department appears to be misleading both the Minister and the public about this matter".</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Minister David Llewellyn carries a considerable responsibility -- police, the environment, national parks, fisheries, public land management, agriculture, aquaculture and water management. Little wonder he is dubbed "the minister for everything"!</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Under our system of government, ministers rely on advise from their departments. Indeed, departmental public servants usually compose letters of response (to constituents such as Mr Davoren) which are duly signed by the minister. Little wonder then that both ministers and the public can be misled simultaneously. There are numerous recent instances of ministers, even prime ministers, seemingly being misled by bureaucrats . . . (Nigel Hawthorne is dead, but Sir Humphrey lives on!)</p><p>This is a systemic problem with the administration of public governance. However, elected ministers and the public are entitled to receive "the whole truth and nothing but the truth". Regrettably, time and again truth is the first casualty when precious personalities and prestige are at stake.</p><p>David Obendorf</p><p>West Hobart</p><p>Buy an</p><p>Incat vessel</p><p>How can Premier Jim Bacon expect anyone to buy one of Incat's vessels when the message he is sending the world is that they aren't good enough for Tasmania?</p><p> Governments don't have their own money, they have taxpayers' money. It is vital and timely that Tasmanian taxpayers' money be invested in Tasmanian jobs.</p><p> We still have debt on the Spirit of Tasmania. It should be retained on its run and, as all the experts have been saying for years, the right Incat vessel purchased and run on the correct route, allowing two crossings a day, boosting visitor numbers.</p><p> It would also be a cheaper service to operate and a win-win-win situation for all involved; increased carrying capacity, more reliability and a good commercial solution for Incat as it restructures its business and job protection for Tasmanian workers.</p><p> Please Mr Bacon, don't send Incat jobs down the gurgler by spending $200 million in Europe.</p><p>Hugh Carter</p><p>Brighton</p><p>Mobile phones</p><p>I. L. Beadle (Letters, December 31) wanted mobile phone statistics. Last August, my father was watering his front garden in Brisbane when a young girl lost control of her car while answering her mobile phone, killing my father.</p><p> On February 22 she was sentenced to one year in prison (suspended, with community service) and five years suspension from driving.</p><p> But apart from this, she has to live with what she has done for the rest of her life.</p><p> Silly really, when she could have pulled up on the quiet, wide open street for maybe 10 seconds.</p><p>S. Thompson</p><p>Moonah</p><p>Mission</p><p>I recently had the privilege of attending the Singapore Commemoration Mission as a Tasmanian delegate.</p><p> As we become older, it is easy to become cynical about politicians and younger generations and to think that the 1941-42 campaign in Malaya and Singapore served no useful purpose.</p><p> But, the mission to commemorate the fall of Singapore on February 15, 1942, has altered my thoughts on both scores.</p><p> The leader of the mission and Minister for Veteran Affairs, Danna Vale, proved not only to be a delightful person but also delivered thoughtful speeches -- sometimes up to three a day -- with total clarity and sincerity.</p><p> Her speech at the Kranji Memorial Cemetery was the best I have heard on such an occasion.</p><p> Senator Mark Bishop, the Shadow Minister for Veteran Affairs, also accompanied the mission and accepted his lesser role with unobtrusive dignity and friendly attention.</p><p> The mission planning and subsequent implementation under Maj-Gen Paul Stevens was remarkable for its attention to the smallest detail and flexibility.</p><p>Gordon Hale</p><p>State President</p><p>Tasmanian Ex-POW Association</p><p>Austins Ferry</p><p>Safe cycleway</p><p>I refer to Jack Buzelin's letter ("When cycling is a health hazard", February 25).</p><p> Jack will be pleased to know that the Hobart and Glenorchy City Councils are combining resources to develop and install directional signage for the Intercity Cycleway. The planning for this is well advanced and works will occur this financial year. Jack mentions a lack of warning signage along the cycleway which I find difficult to understand.</p><p> There is in place already all the necessary warning and regulatory signage to control cyclists and motorists on those roads that cross the cycleway and they are all to the standards required by the Department of Infrastructure, Energy and Resources.</p><p> Jack's implication that cycling on the cycleway is in some way unsafe is alarmist. Most citizens would consider the cycleway a wonderful, safe, easy to use facility which has done much for the health and recreational needs of Hobart residents and visitors.</p><p> Jack, get that bike off the hook in the back shed and have another realistic look at the cycleway -- it's really not that dangerous and we are working to make it even safer.</p><p>(Ald) Jeff Briscoe</p><p>Chairman</p><p>Hobart Bicycle</p><p>Advisory Committee</p><p>Hobart</p><p>Hypocrisy</p><p>In commenting on the position of Governor-General Peter Hollingworth, Prime Minister John Howard was recently quoted as saying, "These are not issues that should be determined by the volume on talkback radio or on the front page of the newspapers" (The Mercury, February 26).</p><p> If this test was consistently applied to all issues of national importance, it would be a credible statement. Unfortunately, given recent events, it is nothing short of gross hypocrisy.</p><p>Tim Moltmann and Julie Carr</p><p>West Hobart</p><p> I sit in my office bewildered and lost for words at this senseless act of vandalism and destruction forced upon two fellow contractors, their employees and families.</p><p> All anti-logging movements and members (Doctors for Forests, Lawyers for Forests and the like) should hide their heads in shame. It's their militant and one-sided views that incite this form of extreme vandalism.</p><p> Now everyday city folk can see how extreme these people are. They are not interested in balanced, sustainable world's best logging practices; they want no logging at all. It's plain to see this is their ultimate agenda. If the perpetrators of this act are apprehended they should be dealt with in the same contemptible way they have shown Mr Howells and Mr Hazelwood.</p><p> Our personal business insurances skyrocketed last year. I would expect we can look forward to much the same this year. Don't give up Rodney and Terry; we are all behind you.</p><p>Michael Woods</p><p>Managing Director</p><p>Eastern Tiers Logging Pty Ltd</p><p>Triabunna</p><p> My first reaction to the news of the destruction of machinery in the Southern Forests was speculation about a variety of motives that could lead to such an irresponsible act of vandalism. Having no solid facts, I will keep those theories to myself. Nevertheless, I feel compelled to respond with the following: For the past 18 years I have been involved with the conservation movement, and in particular, the campaigns to save our Tasmanian native and old-growth forests.</p><p> I feel confident to say, we as a group, oppose all kinds of vandalism, whether it be the destruction of the forests or the demolition of the machinery employed to do so. Over the past few years the support for this movement has grown at least as fast as the woodchip piles.</p><p> Going by my past experience, the anti-conservationist lobby groups will not be able to resist the temptation to exploit these incidents in order to undermine the support for the strictly non-violent forest campaigns. (It may have already started by the time this letter is in print). I hope that the media and the public have learnt from the so-called "children overboard" situation. After all, a state election is imminent and we have to be aware of all kinds of trickery and manipulation in the ruthless fight for power.</p><p>Helmut Schwabe</p><p>Ulverstone</p><p> Thanks to Peg Putt we now know that the Greenies weren't responsible for the destruction of $3 million of forest machinery in the Geeveston area.</p><p> That now makes it easier to identify the real culprits. It must have been a forest fire out of control associated with very high winds. If that's not the case, I hear that foxes are quite intelligent and are probably responsible.</p><p>Matthew Riggs</p><p>Rokeby</p><p> Mike Heywood (Letters, February 27) is mistaken in naming the perpetrators of recent vandalism in the Southern Forests as "environmental terrorists".</p><p> These as yet unidentified people are industrial vandals or saboteurs. The true environmental terrorists are the industries which rely on the destruction of old-growth forests and rainforest habitat and the Bacon/Lennon Government that provides overwhelming support for these industries.</p><p>David J. Bowden</p><p>North Hobart</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P7G-YF90-TXN5-R2VD-00000-00GOOD NEWS FOR SEVEN1988-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisTELEVISIONPg. 61GOOD NEWS FOR SEVENKEVIN SADLIER

THIS is the story of an extraordinary battle for ratings between two rival commercial television news bulletins.

What's extraordinary about it is that Channel 7 and Channel 10 are not fighting for first place. The battle is all about coming second, behind Channel 9.

As Geraldine Doogue, co-reader of Channel 10's Eyewitness News Hour, says: "We want to be number two." So much for ambition.

Geraldine's problem is that Channel 10's news is NOT number two. Not any more.

Way out in front is the unflappable, affable Brian Henderson at 6pm, followed by TV's iron butterfly, Jana Wendt, at 6.30pm.

Over the past few weeks, second place has switched from Steve Liebmann and Doogue on Channel 10 to the soap opera, Home and Away, and the news-reading team of Richard Zachariah and Ann Sanders on Channel 7.

Why?

Media analyst Garry Maddox, who with Stephen Wall, of Horan, Hall and Walker, has just prepared a Federal Government report on quality programming for SBS, blamed the one-hour news format.

STILL CONFIDENT

"With a one-hour news, there always tends to be a dead spot," he said. "Once you get the main news out of the way, there tends to be a slackening of pace somehow before you get to the sport. It's a problem they find very difficult to overcome."

The incumbent Eyewitness News Hour presenters, Doogue and Liebmann, have no answer to why they have gone down, down, down.

"I don't understand it, I just don't understand it," said Doogue.

"Perhaps Home and Away is biting more than we thought - you never can tell with soaps. When a soap takes off, you just have to sit it out."

Doogue remains confident, however. "By the end of this year, we will be nice and stable and sitting on number two," she said.

Said Liebmann: "If we knew the answer, it would be that much easier. The volatility of the figures is confusing. I just don't know why one week you can get 21 ... 22, and the next week you can be down to 15."

According to Liebmann, there will be no panic moves at Channel 10 to counteract the fall. "The whole approach here is steady as she goes," he said

"There's no panic, contrary to all the rumours. A half-hour news, that's one of the stories, with Page One in at 6.30. That's ridiculous. They're not changing anything."

Two previous Channel 10 newsreaders, Eric Walters and John Bailey, have their own theories about the demise.

Walters, now with Channel 9's Today Show, said: "I put it down to 60 minutes of double heads.

"We only had a single head up to 1978 when I left. People would accept the hour but they wouldn't accept the double head.

PULLED PLUG

"I've never been able to understand either 10 or 7 never twigging that it was the double header that people didn't want."

Walters recalled that last Sunday was the 10th anniversary of his sacking by Channel 10.

"They brought in American consultants who wanted to turn the news into a circus," he said. "I kept saying, 'I'll do whatever you want, but I'll do it professionally. Don't ask me to become part of the circus,' and then finally they just pulled the plug."

Walters was replaced by John Bailey, who is now John Laws' producer at 2UE

Bailey, who co-read the news with Katrina Lee - and was in turn replaced by Ron Wilson, who was replaced by Tim Webster - said he now believed the one-hour news format was a mistake.

"I think they have to look at going back to 30 minutes," he said.

"I feel 10's news is a bit tired, so I tend to watch Hendo because of the crispness of Channel 9's news. I don't think I'm getting more news on 10, just that it's a bit more laboured.

"And I'm still not sure that a full rapport exists between Steve and Geraldine. Individually, they are very good.

"It's been a bugbear of mine for years that there seems to be this strange thinking with management here that you can just take two good people and throw them together and it will automatically work.

"It's a lot more complex than that. The chemistry has to be just right. It's a very delicate thing."

Tom Barnett was director of news at Channel 10 for both the launch of the one-hour bulletin in 1975 and the two-headed, one-hour bulletin which followed in 1978.

Barnett, now director of programs and operations for Sky Channel, said the problem with both the Channel 7 and Channel 10 news bulletins was that there had been too many changes.

"The formula for success is consistency," he said. "At Seven and Ten there have been too many changes in front of the camera and too many changes behind the camera.

"If you look at the most successful news in Australia, which is the Channel 9 news, there have been no changes."

A REAL CANING

Out at Channel 7's Epping studios, where this week's ratings brought renewed smiles to the faces of the newsroom personnel, Richard Zachariah was incredulous.

"Are you actually going to write about this?" he said. "This is the great untold story, the fact that we've been giving them a caning."

Forget about the much bigger caning from Channel 9. This is, after all, a battle for second place in the news ratings and Zachariah has every reason to be pleased that it has happened.

"Look, I know what the problem was at the beginning," he said. "I was the new kid on the block. I'd been reaching five per cent of the market with Eleven AM but this was prime time.

"All it needed was time. No-one thought it was going to be easy and no-one thought it was going to happen overnight," he said.

Like Tom Barnett, Zachariah also recognised the importance of consistency. "It just doesn't happen overnight. News is about people getting used to you, like an old armchair."

And, now with the rumour mill working overtime at Channel 10 ("We're not going to half-an-hour," said Liebmann), all is quiet, for the time being, at Epping.

"Exactly," said Zachariah. "We've put the forest fire out."

Not quite! Zachariah is about to go on holidays, to be replaced by the former Channel 7 news reader, Ross Symonds.

Three Illus: RUNNERS-UP SMILES: Seven's Ann Sanders and Richard Zachariah. TRAILING THIRD: Ten's Geraldine Doogue and Steve Liebmann. WAY AHEAD: Nine's perennial winner, Brian Henderson.
