urn:contentItem:5B21-FJ71-JD3N-52ND-00000-00THE THIN BROWN LINE2013-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisMAGAZINEPg. 14THE THIN BROWN LINEBy Greg Bearup

IN THE BLUE MOUNTAINS, WEST OF SYDNEY, ARMAGEDDON IS APPROACHING. THERE'S A RADICAL PLAN - BUT CAN A CRACK TEAM OF REMOTE AREA FIREFIGHTERS PULL IT OFF?

It isn't such a bad day. The winds are light, it's forecast to reach a pleasant 23 degrees and there's no fire ban; a relief after weeks of unseasonal highs and evil westerlies. It's the morning of Wednesday, October 16, and a posse of army engineers is deployed to the Marrangaroo Army Camp near Lithgow, NSW. They are training to search for improvised explosive devices - the home-made bombs that have killed and disfigured so many of their comrades in Iraq and Afghanistan. Sweeping the ground with metal detectors, the sappers locate their deadly foe lurking in the dirt. The bomb disposal expert lays a demolition charge, lights the 30-second fuse and shouts "Fire on!" as they retreat to safety. Boom! A piece of white-hot shrapnel fizzes through the air, landing in a patch of parched grass, sparking a fire that spreads quickly on the live firing range.

Army fire crews are dispatched and firefighters sent from Lithgow. The first half-hour is crucial to containment - if they can reach it before it grows to a hectare in size, they'll have a chance. They arrive well within time but are unable to attack it, fearing the blaze will set off unexploded bombs. They wait for it to emerge onto safer terrain but the beast has been unleashed. The State Mine fire is on the rampage.

In his office at the Blue Mountains Fire Control Centre in Katoomba, David Jones, 57, the local Rural Fire Service (RFS) manager, sees the fire alert pop up on his computer screen at around noon. That afternoon, he and the area's police superintendent, Darryl Jobson, drive to Lithgow, 40km away. It's a neighbourly visit. They want to know how they can help and what containment strategy will be used to halt the fire's spread onto their patch in the mountains. They drive home late that night and Jones rises early the next morning; already he can hear an ominous wind howling outside. It is going to be a horrid day.

He gathers his wife and two daughters, aged 17 and 19. "Righto," he says, "what are your survival plans for today?" Same plan as always, Dad, they chorus - we'll all meet up at the Fire Control Centre. "Goodo." He hugs and kisses his girls and his wife. An almost-reformed smoker, Jones pops into a shop on the way to work, buys a packet of ciggies and sucks the smoke deep into his lungs to settle the nerves.

He and Jobson drive back to Lithgow for another briefing. The situation is grim: the fire is advancing at a phenomenal rate, so they return to the mountains to prepare. At 12.20pm, as they are pulling into the car park of his office, they hear a radio report that another fire has started at Mt York and is heading towards Mt Victoria, a town of 800 people 16km south east of Lithgow. It was ignited by a power line, downed by the 80km/h gusts. This is Jones's patch. "Oops," he says to the policeman, "here comes our first fight."

Four fire trucks are dispatched and RFS strike teams are alerted. Jones and his team move to his operations room, with its giant map of the Blue Mountains on the wall. Dozens of emergency calls flood in; so many that his staff are unable to answer them all and the overflow is diverted to RFS headquarters. The crews on the ground almost have things contained when a huge gust of wind thunders through, picking up a chunk of fire and hurling it over the firemen, who are forced to retreat. It is now heading directly towards Mt Victoria. Jones takes a call on his personal mobile - it's RFS headquarters. Two elderly people are trapped in their home in the path of the fire. He scribbles down the details and a crew is diverted to rescue them. Every available unit is dispatched to Mt Victoria.

Just as this is happening, at 1.27pm, another fire alert flashes across his screen. The high winds have downed a power line at Springwood and flames are galloping towards homes and 6000 residents at nearby Winmalee, 80km west of Sydney. Some of the trucks heading to Mt Victoria are diverted. They are now fighting a battle on two fronts, 50km apart. Jones looks around the operations room and watches the colour drain from the faces of his staff. He says to himself what everyone is thinking. "I hope we don't lose anyone. Please don't let people die."

An RFS Airview helicopter happens to be above Winmalee and streams live video footage of the fire's advance into the operations room. Jones, a 32-year veteran, has never seen a forest fire move this rapidly. At 1.50pm he strides into his office and dials the Red Phone at RFS headquarters in Homebush, in Sydney's west. Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons and his senior staff gather to hear his call. It is now considered too late for people to flee. "Gentlemen," Jones says. "We need to issue an emergency warning for a 'stay and shelter'." Within minutes the fire has jumped Hawkesbury Road and houses in suburban streets with nice, comforting names like Sunny Ridge Road and Buena Vista Road are engulfed in a terrifying inferno.

Jane Boys, a nurse, is on a day off and is checking the web and listening to the radio, but the first she hears of imminent danger is an explosion in her backyard in Emma Parade. Out the front, an off-duty policeman is running from house to house, banging on doors, screaming, "Just get out! Just get out!" Boys and her neighbours scramble up the road to safety with pets and photos and iPads. Within a few hours the fire has raced 10km down the mountain, jumped the Nepean River and destroyed almost everything in its path.

People tell Jones they can see when he's processing information because he starts to blink rapidly. Today his lids are pumping like the shutter of a paparazzo's Canon. He's almost overloaded. Information is coming in from headquarters, from crews on the ground, from the public, from the Bureau of Meteorology, from helicopters and planes circling above, from the media. All the while he is trying to direct his resources to where they are needed most. One of the most disturbing images is relayed from a helicopter hovering above the dense smoke at Winmalee. From its thermal imaging camera, Jones can see dozens of neatly spaced blocks of red. He knows these are images of burning houses. He can only hope there are no people inside. Late in the day the RFS padre arrives. He takes one look at Jones and says, "Mate, you look like you need a coffee." He returns with a warm brew. "You look absolutely shell-shocked."

Late that night Jones walks into his house, exhausted and emotional, to be greeted by his wife Judith. "It's an absolute bloody shambles," he says. "I think I've lost 50 or 60 houses." He still doesn't know if there are any bodies in those houses. "There was just nothing we could do. If we'd had 1000 tankers lined up it still would have overrun them." Still, he can't shake the guilt he feels that so much destruction has occurred on his watch. That evening, Fitzsimmons is briefing his minister and the NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell. "I think we'll be counting bodies in the morning," he tells them bluntly. They'd had unconfirmed reports of bodies floating face down in swimming pools.

Volunteers from around the state pour in - the RFS is a giant, well-organised army of 70,000 volunteers and 4000 fire trucks - assisted by fighters from Fire and Rescue NSW and the National Parks & Wildlife Service. Come morning, 366 fire fighters in 54 trucks are battling the two fires on the mountain, assisted by eight helicopters, each dropping 1000-litre water bombs. Hundreds more volunteers are battling to contain the State Mine fire to the north.

Later that day, Friday, October 18, one of Jones's staff walks into his office and says, "Boss, I've got some numbers." He reads out his list: 195 houses destroyed at Winmalee; 10 at Mt York; 146 badly damaged. "You're joking," Jones says, stunned. Incredibly, nobody is dead.

Jones doesn't have time to dwell on it as fires are still burning uncontrolled throughout the mountains. One of his fire analysts unfurls a big map of the Blue Mountains on his desk with crayon markings all over it; the planner and his team have been predicting what might happen in the days ahead by studying wind and weather forecasts. Red lines run deep into the major population centres of Blackheath, Katoomba, Leura and Springwood. "How many houses are we talking about here?" Jones enquires. "Eight to ten thousand," the planner says. Jones pats his pocket. It might be the time for a quick durry.

Dr Simon Heemstra is watching all this unfold from RFS headquarters at Homebush. He's a worried man. On the Thursday, when Winmalee was devastated, the State Mine fire burned an incredible 35km in less than six hours through the eucalypt forests. Heemstra, the RFS's senior fire behaviour scientist, is leading a team of analysts trying to predict what may happen next. These three fires that have caused so much destruction - the State Mine fire, the Mt York fire and the Winmalee fire - were caused by three tiny sparks. They now have more than 150km of active fire front to deal with. What happens if they get another day like they've just had? Or worse?

Heemstra has an impressive array of tools in his kit bag. The entire state has been mapped for its vegetation mix. Fires will burn faster through low, shrubby country than through forests, for instance; eucalypts with loose bark are more likely to cause spotting than those with a smooth trunk. His team is examining these maps in great detail, along with the fire history in various parts of the national park to determine fuel loads. This information is being overlaid onto topographic maps - the terrain is an important factor because fires burn rapidly uphill and then slow on the downward slopes. A meteorologist from the Bureau is on hand to provide instant wind and weather information. Real-time information about the fire is provided by an aircraft flying overhead, using a multi-spectrum scanner which takes images through the smoke. And then there are pictures being emailed from helicopters, crews on the ground and the public on social media, giving them vital information about the formation of the smoke clouds. They are collating all this information with the weather predictions for the days ahead.

The data is being crunched manually by analysts to allow them to make informed predictions. At the same time it is being fed into supercomputers using the latest fire simulation modelling. The conclusions reached by both humans and machines are very, very frightening.

What troubles Heemstra most is a terrifying phenomenon known as pyrocumulus, or pyroconvective, where a large fire marries up with unstable atmospheric conditions to form giant smoke clouds. These monstrous clouds can rise to a height of 15km and cause violent winds and lightning - a firestorm. They have the potential to drop burning embers and cause lightning strikes 20km in front of the advancing fire. If the fire progresses another 35km in one day, as it has just done, tens of thousands of homes in the western suburbs of Sydney and the Blue Mountains are at grave risk and burning embers could land as far east as Parramatta, the geographic heart of Australia's largest city. This is a worst-case scenario, but a real possibility - and while the weather conditions are nowhere near as severe as Victoria's 2009 Black Saturday bushfires, where 173 people perished and 2030 houses were destroyed, these fires are threatening much larger population centres. The lesser scenarios aren't pretty either, still involving the loss of many thousands of homes.

Everything points to Wednesday, October 23, as being the horror day when unstable atmospheric conditions could lead to pyrocumulus. It is now late on Friday, October 18. Armageddon is approaching.

Heemstra seeks out his boss, Commissioner Fitzsimmons, to deliver his predictions. He explains the worst-case scenarios and works back from there - it's the RFS's creed to "plan for the worst, hope for the best". Fitzsimmons listens and then asks a series of searching questions about the likelihood of each scenario; he's overseeing this vast operation like a wartime general, making sure his troops are properly resourced and deployed to where they are most needed.

As a 15-year-old kid, Fitzsimmons joined up as a volunteer and has watched the service evolve from a disjointed, poorly funded outfit run by local councils to a professional, centrally coordinated organisation with proper training and standardised equipment. He is acutely aware of the dangers his firefighters face, having lost his father, George, in 2000 when a backburning operation went horribly wrong. A number of his volunteers have just lost their homes at Winmalee, but are refusing to stand down. He's been up to visit and they've been touched by his empathy. He's a man who's not ashamed to cry.

For a long time Fitzsimmons lived in the shadow of his charismatic former boss, Phil Koperberg. But the public has grown to know and trust him. They like him. He fronts the media with blunt warnings of the dangers, his delivery like a nightclub bouncer explaining the dress code. The pressure on him is immense. He is thinking, "None of these fires is contained, they are all burning very aggressively, and within a week we are going to see a day similar, or worse, to the day that caused all these fires to run and spread as badly as they did." Some radical decisions need to be taken and Fitzsimmons is in the mood to approve them. He knows that "tens of thousands of houses are at risk - it is that serious. We either fight, or we retreat and let them burn."

One of the most audacious plans is known as The Plug, a strategy to stop the Mt York fire advancing further into the Grose Valley with an offensive backburning operation. If it fails, those who approve it will probably end up before a coroner, having to explain their actions. But that will be nothing compared to the guilt they'll feel if more houses are lost, or worse. Fitzsimmons' overriding concern is for the safety of his firefighters. He tells his commanders that if things don't go to plan they'll all have his full backing should they later have to face the lawyers. Still, he's apprehensive.

Fitzsimmons informs Barry O'Farrell of the plans. "The option to do nothing is not an option," he tells the Premier. "If we don't do something these fires have the potential to cause incredible damage. It can't get much worse. I have extraordinary confidence in my team, but this is a high-risk strategy that has the potential to go wrong." The Premier nods and wishes him the best of luck.

The Grose Valley is only a two-hour drive from Sydney CBD yet it's one of the most rugged places in Australia. It's not all that far from where the prehistoric Wollemi Pine grew undiscovered until 1994. When Charles Darwin visited the valley in 1836 he stood atop a sandstone cliff and looked across the impressive forested valley to the other side and remarked that it was "stupendous ... magnificent". Darwin was overlooking where they now plan to put The Plug.

The idea comes from senior Parks ranger Richard Kingswood, who walks into Jones's office and says, "Have you thought about this?" Kingswood's plan requires cutting a 5km containment line across the Grose Valley, by hand, to form part of the northern strategic line, what they call the Blue Mountains "Armageddon Line". The hope is that they can backburn enough of the Grose Valley to starve the advancing fire of fuel, come Wednesday. The danger is that it could all so easily backfire and they'll have a fire on the doorstep of the urban areas of the Blue Mountains.

Just cutting the fire trail across the steep and thickly forested valley is a mammoth task. An elite team of 40 remote area firefighters, drawn from the RFS and NPWS, is assembled. Nigel Holland, 40, a Parks field officer with 20 years' firefighting experience, is part of the team. Over the weekend he and his team work day and night. They descend into the Grose Valley with the fire front 6km to the west of them; they carry chainsaws, leaf blowers, axes, rake-hoes and litres and litres of drinking water for the backbreaking task of clearing a one to two metre-wide path across the entire valley - the thin dirt line. They then wait for favourable weather to light the backburn.

That time comes late on the afternoon of Monday, October 21 - two days before the predicted Pyrocumulus Day. Holland is at home when he gets the call; it's his daughter's birthday party and he's in the garage, cooking a barbecue. He doesn't usually get nervous doing backburns but this call induces "a crook feeling in my guts". His initial reaction is, "I don't think we should be doing this." One of his mates at the barbie says, "Are you sure about this?" His wife, too, is unhappy but says she trusts his judgment. "It's up to you," she says. He reassures her and says he'll re-evaluate, "minute by minute". He gives her and their two kids a big squeeze and then drives to the nearby Parks depot, on the lip of the Grose Valley. It's just on dusk.

Holland finds that his fellow rangers and the RFS crews are equally nervous. Because the operation is being conducted at night they'll have no air support - no choppers to water-bomb should the fire get away. However, they are told an ambulance helicopter with night-vision equipment will be on standby at Blackheath. It's been specifically assigned to support Holland and his team and ordered not to attend any other jobs.

The firefighters are briefed by a Parks field officer, Mick English, a guy whom Holland trusts with his life. His briefing is sombre and direct. English reinforces that this is a voluntary mission; that anyone who doesn't want to participate is free to leave. A couple of people opt out. Holland thinks to himself, "I don't disrespect their decision. I wouldn't go down there either if I didn't know the terrain." There's no swagger; nobody is saying, "She'll be right, mate."

The remaining group discusses the mission and the consensus is that the plan is the only way to stop this fire. "There are only a few people who can pull this off," Holland says to his mates, "and so if we don't do it, who else is gonna do it?" They gear up and head off to the valley.

A couple of fire hoses, several kilometres long, run down the cliff face from the southern Blackheath side. A pump has been dropped down to the Grose River to supply water to the northern side. It pumps water up to a bladder where another pump forces the water further up the hill to another bladder, and so on. However, it only reaches so far up the northern slope. Holland has been assigned to this section at the end of the containment line, where the fire hoses don't reach. A place where, if things go tragically wrong, there will be no escape.

At around 8pm he sets off for the two-hour, 5km walk, descending a vertical 700m through the blue gum and turpentine forests to the river below. He then scales the other side. One section is so steep that he has to use a rope. He is armed with a drip torch, packets of matches, a back-up lighter and a rake-hoe. All he can hear is the crunch of his boots, his own breathing and the chirping of the night forest as his helmet-torch lights up the track ahead. At around 10pm he scrambles up the last shaley section to be halted by a giant sandstone cliff.

Holland catches his breath for a moment before radioing his supervisor. "Boss," he says. "Are you sure you want me to do this?" Go ahead, comes the reply. He asks again, and then a third time. He then checks the wind direction one final time. If it jumps the break, he'll fight it with his rake-hoe, or flee. Holland has a drip torch, but doesn't want the fire to spread too quickly and so opts for a single match. He strikes it and flicks it into a patch of grass. The fire takes hold, spreading slowly westward, the right direction, away from the containment line. For a minute or more he stands, enchanted by the incredible beauty of it all, as it flickers and flows across the forest floor like a dancer, illuminating the giant eucalypts and the sandstone cliff in a soft, warm glow. A few minutes after that he thinks, "This just might work."

He then begins his descent to the valley floor, flicking matches at intervals as he goes. The fire burns slowly through the undergrowth, behaving just as they had hoped. All night he and his team patrol up and down the containment line, making sure it doesn't jump. After dawn helicopters arrive to drop aerial incendiaries - small fireballs - to deepen the backburn, to reinforce The Plug.

At 8am on Tuesday, Holland begins the long trudge out of the valley. Two hours later he and his team arrive back at the depot where someone has put several cases of beer and soft drinks on ice. Holland cracks one open and sits down on the ground, exhausted, allowing himself a moment to feel very proud of what he has just been involved in. He thinks to himself, "This strategy has never been used before - a 5km hand-line that's been lit by a small group of guys in the middle of the night. Normally a backburning operation has vehicles and helicopter support and all those other things and we didn't have any of that." He thought it had about a 30 per cent chance of success, but it held. He takes a long swig and it barely touches the sides. Someone tosses him another can. They've organised drivers to ferry them all home.

As Wednesday, October 23 unfolds, Shane Fitzsimmons is allowing himself to think he may soon get to sleep in his own bed again. The Plug appears to be holding. Other aggressive backburns to halt the State Mine fire also appear to have worked. And the weather - so vengeful the week before - has, overnight, delivered some relief. Fitzsimmons arrives at RFS headquarters to the news that 5mm of rain has fallen across much of the fire ground. If the fire is going to spread rapidly it will need to be up and running by mid-morning, but at 11am he is looking at live video feeds showing "fire dormancy across large areas of the fire ground". By mid-afternoon, Fitzsimmons is feeling like he dodged a bullet. It worked!

Heemstra is in his office on this day, clicking his heels each time he pulls up a new piece of data on his computer. The unstable atmospheric conditions the Bureau predicted are not quite as bad. The wind is not quite as strong - a drop of just 10km/h can mean the difference between a fire advancing 5km a day rather than 40km. The rain was a godsend and he smiles as he looks at the measurements from each and every gauge. He knows that the work of the firefighters has been heroic but it could so easily have gone the other way. It was a case of good management combining with an enormous dollop of good luck. He turns to one of his colleagues and says, "We just kept a tiger in a cage with paper walls."

urn:contentItem:4P8B-R810-TXN5-S1DY-00000-00Memoir lapse2001-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisSATURDAY EXTRAPg. 1Memoir lapseROMAN MILISIC

SUFFERING is good.

Suffering is an essential for the memoirist, whom we ask to peer down a deep, black well of emotion and capture in words that vertiginous feeling for the rest of the world.

Well, in 1991, my father walked to the kitchen and was killed. This was Yugoslavia. Morning was rising over a civil war. The shutters seemed to yawn - and a shell blast blew them open. He died on the splintered kitchen tiles where he fell. Our shepherd dog, Chobi, also injured in the explosion, stood over his still body and howled and howled, until a neighbor took a gun and killed him too - out of pity.

For the memoirist to lose one parent is unfortunate, but to have lost neither is unforgivable. So I have my "missing" - that which the memoirist sets out to find - as author Martin Amis termed it in his memoir, Experience. Amis' voyage was around a literary father, Kingsley Amis. Mine was a literary father, too. I was the son of a poet, and because I want to write, perhaps I should write about that. On my voyage I might discover not just him (for we all want to understand our parents) but myself; who I am and from which experiences, rooted in bittersweet childhood, I might bloom as a writer.

It's a convenient metaphor (of the king-is-dead variety) that my father and I would play imaginary games of chess on the black and white tiles of the kitchen floor. In my childhood I learnt to live in my mind. This was communist Yugoslavia. My father would publish books and then have his passport revoked. I was born in that house in Dubrovnik where my father died; I was raised among artists and eccentrics - a Gen-X child of a disenfranchised family in a 14thcentury seaside town under a totalitarian regime. This is all good.

On the memoirist's checklist I can cross off: Climactic Event, WellKnown Parent, Unique Childhood, and Personal Tragedy. Let's add Historical Resonance.

For better or worse, my father was a Yugoslav - not a Croatian, not a Bosnian, not a Serb. He was born and died along with his problematic country. Fifty years earlier, around the time Yugoslavia came into being, my grandmother fled fascist-held Dubrovnik with her one-month-old son, my father, on a train bound for Sarajevo.

Croatian Ustase militia stopped the narrowgauge train she was on, dragged off the Serbs and threw them into a pit to die. But my grandmother kept screaming to the Ustase, "Look at this child! Look at this child!" And one of them felt pity and said to the group, "Let them go, at least as far as Sarajevo". My father wrote a poem about it.

So I have a story, and no one can take it away. But here's the rub: I can't write it.

Not everyone is a memoirist, though it often seems that way.

Memoir is our most dynamic literary form. It darts and lurches and is checked and continues on every month with a slew of new releases.

There was Frank McCourt's Angela's Ashes, The Beatles Anthology, Dave Eggers' A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius; Martin Amis' Experience. We are not all celebrities; we are not all supertalented; but in one way or another, we are all witnesses. "Reality" defines our vision of the world. And what we have seen, we must tell others.

That goes double for the young writer, whose first novel is a patchwork of true stories. How can fiction compete with the sheer authenticity of experience? The young writer is well advised to drop the pretence and debut with a powerful slice of autobiography. He should find memoir easier to compose, for the facts aren't negotiable. Though, to me, facts are their own problem. Can I remember those formative moments? Can I crawl back down the stem and capture the raw sensations of my lost childhood and bottle them? I can't fully recall the smell of this morning's madeleine. But others have done so.

And some have done so without as powerful a brain or delicate a touch as Vladimir Nabokov, who in Speak, Memory summoned sensational memories like this: "I registered simultaneously and with equal clarity not only (the schoolmaster's) wilting flowers, his flowing tie and the blackheads on the fleshy volutes of his nostrils, but also the dull little voice of a cuckoo coming from afar, and the flash of a Queen of Spain settling on the road, and the remembered impression of the pictur

es ¤ in the well-aerated classrooms of the village school ¤ (and) the throb of some utterly irrelevant recollection (a pedometer I had lost) ¤ and the savor of the grass stalk I was chewing."

Speak,Memory was Nabokov's own paean to his father. Memory will guide me, if I invite it. And where it fails, my best guess will be authoritive enough. After all, I was there. Tobias Wolff, author of This Boy's Life, described the memoir as "the story that memory tells you about yourself". Wolff gave his tale of a child and a parent the momentum of fiction - and a real truth remained.

Wolff's case serves to remind me that history belongs to its writers; history, in fact, exists only in the telling.

Without that barrier between truth and "novelisation", the wouldbe memoirist might find himself overwhelmed by the vast landscape the form presents. With the canvas so wide, new attempts at the texture of experience seem almost obligatory.

Eggers' Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius pushed the boundary of the innovative memoir to metafiction. What can one offer in its wake? Formlessness? A memoir presented as an index to a nonexistent memoir? Say: Father winterwear (cable-knit, Christmas '85, Sarajevo), 189 wit, examples of, 34, 35, 56, 166, 169171, 205, 213 woken by: with hand on forehead, 72; to go fishing, 111; the forest fire, 130 You get it. And what the work might lack in drama, perhaps it could make up for in flair. Actually, no.

Eggers' story of the death of his mother and father taught us that even the most painful events of a life could - had to be - treated comically. The work was questioning of content and form, but Eggers' professed sincerity of feeling, and the hundreds of thousands of Americans who read his book sensed that. Sincerity is the keynote of the successful memoir.

And that requires self-awareness, honesty, bareness.

But bareness is tough. It has a difficult relationship with integrity.

Could I really disinter the circumstances of my father's bloody death and my upheaval to England with the unembarrassed egotism of a daytime TV show? I suppose if my father had told me that it took such honesty to achieve The Truth, I'd accept it as the writer's uncomfortable duty. I wouldn't be the first - Eggers admits in the appendix of the recent paperback edition of his book: "So because I knew that many people would be saddened by the appearance of this book - those who cared about my father, for instance, and feel I was unfair - I figured that after its publication I'd be in hiding somewhere."

To make one's own parent - particularly if that parent is famous - the hero of one's memoir is an onerous task. The viewpoint is both wholly personal and hopelessly myopic. So the final picture may be skewed, but it will be valid. But then, not everyone is a memoirist. Not every checklist becomes a pile of typed pages. Not all writers turn so directly to themselves. There are good reasons. Mine is fear.

First, and rather mundanely, I'm afraid that I'll fail. I doubt my strength as a storyteller and myself as a story.

And it's hard for the first-time writer to separate the two. I put myself on trial every time I sit down at the keyboard.

I don't trust myself not to be wasting my time, not to be deluding myself, not to be creating themes where there are none. And when that happens, one question will remain: Was my life at fault, or my writing?

Then I'm afraid that I'll succeed and thus ultimately lose what I set out to find: my missing. Write it down and you don't have to remember it, right?

Once a real document for your memories exists, it gradually becomes their sole repository. And that certain quality that is impossible to fully capture in print - a body's warmth, if you will - is lost. My father, the bundle of words, will be available to all. But how could the real, warm man who used to walk to his kitchen not get lost in the imperfect house I'd built for him - trapped in unfamiliar surroundings, confounded by a misplaced door, a hidden year, an invention of plot? He'll slip away a second time.

That, for me, would mean more suffering. And I'm not sure I can pay that price again.

urn:contentItem:49KD-6G40-01S8-G1M9-00000-00<published>1987-11-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ANNUALS: NOT JUST A SPRING THING</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CAULFIELD H</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Annuals: not just a spring thing F LOWERING annuals provide the quickest means to obtain a floral spectacle, with most popular lines blooming within 12 to 14 weeks of transplanting. Spring flower gardens can be an unforgettable sight. They are so outstanding, many gardeners think all annuals bloom only in spring. This is not the case, although selections are limited in other seasons. The life of a summer display can be short because of the effect heavy summer rains and the attendant disease problems have on some varieties. A summer showing can be worthwhile, despite the shortcomings. Growth is usually much quicker and more vigorous in summer, because of warmth and humidity, than may be stated on seed packets or the labels which accompany a punnet of seedlings. Plantings should be adequately spaced so they obtain free air movement around them in the early growing stages and then just meet as they reach flowering maturity. Good air movement around the plants helps resist diseases. It produces much more flower power over a longer period than do etiolated close-planted varieties, when given plenty of room to develop. Only about 10 annuals can be successfully used along the coast in summer, with three of these only marginally suited for the humid months. There is however a wide varietal range within each type, offering a choice of color and height. Annual balsam, a form of impatiens, is ideally suited for semi-shaded, sheltered situations. It is a fast, upright grower.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Space at 20 cm for best results. The double camellia flowered mix is popular. The flower color ranges through shades of pink and red to pure white. A smaller variety, Tom Thumb, is attractive, but the flowers get dirty in heavy rain. Celosia is a great standby for summer. Varieties may be obtained ranging in height from 40 cm to almost 1 m. Self colors are available as well as mixtures. Seedlings transplant best when handled while small. The smallest variety is the fairy fountains range which comes as a mixture of six or more colors or separate in pink, red, gold and pale yellow. Spacings should be 20 cm. The medium-height range comprises red fox, with striking brick-red plumes of bloom. It grows to 50 cm. Dwarf fiery feather red, golden feather and apricot brandy are slightly lower growing. The tall varieties are forest fire improved, which is a glowing red, golden triumph and a mixture of at least six colors. Tall varieties make wonderful cut flowers. Celosia should be removed from the garden beds as soon as the main flush of flower shows signs of deterioration. It is a free seeder and if allowed to run to seed, the problem with germination can be as bad as with most weeds. Celosia needs only moderately rich soil but must have a good supply of moisture. A watch may have to be kept for small caterpillars which skeletonise the leaves. Cockscomb is a stiff, low-growing annual best suited for borders rather than bedding. It is a monstrosity or fasciated form of celosia obtainable as a mixture called coral garden, which includes a range of interesting pastel tones. There is also a dark red called fireglow. Cockscombs need a minimum spacing of 30 cm. Gomphrena dwarf purple buddy is a zinnia look-a-like with mauvy purple pompom flowers. It relishes full sun and does not need rich soil or a lot of water. Maximum height is about 35 cm. Gomphrena is popular in public parks where it is used combined with the lower growing orange-flowered Zinnia linearis. Impatiens is almost an all-year-round subject along the coast, however puts its best showing in the hotter months. The varieties vary considerably in height range and color. It is a free seeder and tends to self-sow itself and become a permanent colonist. The second and third generation of seedlings usually grow very tall and the flower color may differ considerably from the parents. Light shade and constant soil moisture are the main prerequisites for a good show however bright displays may be obtained when planted in full exposure. The futura strain, available as a mixture or in about eight self colors, is most popular. It grows from 25 to 30 cm. The low-growing sparkles strain offers two-toned or variegated flowers. Impatiens strike readily from cuttings, therefore a particular color which may appeal can be quickly created. French marigolds just make the grade in summer. They are better in the cooler, less humid periods, because they make excess foliage and fewer flowers in humid weather. There is also a greater likelihood of them being troubled by white flies. French marigolds need full exposure and free-draining, moderately fertile soil. Petunia is an all-year-round plant, although in Brisbane is best from September to December. Good soil drainage with the plants spaced a little further apart is needed for mid to late-summer flowering. Phlox is in the same class as petunia. It will grow and flower in summer. Best results are obtained pre-Christmas, although displays will be excellent if planted in late January or early February to flower at the end of March, April and early May. Torenia is a delightful blue-flowering annual for borders and small bedding schemes. It is a real tropical species and thrives in summer. The flower is not always shown to advantage because the foliage turns a russet color with the blue bloom lost against it. Torenia should be spaced 20 cm apart. Zinnia is a real success story in the summer months. It grows quickly and flowers freely. The tall varieties are sometimes at risk in storms or from heavy rain. Zinnias are excellent as cut flowers if the blooms have fully matured before picking. Otherwise the stem bends just below the flower when severed from the parent. The Thumbelina range is excellent for small beds and borders because it grows to only 15 cm. The pompom or Lilliput strain has delicate flower color and is a compact plant to 35 cm. The tall-growing dahlia-flowered types are a favorite for cut flowers and large beds along with the fluted, petalled happy-talk mix. Zinnia linearis with bright-orange single flowers is wonderful for bedding, as are the strong-colored Persian carpet types in haageana and old Mexico. Zinnia needs well-drained soil, not over enriched, and plenty of light. AVID gardeners who may want a holiday with the accent on a different type of gardening experience should contact Debra Laws, better known as the fuchsia lady of Tamborine Mountains. A trip is being organised to Hawaii in February to inspect tissue-culture laboratories and horticultural establishments. Arrangements need to be finalised by November 15. Debra can be contacted on (075) 45 1595.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">QCOUML-CML8711072015P73334</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">COURIER-MAILLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49KD-6G40-01S8-G1M9-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244788</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1105"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>COURIER-MAIL</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1987 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="07" month="11" year="1987"><dateText>November 7, 1987 Saturday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="89"><classCode>STX000773</classCode><className>GARDENING</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="79"><classCode>ST000D890</classCode><className>HORTICULTURE</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="76"><classCode>STX001826</classCode><className>WEATHER</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="50"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem score="79"><classCode>ST000D890</classCode><className>HORTICULTURE</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

(Slug JAPAN DAYLEAD  sent at 02:02, 595 words.)<<br/> ASIA: OPPOSITION INSISTS ON CAMBODIA BALLOT RECOUNT    PHNOM PENH, Aug 4 Reuters - Cambodia's two main opposition<br/> leaders today insisted on a recount of ballots from last week's general election before they would discuss a coalition with probable winner Hun Sen. (Slug CAMBODIA ELECTION DAYLEAD  sent at<br/> 02:02, 520 words.)< ASIA: HEAVY RAINS FLOOD SEOUL, DEATH TOLL 58    SEOUL, Aug 4 Reuters - Heavy rains pummelled South Korea's<br/> capital today, flooding subway stations and sending soggy hillsides tumbling, while the death toll from weekend floods and mudslides in southern regions rose to 58. (Slug KOREA FLOODS DAYLEAD  sent at<br/> 02:02, 635 words.)< CHN: HUNDREDS KILLED IN DYKE BURST NEAR YANGTZE RIVER    BEIJING, Aug 4 AFP - A burst dyke on China's flood-swollen<br/> Yangtze river unleashed a vicious torrent which swept hundreds of soldiers and civilians to their deaths, sources said today. (Slug CHINA FLOODS DAYLEAD  sent at 02:02, 755 words.)<<br/> ASIA: TAIPEI URGES BEIJING TO RESUME TALKS    TAIPEI, Aug 4 AFP - Taiwan's top negotiator today appealed for<br/> the resumption of talks with Beijing, on issues such as the protection of Taiwanese in China following the murder of a city councillor there. (Slug CHINA TAIWAN DAYLEAD  sent at 02:02, 647<br/> words.)< ASIA: TALIBAN BATTLE EAST AND WEST OF OPPOSITION STRONGHOLD    KABUL, Aug 4 AFP - Taliban forces battled to the east and west<br/> of the opposition capital of Mazar-i-Sharif today with alliance troops gearing up to defend the last Afghan city they hold, sources said.</p><p>(Slug AFGHAN FIGHTING DAYLEAD  sent at 02:02, 649 words.)<<br/> ASIA: MALAYSIA MAHATHIR CAUTIONS S'PORE OVER TIES    JOHOR BARU, Malaysia, Aug 4 Reuters - Malaysian Prime Minister<br/> Mahathir Mohammed said today he may consider his party's suggestion to suspend new bilateral dealings with Singapore following a row over immigration procedures. (Slug MALAYSIASINGAPORE DAYLEAD  sent<br/> at 02:02, 592 words.)< US: ETIMOR TALKS OPEN AMID CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM    UNITED NATIONS, Aug 4 AFP - Portuguese and Indonesian foreign<br/> ministers opened two days of intensive talks here today amid cautious UN optimism about prospects for an East Timor settlement. (Slug INDON TIMOR  sent at 02:02, 529 words.)<<br/> US: RAIN BRINGS WELCOME RELIEF TO NORTH TEXAS    DALLAS, Aug 4 Reuters - A canopy of clouds and a light rain,<br/> sights unseen in much of Texas for weeks, brought a brief respite today from a deadly heat wave gripping the state. (Slug US WEATHER DAYLEAD  sent at 02:40, 455 words.)<<br/> EUR: CZECH PRESIDENT HAVEL IN NEAR-DEATH HEART SCARE    PRAGUE, Aug 4 AFP - Czech President Vaclav Havel underwent<br/> emergency cardiac electro-shock therapy to save his life today after his heartbeat became irregular, in his most serious health scare since 1996, doctors said. (Slug CZECH HAVEL DAYLEAD  sent at<br/> 02:48, 582 words.)< AFR: OAU CALLS FOR URGENT SOLUTION TO "SENSELESS" SUDANESE WAR    ADDIS ABABA, Aug 4 AFP - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU)<br/> called for an urgent solution to the "senseless" 15-year-old civil war in Sudan today as peace talks opened in Addis Ababa between the Khartoum government and southern rebels against the backdrop of a devastating famine. (Slug SUDAN  sent at 02:56, 749 words.)<<br/> US: LABOUR LEADER SAYS ISRAEL MUST TAKE RISKS FOR PEACE    WASHINGTON, Aug 4 Reuters - Israeli opposition leader Ehud<br/> Barak, on a US visit criticised by Israel's government, called today on the Jewish state to take calculated risks for a peace deal with the Palestinians while it had the chance. (Slug MIDEAST BARAK  <br/> sent at 03:09, 431 words.)< MID: ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN TALKS MIRED IN DISCORD    JERUSALEM, Aug 4 Reuters - Direct peace talks between Israel and<br/> the Palestinians appeared deadlocked today, with the two sides no nearer agreement on a US initiative to break more than 16 months of paralysis. (Slug MIDEAST DAYLEAD  sent at 03:12, 564 words.)<<br/> UK: SKASE STILL IN MANSION AS DEADLINE TO EXIT MOVES CLOSER    LONDON, Aug 4 AAP - Christopher Skase was ensconced in his<br/> million dollar Spanish mansion today as the latest deadline in a series of legal moves against him was set to expire. (Slug SKASE  <br/> sent at 03:26, 343 words.)< ASIA: INDIA SAYS COMMITTED TO N-TEST BAN TALKS    NEW DELHI, Aug 4 Reuters/AFP - Prime Minister Atal Behari<br/> Vajpayee said today India no longer needed to conduct nuclear tests and that he was committed to talks to join a global nuclear test ban treaty. (Slug INDIA NUCLEAR DAYLEAD  sent at 03:36, 562 words.)<<br/> EUR: RESCUERS SEARCH FOR SURVIVORS IN BERLIN BUILDING    BERLIN, Aug 4 Reuters - Rescue workers dug layer by layer<br/> through the rubble of a Berlin apartment building today, searching for a 13-year-old boy and up to five adults buried by a suspected gas explosion.  (Slug GERMANY EXPLOSION DAYLEAD  sent at 03:54, 379<br/> words.)< ASIA: 32 DEAD IN INDIAN APARTMENT BLOCK COLLAPSE    BOMBAY, Aug 4 AFP - Rescue services said here today they had all<br/> but given up hope of finding more survivors in a collapsed apartment block and predicted the toll would rise further after recovering 32 bodies. (Slug INDIA COLLAPSE DAYLEAD  sent at 03:59,<br/> 508 words.)< EUR: SERB-ALBANIAN CLASHES MULTIPLY IN WESTERN, CENTRAL KOSOVO    PRISTINA, Yugoslavia, Aug 4 AFP - Violence escalated between<br/> Serb and separatist Albanian forces today, as Serb gunners pounded western Kosovo and Serb officials claimed victory in the central area around Drenica. (Slug YUGO KOSOVO DAYLEAD  sent at 04:13, 661<br/> words.)< EUR: EASTERN EUROPE SWELTERS IN HEAT WAVE    BUCHAREST, Aug 4 Reuters - Eastern Europe sweltered in a heat<br/> wave unseen for decades today, with temperatures of 40 degrees Celsius buckling tram lines, turning asphalt into a sticky mass and swamping emergency services. (Slug EUROPE HEAT DAYLEAD  sent at<br/> 04:16, 470 words.)< MID: IRAQ HEADS FOR ANOTHER SHOWDOWN WITH THE WEST    BAGHDAD, Aug 4 Reuters - Iraq appeared to be heading for another<br/> showdown with the West after UN weapons inspector Richard Butler abruptly cut short his visit to Baghdad today, refusing to declare his work complete. (Slug ALGERIAUN  sent at 04:36, 625 words.)<<br/> US: CLINTON, LEWINSKY PREPARE FOR GRAND JURY TESTIMONY    WASHINGTON, Aug 4 Reuters - A White House damage control expert<br/> was called to the grand jury in the sex-and-perjury scandal today, as President Bill Clinton and Monica Lewinsky met with their lawyers to prepare for their days in the witness chair. (Slug US CLINTON DAYLEAD  sent at 04:39, 591 words.)<<br/> EUR: GREEK PM INTERRUPTS HOLIDAY TO DEAL WITH HUGE FIRE    ATHENS, Aug 4 Reuters - Greek Prime Minister Costas Simitis<br/> interrupted his holiday today to deal with a huge forest fire near Athens that had raged unchecked for two days and destroyed at least 30 homes. (Slug GREECE FIRE DAYLEAD  sent at 04:42, 567 words.)<<br/> AFR: CONGOLESE REBELS CONTROL TWO MAJOR EAST TOWNS - SOURCES    JOHANNESBURG, Aug 4 Reuters - Congolese army mutineers have<br/> taken firm control of the major eastern cities of Goma and Bukavu from the forces of President Laurent Kabila, regional security sources said today. urn:contentItem:4P0N-JVF0-TXN5-S20H-00000-00BOOK REVIEWS2005-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisREVIEWBooksPg. 5BOOK REVIEWSDianne Dempsey, Lorien Kaye, Owen Richardson, Dianne Dempsey, Lorien Kaye

BOOK REVIEWS: The Whole Hog: Exploring the Extraordinary Potential of Pigs; Now is the Time to Open Your Heart; My Ear at His Heart: Reading My Father; Wild Figments; Beds are Burning; The Silent and the Damned

NATURE

The Whole Hog: Exploring the Extraordinary Potential of Pigs, Lyall Watson, Allen & Unwin $49.95

THAT pigs and people have been mutually coexisting for some 40,000 years is one of the reasons naturalist Lyall Watson argues the case for the existence of a "pig culture". By this he means that pigs tend to form societies among themselves and that humans are usually close by - we have always found their company not only delicious but of social and ritual significance. According to Watson, this mutual attraction is based in part on that fact that pigs, in common with primates, are one of the more intelligent species of the animal world. He quotes Winston Churchill on the subject (his references are from the general culture as well as scientific): "Cats look down on you; dogs look up to you; but pigs look you in the eye asequals."

Watson argues that pigs can and do distinguish between self and non-self and they behave towards each other in a manner that suggests they are conscious of the consequences. In short, in common with man, the pig's most useful tool is its brain. It was no accident, says Watson, that George Orwell cast pigs as the rulers of the farm yard.

Watson delivers his hypothesis after studying wild and domestic pigs and then examining the history of human/pig relations; a relationship that, in some cultures, inspires reverence and in others, downright loathing. Watson writes with such flair and affection for pigs that it will be a few days, I can tell you, before I'll be able to tackle the barbie pork chops with my usual insouciance. -- Reviewer, Dianne Dempsey

NOVEL

Now is the Time to Open Your Heart, Alice Walker, Weidenfeld & Nicolson $29.95

THE Colour Purple, Alice Walker asserts in the preface to the 10th anniversary edition of her popular Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, is "a theological work examining the journey from the religious back to the spiritual", a book about "the desire to encounter the Ultimate Ancestor". But, she writes, it is rarely identified as such and her preface exudes a sense of frustration that it has not always been interpreted by her readers as she would wish.

In her latest novel, Walker ensures her "theological" points about humanity's spirituality, its connectedness with nature, cannot be missed. But in doing so, she has created a new-age treatise rather than good fiction. Kate - author, woman of colour, 50-something - searches for and finds enlightenment on two pilgrimages, purging by the Colorado River and consuming hallucinogenic plants in the Amazonian jungle. She discovers the Grandmother, an un-God-like divinity who is present as much in Kate as the natural world. Her lover Yolo also experiences spiritual awakening, among the locals in Hawaii. Kate and Yolo's primary function is to relay the new-age lessons they learn on their journeys. Like her characters, Walker's familiar themes of race and gender are subordinated to her desire to sermonise on the spiritual.

Now Is the Time to Open Your Heart is as much directive as title. Those who share Walker's interest or belief in her brand of new-age philosophy may well obey such a command when reading this book. But my heart, and my head, stayed closed. -- Reviewer, Lorien Kaye

MEMOIR

My Ear at His Heart: Reading My Father, Hanif Kureishi, Faber & Faber $35

ALL the time Hanif Kureishi was growing up, his father wrote. None of the novels and stories he wrote was published, but he persevered and encouraged his son's efforts in the same direction (when he was still at high school, Kureishi was mentored by Jeremy Trafford, an editor with Anthony Blond, and has never looked back). Eleven years after his father's death, Kureishi came into possession of one of his manuscripts, an autobiographical novel about his father's childhood in Bombay. This book examines the novel, and Kureishi snr's other productions, in the light of his biography, his son's relationship with him and Kureishi's feelings about ageing and becoming a father and writer himself.

You also get some self-congratulatory detours into the wonders of London bohemia; you sometimes wonder if the story of Kureishi's father is just a prop for Kureishi's own fairly serious self-absorption to do its stuff. (He talks about how much his father competed with him for attention, for instance when Hanif had his girlfriends around: is there a little bit of tit-for-tat here?) You also get some more interesting vignettes of what it is like to grow up between two worlds: when Peter Brook was working on The Mahabharata, he tried to pick Kureishi's brains about India, but was disappointed as Kureishi's artistic education was entirely English and American - "a mishmash of British sit-coms, contemporary American literature and pop" - and he didn't know much more about traditional Indian culture than Brook. "From this point of view I was a failed Indian, a fake." -- Reviewer, Owen Richardson

PHILOSOPHY

Wild Figments, Michael Leunig, Penguin $29.95

THIS collection of Michael Leunig's work, taken from 40 years of cartooning and writing, emphasises Leunig's longer prose. For the most part, the cartoons sit on the page as an aside or embellishment to the more often than not melancholy words.

Leunig's voice is similar in style to his artwork: whimsical, fanciful and at times sad and dark. Leunig's intention is always to give the reader a shake - to force us to see with his eyes the scabrous texture of our daily lives. Take gunk for example. "Gunk is the material which holds the modern world together", it is "a mish-mash blend of a million and one varieties of 100 per cent bullshit, and we're all absolutely covered in it". Then there's stuff. "Stuff has become a major threat to freedom and happiness . . . It fouls beauty." Leunig is not always comfortable reading. We are all implicated in the loss of innocence; all responsible for Mr Curley and his friends awash in a sea of shit and stuff.

Leunig is vague about how we right the wrongs. Should we throw away our possessions and follow him to the countryside? Grow our own babies? Vote Labour?

Make love often? Will these actions change the world, stop Leunig from feeling sad? Then again, is it necessarily the responsibility of the artist to come up with the answer as well as the question?

Occasionally Leunig puts aside the angst and is simply funny, as in Thoughts About Saint Valentine's Day: "Firstly, do not under any circumstances attend something like a women's writing workshop on erotic fiction. Secondly, do not wear underpants and beware carpet burns." -- Reviewer, Dianne Dempsey

MUSIC

Beds are Burning, Mark Dodshon, Viking $29.95

MIDNIGHT Oil always defined itself as unique. It was the band with a social conscience that refused to sell out. So it's fitting that a book about the band is more than a discography or tour diary. One-time music journalist and radio DJ Mark Dodshon does devote plenty of space to describing the recording of albums, the writing of songs and the staging of live shows, but there is just as much about the band's politics, external and internal. There is not, however, intimate personal detail, a deliberate decision. Nor is there, because of the focus on the band rather than individuals, any exploration of Garrett's recent move to join the ALP.

Dodshon's thematic rather than chronological approach results in a sometimes analytical book, but one that can be disorienting for those who aren't versed in the who, what and when of the band's career. Through the mosaic, though, one gets a sense of the development of a band that went from gigs at oxygen-starved pubs to airplay on 2JJ and 3RRR to the cultural icons who donned "Sorry" suits at the Sydney Olympics.

Beds Are Burning is not an "authorised" biography, but Dodshon describes himself as a friend, fan and occasional employee of the band, and he interviewed all band members but guitarist Martin Rotsey. Guitarist Jim Moginie (in only his second interview) was the most enthusiastic about the book, but warned against a hagiography. Certainly, this is a balanced account, but Dodshon's respectfor the band does verge on the reverential. -- Reviewer, Lorien Kaye

THRILLER

The Silent and the Damned, Robert Wilson, HarperCollins $29.95

ROBERT Wilson's thriller, his eighth, opens early in the morning in a wealthy suburb of Seville; the bodies of the successful builder Rafael Vega and his wife, Lucia, are discovered in their home. He appears to have drunk a bottle of drain cleaner; she has been knocked unconscious and then smothered. Is it a murder-suicide? It is up to police detective Javier Falcon to find out and to sort out what relationships the murdered couple had with their neighbours: the American couple, the Krugmans, he old and jealous, she young and provocative, and the fading actor Pablo Ortega, whose son, Sebastian, was imprisoned for kidnapping and apparently abusing a 12-year-old boy. Various people connected with the case commit suicide or go off the rails in other ways; a forest fire rages outside the city, leading to a macabre discovery; and pedophile rings, the RussianMafia and the Chilean coup and the CIA are all implicated at one point or another.

Making his way through all this is the saturnine Falcon who, like many a crime novel hero, has a lot of baggage to carry with him (ex-wife, dodgy dad, mental problems - his blind therapist gets involved in the case as well).

Some of the writing can be off-key and slightly pretentious, particularly when dwelling on the vagaries of Falcon's emotional life, but Wilson can tell a story and the Seville atmosphere is sketched in well without taking over too much. Wilson also manages to suggest cruelty and depravity without seeming over-exploitative. -- Reviewer, Owen Richardson

urn:contentItem:4P7G-Y240-TXN5-S36V-00000-00The hermit of Kallista1993-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisTRAVELPg. 3The hermit of KallistaMary Rhyllis Clark

TOM TREGELLAS never forgot his first sight of a lyrebird. He was walking in the Sherbrooke Forest near Kallista one weekend in 1918 looking for pilotbirds, which were plentiful in the Dandenong Ranges, when he suddenly came across a male Superb Lyrebird (Menura novaehollandia) in full display. The startling beauty of its long, silver-white tail, feathers shimmering against the deep greens and browns of the forest, and its melodious calling, captivated Tom.

The following weekend was just as momentous. This time, he pushed through the tall bracken and scrub into a damp rainforest gully of sassafras and tree-ferns and discovered two freshly scraped mounds scattered with tell-tale prints. He also came across an enormous hollow log lying amid the ferns on the forest floor. It was about five metres long and 2.5metres wide, burnt out by a forest fire; probably a reject from an early logging operation.

In 1918, the lyrebirds were facing extinction. For thousands of years, the Aborigines had made seasonal visits to the lower slopes of the mountain forests with the specific purpose, according to Robert Brough Smyth in 1878, "of obtaining woods suitable for making weapons, feathers for ornaments,

birds and beasts for food". European settlers also hunted the birds for their beautiful tail feathers and cooked their bodies like pheasant.

On his second weekend at Sherbrooke Forest, Tom made a decision that was to prove crucial to the lyrebirds' survival. He would awaken public interest in these remarkable and little-known creatures, which were unique to specific forests in Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales, and ensure their protection. To do it effectively, he needed to study them at close quarters, and what could be closer than the hollow log.

From an early age, Tom Tregellas was remarkable for two things: his love of nature and his skill with his hands. His hands earned him a living making iron lace work at a foundry in South Melbourne, as a dental mechanic in Collins Street, and finally working in a factory in Collingwood. His love of birds earned him a place in Victoria's history as a pioneer in the study of the Superb Lyrebird.

Tom was not a young man in 1918 _ he had been born at Whitehills near Bendigo in 1864, and spent his childhood roaming the bush, often in trouble for skipping domestic chores. He trained as a blacksmith but, when he married, he moved to Melbourne. He was bored by his various jobs and hated suburban living. His "real" work, which earned him an international reputation but no money, was as an amateur naturalist.

Although he never left Victoria, he was well-known for his entertaining and informative lectures on Victorian flora and fauna and his articles in prestigious nature magazines such as `Emu'.

Between 1918 and 1931, Tom spent so much of his spare time living in his log in Sherbrooke Forest that he became known as "the hermit of Kallista". To make the log habitable, he chipped out the charcoal, boarded up one end, levelled the floor and built a shelter of corrugated iron and brushwood over the entrance. Inside were a shelf, an old meat safe, lanterns, billy cans, tin plates, a frying pan, spade and rough hewn tables and stools. He called it Menura.

Fellow bird lovers begged for the privilege to share Tom's camp. He would meet them on a disused timber track up the hill as his path to Menura was concealed to keep weekend walkers away. Naturalist and journalist Michael Sharland wrote in 1981 about the time he stayed with Tom between 1929-31: "Tom was selective in who he asked. Very few persons ever knew the log was there. Smoke from the camp fire occasionally brought inquisitive visitors.

Sharland described the log as "large enough to accommodate four persons for sleeping, side by side and head to toe, and it was entered on hands and knees without lowering the back, and with sitting room if necessary". Another guest at Menura was the Earl of Stradbroke, Governor of Victoria.

From Menura, Tom acquired an extensive and detailed knowledge of the Superb Lyrebird. With incredible patience and many disappointments, he took clear and vivid pictures of the lyrebird's life cycle, using an old Premo quarter-plate camera with no flash. The two highlights of his life were to be the first to photograph the male bird in display and the first to broadcast the lyrebird's song live _ for the ABC in July 1931.

Esther Hardware has been working on a biography of Tom Tregellas for several years and says she is amazed at how famous Tom was in his day.

His articles were read by naturalists all over the world and his photographs made into postcards entitled, `Tom Tregellas Nature Series', which gave a complete pictorial history of the lyrebird.

When Tom died in 1938, two tins of precious glass slides, photographic negatives and prints were thrown on the Dandenong tip. They ended up at a local market, were bought by someone who realised their value and given to the Bird Observers Club and the Victorian Museum of Birds in Abbotsford.

A short time after Tom's death, the Forests Commission placed a sign at Menura, proclaiming it an historic site and commemorating Tom's work with lyrebirds. The log and his few possessions have been reclaimed by the earth _ but the lyrebirds in Sherbrooke Forest are both protected and treasured as Tom would have wished. Currently there are about 70 birds in Sherbrooke Forest. Their main threat is domestic pets.

While gathering material for her book, Mrs Hardware has built up a vivid picture of Tom Tregellas as an extraordinarily reclusive and quiet man, only truly happy alone in the bush. A story told to her by one of his nieces, Thelma Fry, typifies the man. Thelma was one of the few children in the family allowed to stay at Menura, because of the solitude and unpleasant creepy crawlies. She told her uncle one day how much she believed in his great fame. "What, me famous!" he replied. "I'm only a bloke who loves birds.

GETTING THERE SHERBROOKE Forest is now part of the Dandenong Ranges National Park, 42kilometres east of Melbourne. Take the Burwood Highway to Belgrave and continue on Monbulk Road to Grants picnic grounds (toilets, shelter, picnic facilities). There is another picnic spot at the junction of Sherbrooke Road and Sherbrooke Lodge Road and various signposted walks into the forest. The information centre at the lower picnic ground at the Ferntree Gully end of the park (Melways 74 H5) contains a diorama of Tom Tregellas sitting outside his hollow log and displays some of his gear and his lantern slides. Usually only open by arrangement (phone 037581342), it will be open on Sunday, 25July from midday-2pm.

Photo A rare photograph of Tom Tregellas (who hated being photographed) sitting outside his log Menura at Sherbrooke Forest

urn:contentItem:4P78-1640-TXN5-S383-00000-00Caffe latte . . . and a new life2003-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisAGENDABooksPg. 10Caffe latte . . . and a new lifeHelen Verlander

The literature of seachange has proved remarkably popular among readers. Helen Verlander investigates a burgeoning genre.

WHEN Peter Mayle quit his advertising job in London and moved to Provence to pursue the good life and produce a trilogy of memoirs on life in Provence pursuing the good life, he unleashed a tidal wave of seachange memoirs that are still washing through the best-seller lists. In Australia, Frances Mayes's Under the Tuscan Sun has sold more than 140,000 copies and is still attracting new readers while two Sydney journalists, Sarah Turnbull and Sarah Macdonald, have sold more than 100,000 and 50,000 each of their respective

accounts of living elsewhere, Almost French and Holy Cow.

According to Harper Collins's marketing manager, Kate Wright, these books are literature lite and appeal to a less discerning reader than travel books, with even the less stellar exemplars, such as Ferenc Mate's The Hills of Tuscany, doing 25,000 in

sales, on the back of the Frances Mayes's phenomenon.

The seachange books occupy the space between autobiographies (Emilie Carles's Wild Herb Soup) and memoirs (Daphne Phelps's A House in Sicily), rooted in place, and travelogues in which the author is a transient in an unfamiliar landscape, such as the recent Sicilian travel story The Stone Boudoir by Theresa Maggio.

Driven by downshifters and romantics, these books depict the ultimate seachange, moving to another country, mostly to live out rustic idylls in sunny places around the Mediterranean. Lady Winifred Fortescue's Perfume from Provence, first published to popular acclaim in the 1930s and re-released in 1992, is the earliest example of the genre. But it took mass tourism and the extension of basic services such as electricity and water in the rural backwaters of Europe to make a pastoral dream for a foreign middle class viable only in the past 15 to 20 years. The most quixotic new homes in the seachange memoirs are the grand palazzo of Lisa St. Aubin de Teran's A Valley in Italy and the Romanesque monastery in Rosemary Bailey's Life in a Postcard.

There have been memorable, personal accounts of living in foreign places before such as Mermaid Singing, Charmian Clift's ode to the Greek island of Kalymnos in the 1950s when all the locals dreamed of emigrating to Australia, or Norman Lewis's story

of living in Spain after the Second World War before the deluge of tourism diluted and destroyed its traditional identity. This new genre within a genre, a Clayton's travel book, is something else again.

The Lonely Planet anthology, A House Somewhere, edited by Don George and Anthony Sattin, published at the end of 2002, has picked up on this trend, and made it into Dymock's best-seller list. As George points out, this is "not the literature of movement but rather of staying put".

A House Somewhere presents extracts from some of my favourites such as Annie Hawes's Extra Virgin about two sisters buying a run-down shack in Liguria and Chris Stewart's A Parrot in the Pepper Tree (a worthy sequel to the lovely Driving Over Lemons about buying an old farm in Spain), which are distinguished by a self-deprecatory humour and sense of irony. Other extracts, like Emma Tennant's A House in Corfu, lead one back to the book for a fuller savouring of local colour.

Among the eight commissioned pieces in A House Somewhere, some, like Lily Brett's terse account of having the family's New York apartment burned down by a visitor, sound more interesting than they are. There's no romance in bodies corporate wherever they are, and in the seachange world, New York is just one of those grungy places from which to effect your escape to a villa somewhere.

Random House Australia publisher Fiona Henderson, who published the blockbuster of the moment, Almost French, says that if there were a "magic ingredient" for these books, she'd be off renovating her own Italian villa. Still, the seachange books have some things in common with the predictabilities of popular romance. There is the chance meeting, with the future owners often finding the property by accident, the overwhelming feeling of the house's rightness, the blind failure to see the chosen ruin's large deficiences such as the absence of walls or roofs, the legal tying of the knot in an incomprehensible foreign language, the subsequent rebuilding or tasteful renovation, and interaction with the friendly but quirky natives.

As John Hobday reminds us in his In the Valley of the Dragonflies, the seachange books are the testaments of only the happy renovator survivors and the expensive renovations mask the hardship and poverty of the agricultural workers who once lived there. Only Tom Stone's The Summer of My Greek Taverna, another recent release, differs in this respect and he and his partner are back in California as a result.

In the cosmopolitan variations on the theme, Marlena De Blasi's A Thousand Days in Venice and Sarah Turnbull's Almost French, there is also the happy ever after with the foreign chap who comes with the charming, if bijou, flat in Venice or Paris.

As with the popular romance, escape is all. All the seachange writers to one degree or another are in flight from the violence, isolation and disconnectedness of big-city living. In Tony Cohan's On Mexican Time, an American visitor weeps from culture shock when Mexican strangers take it on themselves to care for him after he falls ill in the street. Especially in the case of Italy, rural life overseas is experienced as a return to an Eden where tradition and community count, food still has real taste and there is time to sit on a stone wall, shelling peas in the sun. In Macdonald's Holy Cow, which lacks most of the middle-class "good life" trappings such as renovations and good food, the author experiences lessons in patience and life's priorities.

Where Charmian Clift and Norman Lewis, for all their willingness to be charmed by their surrounds, could not help but explore the societies they found themselves in, the seachange memoirs are extended picture postcards, celebrating middle-class preoccupations with fine food and real estate. Even when they attempt to colour in the mis en scene as in the bestselling Vanilla Beans and Brodo by Australian Isabella Dusi, they seem more like effortful tourist guides. While the authors provide teasing but slight autobiographical detail, there is no detail related to food and drink or home improvements that is too mundane for inclusion. Every meal is lovingly regurgitated through careful diarising. It is Enid Blyton meets Burke's Backyard. Reading Mayle is like overdosing on souffle as we follow his resolute pursuit of nothing more taxing than a nice truffle.

The seachange books would not work at all if they did not appeal to our envy. It was fitting that Sarah Turnbull should have recently been voted by Sydney Morning Herald readers "most envied person", a description she reportedly found ironic as she huddled with her dog over a small radiator in wintry Paris. Although Almost French is mercifully mostly free of foodyism and offers not a single recipe, it still stays true to character in its celebration of middle-class consumption when the author nearly dies of pleasure drinking hot chocolate in Les Deux Magots in St Germain.

Even where the seachange books try to explore the foreign milieu of neighbours, artisans, shopkeepers and assorted festivals, it is more wading pool than deep-sea navigation, "banal but efficient" as a friend offers of Almost French. The book's "insights" into French culture make it relaxing and unchallenging armchair travel.

The projected movie of Mayes's Under the Tuscan Sun makes the mind boggle. Mayes is brilliant at conveying the sensual immediacy of things and her feeling response to them. We can almost taste the artichoke "drizzled" with the purest green olive oil but at its worst her writing degenerates into terminal solipsism. In the sequel, Bella Tuscany, she spends no less than seven pages, for example, raving about her love of monogrammed antique linen.

The thing about the seachange books is that they are almost totally incident free, taking as their "little bit of ivory" only the daily business of eating, house-fixing and buying provisions, with the occasional tourism, guidebook on lap, to other parts. Carol Drinkwater's The Olive Farm is singular in mentioning a forest fire that comes close to their French farmhouse, the death of her father, the illness of her husband, hiccoughs with the blended family and a nearly missed acting performance in London because of bad weather.

Publishers say that cashed-up baby boomers with a desire to travel mean that there is no glut to the seachange memoirs in sight. Even the threat of terrorism can only boost a market that relies on our dreams of playing the shepherdess in a quaint cottage. As Alain de Botton puts it in The Art of Travel, what we find exotic abroad may be what we hunger for in vain at home.
