urn:contentItem:5573-8W21-F0J6-J2J8-00000-00Palm oil nepotism adds fuel to disaster1997-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisNEWSOpinionPg. 19Palm oil nepotism adds fuel to disasterBig Picture - IndonesiaGeorge J. Aditjondro - Dr George J. Aditjondro is an Indonesian environmentalist who teaches at the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at the University of Newcastle.

President Soeharto and his family are the most reluctant to make the necessary sacrifices because of their business interests, contends George J. Aditjondro.

Last week, Indonesian President Soeharto called for the International Monetary Fund to patch Indonesia's financial system, after the rupiah suffered a dramatic 20 per cent plunge over the previous two weeks. But who will fight the forest fires which have been raging since July in many of the main islands of Indonesia, at the same time as the rupiah's exchange rate began its dramatic plunge?

In this case, it is not only a problem of extinguishing the fire. It is a matter of halting the alarming rate of tropical deforestation in Indonesia. In this case, nobody has more power than Soeharto himself. Yet the President, two of his brothers, five of his children and one grandchild are the most reluctant to make the necessary sacrifices, due to their logging operations, oil palm plantations, a mega-project to convert 200,000 hectares of peat swamp in central Kalimantan into rice fields for transmigrants from overcrowded Java, coal mines, pulp and paper production, as well as palm oil marketing.

Many of those companies were targeted when the Forestry Department issued a list of 176 companies, which had fires burning on their properties. On October 3, licences were revoked for 29 of those companies, since they still had not managed to extinguish those fires. Several companies in Kalimantan owned by Soeharto's charities and managed by the timber tycoon Bob Hasan were among those 29. So were companies from the Raja Garuda Mas (RGM) Group in Sumatra, owned by another businessman, Sukanto Tanoto, who also has joint ventures with Soeharto's children and in-laws.

The initial Forestry Department blacklist of 176 companies indicates the major culprits of tropical deforestation in Indonesia since the New Order began in 1967. Most are plantation companies, mostly rubber and oil palm, followed by timber estates to grow the raw material for pulp and paper factories. And a smaller group of land-clearing contractors for transmigration schemes exposed tens of thousands of hectares of peat soil, which sprang into flames in the heat of fires from neighbouring forests and timber plantations.

Oil palm illustrates the power of Indonesia's First Family, since three generations of the Soeharto family are involved in this lucrative business. It began in the mid-1980s, through a joint venture of the Salim and Sinar Mas Groups, which involved Soeharto's eldest son, Sigit Harjojudanto, his youngest brother Tommy Soeharto and Soeharto's cousin, Sudwikatmono.

In the late 1980s, Salim and Sinar Mas split their joint venture and all its properties, and each group developed its own crude palm oil (CPO) division. The Soeharto family interests were still represented in both groups, especially in Salim Group, where apart from Sudwikatmono, two Soeharto siblings, Sigit Harjojudanto and Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, are major shareholders in the group's Bank Central Asia (BCA).

In the meantime, Sinar Mas developed its edible oil division in co-operation with Soeharto's second son, Bambang Trihatmojo, who is also a minor shareholder in a plantation company of another conglomerate close to the First Family, the Bakrie Brothers.

Bambang's younger sister, Siti Hediyati Hariyadi, also got involved in this business. She and her brother-in-law, Hashim Djojohadikusumo, formed a joint venture with a Sino-Malaysian tycoon, Robert Kuok, to open a 44,000-hectare oil palm plantation in South Sumatra in 1994.

This is when the third generation came into the picture. A company owned by Sigit's eldest son, Ari Harjo Wibowo, received a quota from the Indonesian Logistics Board (Bulog) to market 70,000 tonnes of crude palm oil a month more than the crude palm oil marketing quota for the Salim and Sinar Mas Groups. Ari, however, not only wanted to sell other companies' palm oil but wanted to manage his own plantations. So the Transmigration Minister gave Ari a contract to develop an 80,000 ha oil palm plantation in East Kalimantan, using transmigrants as "captive labour".

Capital was no problem for Ari, as grand-uncle Sudwikatmono would lend to him from Salim's cement factory. And with his First Family connections in March 1996 Ari signed a memorandum of understanding with a Pakistani trading corporation to export $US1.24 billion ($1.7 billion) worth of crude palm oil to Pakistan.

This oil palm (family) story and the cancerous growth of plantations, timber estates, and mining operations in primary forest land indicate the extent of nepotism of the Soeharto family and its effect on Indonesia's economy and ecology.

This nepotism has often been justified by playing on Indonesian nationalism, by making the people proud of becoming "the largest plywood producer", then "the largest paper and pulp producer", and eventually "the largest oil palm producer" in the world. But this misplaced nationalistic pride has contributed to Indonesia's growing public and private debt, as well as to the displacement of tens of thousands of local farmers and tribal communities by the logging concessions, timber estates and other major mega-projects. And it may also boomerang on the Australian economy and on Australian consumers.

The most immediate effect of the forest fires will be on edible oils. As mentioned, most companies on the Forestry Department blacklist are plantations which were growing, or at least were supposed to grow, oil palm. Most of them were members of the Sinar Mas and the Salim Groups, or were involved in marketing arrangements with Sinar Mas, Salim, or Ari Haryo Wibowo's Arha Group.

This will affect Goodman Fielder's edible oil supply from Indonesia. This largest Australian food producer has two 50:50 joint ventures with Sinar Mas: one in cooking oil and the other in snack foods, a total investment of $47 million. The first produces the well-known brands of cooking oil and margarine, Meadow Lea and Mother's Choice.

The Indonesian forest fires will force Goodman Fielder - and so ordinary Australian consumers - to pay more for their palm oil- derived margarine, cooking oil, and soap. As an an oil palm marketing manager told the Business Times in Singapore last week, the haze will shrink yields more after the natural three-month cyclical fall in production. Oil palm needs sunlight and rain. The prolonged drought caused by El Nino and the lack of sunlight due to the smog will take their toll on yields in six months time, so he predicted.

The second commodity in Australia which may be hit is paper. The second-largest group of forest fire culprits are the timber estates which were developed to produce the raw material for Indonesia's growing paper and pulp factories. The two largest paper and pulp producers in Indonesia are Raja Garuda Mas and Sinar Mas, which have listed their paper and pulp offshoots in Singapore and New York, respectively, as APRIL (Asia Pacific Resources International) and APP (Asia Pulp & Paper).

With their domestic and overseas mills, these two Indonesian paper tigers have assaulted the Australian market. An Amcor subsidiary, Dalton Fine Paper, is the agent for APP copy paper, while a 42 per cent subsidiary of Amcor, Spicer Paper, is a full range agent for APP. In the coming months, however, the Indonesian assault on the 15,000 tonne paper market in Australia may be slowed by the losses from the burned plantations in Indonesia, which have to be cleaned and planted with new seedlings.

In the meantime, the ordinary people in Indonesia still have to suffer from the increasing prices due to the plunging rupiah, the foul air left behind by the forest fires, the landslides from the denuded hillsides in the coming monsoon rains, the increasing prices of cooking oil and margarine, and the increasing prices of paper - a major problem for the tens of millions of Indonesian school kids.

urn:contentItem:4JFH-5X00-TX4S-M38X-00000-00By George, what a year2006-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisAPg. 4By George, what a yearThe Canberra Times

IT'S NOT every day you get to see celebrities canoodling in public, but then George Clooney and Matt Damon aren't like most celebrities. Midway through an interview at New York's Regency Hotel, Clooney jumps out of his chair when friend and Syriana co-star Damon stops by for a visit.

After apologising to a reporter for the interruption, Clooney gives Damon a bear hug and then playfully grabs his backside.

"Matt's hot," Clooney teases.

"Look at him. He deserves to be People Magazine's Sexiest Man Alive!"

Later, Damon admits that he's happy to see his friend back on his feet and feeling chipper, as the past year has been rather tough for Clooney. During the process of mourning the deaths of a number of family members, including his aunt Rosemary, his grandfather and brother-in-law, the weight the actor put on to play one of the protagonists of Syriana - 16kg in 30 days - had a rather adverse effect on him.

"It changed him," Damon says.

"It made me think of that movie Super Size Me, where the guy gets depressed as he gains weight. George was like that, like I've never seen him before. He's normally so fun and vibrant and playing pranks, [but] he wasn't like that at all."

Clooney might have had a tough year personally but, professionally, the 44-year-old is surely at his creative peak. After finishing up Syriana , Clooney co-wrote, directed and co-starred in Good Night and Good Luck. The latter, which has received almost universal critical praise around the world, focuses on the 1950s battle between Communist-obsessed senator Joe McCarthy and US TV newsman Edward R. Murrow (played by David Straithairn). The films garnered multiple Oscar nominations, with Clooney collecting the Best Supporting Actor prize for Syriana.

Far from basking in the limelight personally, he directs attention towards the films themselves.

"The actual victory for me is that Good Night and Good Luck is making money, and it's getting good reviews. We're really excited about the fact that it's sparked discussion among TV news reporters.

"So I feel like it's been a great thing. The same with Syriana.

[That's] being reviewed very well, and we're having a really enjoyable time with the idea that debates will be raised by the film. To me, that's the real issue."

Clooney has never transformed himself for a role quite as rigorously as he did for Syriana. Initially, he had signed on as executive producer, knowing that his name would help director Stephen Gaghan raise money for the film. But when the actor signed on to play CIA man Bob Barnes dropped out, Clooney stepped in, growing a beard and putting on weight for a character whose decision to question the misplacement of a missile leads to a tragic set of circumstances. It's a dark film, perhaps Clooney's most sinister to date, but then as Matt Damon has already attested, the actor was himself in a dark place during much of its filming.

"A lot of bad things were going on in my life," Clooney says of the multiple bereavements he'd endured, "so it wasn't hard to be depressed. I thought that it was a good space to stay in while I was doing the film because this character feels like he's been deserted and betrayed all along.

I wanted to concentrate on that, and I wanted to blend into the wallpaper and not really be noticed at all."

Epic in scope, Syriana probes the ways in which oil companies, law firms, the US government and the Middle Eastern regimes conspire to control the flow of oil throughout the world. A rap against American consumer culture, the film overflows with characters as varied as Islamic fundamentalists, Justice Department investigators and energy consultants.

While a critical hit in the US, it has nevertheless received some flak for being anti-American.

But the actor insists the film is wholly patriotic. "I don't think that it's an anti-American movie at all," he says. "I think that it's as pro- American as you can get. The whole idea of America was based on dissent and bringing questions to the forefront.

It's your right and your duty to ask questions. I know we're not providing answers, but we're certainly asking a lot of questions."

Something he has been doing rather a lot of late.

But then, perhaps it's in the blood.

The son of an army helicopter pilot- turned journalist and a former beauty queen, George Clooney was born in Lexington, Kentucky, in 1961. His initial ambitions were to follow in his father's footsteps by becoming a TV anchorman. Nick Clooney's life was largely defined by principles, and he often walked out on jobs over ethical issues. As a result, George and his younger sister, Ada, were forced to move home and change schools frequently.

Settling in Ohio, he briefly attended college before bailing.

Having ditched the idea of becoming a TV anchorman on the grounds that "I wasn't going to be any good at it", he thought about becoming a professional baseball player. Instead, he settled on temporary jobs: harvesting tobacco, selling insurance and even ladies' shoes.

Ultimately, spurred on perhaps by his movie star good looks, he fell into acting, though he was anything but an overnight sensation. A decade of daytime soap operas and unsuccessful pilots would follow, Clooney increasingly convinced that a big break would never come his way.

But then, at 33, fate finally smiled upon him when he landed the part of Dr Ross on the TV medical drama ER. His character may have personified TV cliche - he was the hunky doc who saved children's lives while bedding a good chunk of the nursing staff - but he played it with a nice line in arched eyebrow irony. The show was an instant hit.

At last, Clooney was a star.

But when he quit the show in 1996 for the big screen, many considered it a reckless move. Countless TV stars before him - Tom Selleck, Ted Danson, David Caruso - had attempted similar, only to fail and then crawl back to the small screen, cap in hand.

But Clooney triumphantly bucked the trend, becoming not just hot property but also an increasingly versatile performer. With fluff like 1996's One Fine Day alongside Michelle Pfeiffer, he proved himself adept at gloopy rom com in the manner of a latter-day Cary Grant.

But it was the box office success of 1998's Out of Sight that cemented his leading man credentials, with him as a bank robber trailed by US marshall Jennifer Lopez - the two leads smouldering like cigarettes in a forest fire. He was now a genuine A-lister, but would go on to subvert his standing in Hollywood with a vigour that would give him more in common with, say, Ken Loach than Tom Hanks.

Forming a production company (Section Eight) with the latter's director, Steven Soderbergh, Clooney went on to co-create thoughtful, almost belligerently uncommercial films more concerned with art than artifice. For every mainstream film he appeared in - from the sublime (O Brother, Where Art Thou?) to the ridiculous (Intolerable Cruelty) - he would do deep- thinking sci-fi (Solaris), sea-faring calamity (The Perfect Storm) and twitchy drama (Confessions of a Dangerous Mind, his impressively low-key directorial debut).

And while the majority of his peers seek bigger bucks for each new project, Clooney seems little taken with financial gain. For Syriana, he took an actor's fee of just US$250,000, ($339,000) about 1 per cent of the going rate for male superstars. And for Good Night and Good Luck, he accepted symbolic pay only: a dollar for writing the script, and another for directing it.

The whole film cost a paltry US$7million ($9.5million), and it has already earned three times as much in the US alone, but Clooney will see none of it. He signed his rights away in order to get the film distributed.

"I've actually had a very good career once I realised it wasn't about trying to make money," he said recently.

And in this pursuit of such leftfield, often polemical, projects, he has effectively become Michael Moore with added sex appeal. If Good Night and Good Luck prompted some of America's more hysterical critics to label him borderline anti-American, then Syriana's main thrust - which documents the gradual transformation of two innocent Pakistani boys into suicide bombers - has prompted accusations of him as a terrorist sympathiser. Nonsense, he says.

"Obviously I'm not condoning or defending horrible, heinous acts, but there is a reason these things happen."

And it is his motivation to find out why. "So yes, I'm a liberal," he concludes, "but I'm sick of it being a bad word."

During the filming of Syriana, Clooney suffered an injury that, it was reported, pushed him to the brink of suicide. In one scene, he was tied to a chair for the purposes of interrogation, but he fell backwards, banging his head on the concrete floor. Crippling headaches started soon afterwards, and the man who first came to prominence pretending to be a doctor in a TV show, immediately decided he'd had aneurysm and was about to die. In fact, he explains, "I tore my dura [the membrane that surrounds the brain]."

He underwent two medical procedures over the course of the following year, in which three small bones were removed from his neck and back.

Very gradually, the headaches began to ease, life slowly returning to normal. The reports of suicidal contemplation, he explains, were exaggerated to say the least.

"I had done [a TV interview] and [the host] said, 'How bad did the pain get?' I said, 'Well, you couldn't live like that', and the next thing I heard was I wanted to kill myself. That's not exactly what I was saying."

And so his fanbase breathes a sigh of relief, greeting the news that 2006 is shaping up to be his most industrious year yet. Within months of his latest two releases, there will be a further three Steven Soderbergh's The Good German, in which he plays a reporter on the trail of his former mistress (played by Cate Blanchett); Michael Clayton, about a defence attorney facing retirement; and another Coen Brothers comedy, Burn after Reading."It'll be the end of my trilogy of idiots that I've played for the Coens," he says, grinning. "Finally, I'll be back with the idiots."

And, it must be said, he does play them rather well. Perhaps because, in real life, the man is anything but.

urn:contentItem:49N1-62Y0-01S8-G4H4-00000-00<published>1991-12-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>THE BIRTH OF APOCALYPSE - PALM BEACH SEASON HOTS UP</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>COOPER J</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">COURIER LIVING TUES PG 20 PUNCHING herself free, utterly shocked, she slapped his face as hard as she co uld. For a moment the streaked gargoyle face looked as though it had turned to stone. Then he was gone. Sobbing, Perdita collapsed on the bed. There was a knock at the door. frantically hopeful, Perdita looked up. But it was Red _ not Luke _ who stood in the doorway, grinning from ear to ear. ""Hi Godiva," he said softly. Perdita told him about the row with Luke. ""I'm not hanging round here any more. You'd better come with me. The press are going to annihilate you, Lady Godiva." ""But I can't walk out on Ricky and Dancer," wailed Perdita. Red crossed the room and kissed her properly for the first time. ""I'll come with you," said Perdita helplessly. From that moment Perdita was a leaf, ripped untimely and whipped hither and thither by the whirlwind. Back in Rutshire on an October afternoon, Ricky, having worked young ponies all day, by way of light relief was hacking through the Eldercombe woods. He passed Daisy's cottage. Ricky thought for a moment how comforting it would be to go in for tea, crumpets and fruitcake. But he didn't want to inflict his black gloom on poor Daisy who was unhappy enough over Perdita's defection. A dark blue Ferrari roared up the driveway scattering an appropriately red carpet of beech leaves and screeched to a halt.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>It was Bas and Rupert, on their way home from hunting. Both were in tearing spirits. Ricky thought for the hundredth time how well being happily married suited Rupert. Rupert grinned. ""Tell it not in Gath, but I have actually been faithful to Tag for a whole year, and I want to get home to her, but first we've got a proposition to make to you. We are definitely going to revive the Westchester in America next year. We want you to act as consultant. " Ricky went very still; the color drained from his face. ""The plan," added Rupert, ""Is to transmit it in America, the UK, Europe, certainly Australia and Argentina and God knows where else in October. You'll captain the English team." If Chessie really loved him, reasoned Ricky, she'd have come back by now. On the other hand he could go to ten, he could win the Gold Cup and now there was the possibility to win the Westchester. It was worth a try. Since Perdita has run off with Red she had rung her mother twice, the first time from Kenya to say she was deliriously happy. But when Daisy reproached her gently for hurting Luke and walking out on Apocalypse, Perdita had hung up and cut off all lines of communication. Few people realised how much Luke suffered. Because he was unhappy, he didn't see why the rest of the world should suffer. And it was difficult to forget Perdita when every newspaper carried pictures of her and Red entwined and laughing. It was the last tournament of the Palm Beach season with six crack teams playing each other over 10 days for a huge silver cup topped with rearing horses. On the hottest Sunday of the year, the Alderton flyers were only leading the O'Briens by two goals at half time. Perdita had had a lousy first half, not helped by a ball on her arm in the second chukka which was now agony. As she cantered back to the little tent where the other Flyers were taking a break she saw them standing in a huddle outside looking deadly serious. Then she heard Bart say, ""Well for Chrissake, don't tell Perdita." ""Tell Perdita what?" the dust made her hoarse. Red who'd gone very pale, was lighting a Black Sobraine with a trembling hand. ""Bobby Ferraro hit Luke with a ball yesterday," he said. ""Broke his hand in three places. they've just operated and taken out 50 chips of bone." Four days later Perdita disobeyed everyone's advice and flew up to see Luke. She didn't tell Red. ""Darling Luke have you forgiven me?" Then she dropped her parcels all over the floor for sitting on Luke's bed was an incredibly attractive girl. Her second almost more agonising impression was how desperately ill Luke looked. ""Who's she?" she asked Luke, nodding rudely in the girl's direction. ""Margie Bridgwater." Luke made no attempt at explanation. ""For the first time I can suddenly see how like Red you are," she said. ""I've seen pictures," Margie put her hand over his. ""I like my men more rugged." ""Red's the handsomest man in the world," exploded Perdita. ""Not as good looking as Rupert Campbell-Black," said Margie. ""Wow! He came to see Luke this morning." Margie followed her out into the passage. Forcing her hand furiously into her trousers pocket, Perdita pulled out a bottle. ""Give it to Luke," she said. ""Morphine for when the pain gets too bad." ""He needed that in August when you shoved off with Red," said Margie. As she went back into the room to grip Luke's other hand as the doctor started to undo his bandages, he said through gritted teeth, ""I've just realised who Perdita's father is. RED'S temper was blazing like a forest fire when Perdita got home. All in all Perdita wasn't in a ve ry chipper mood to go to a barbecue that evening, particularly when Red was immediately collared by a comely, female feature writer in a groin-level, blue suede skirt from Vanity Fair. One more drink, thought Perdita, and I'll separate them. ""Hi aren't you Perdita Macleod?" said a soft voice. ""Who are you?" she asked aggressively. ""Simpson Hastings." If Perdita had been less drunk she would have heard warning bells. Simpson Hastings seemed to know a lot about polo and particularly about her. ""They say you're a phenomenon beyond genius. Where did the skill come from? D'your parents ride?" ""My mother's never been on a horse in her life." ""And Hamish?" ""Hamish isn't my father." Suddenly an Ancient Mariner compulsion to tell all swept over her. Back in Rutshire, Daisy had had a long day finishing off a painting. She felt quite faint with happiness. Ricky had become such a friend recently and her painting was going wonderfully. She clambered over Ricky's padlocked gate, raced up the path and then gave a gasp. Outside the door was a glamorous, if slightly grubby-looking blonde. With her was a man carrying a camera. ""Mrs Macleod?" said the girl. ""We're from The Scorpion. Can we have a word?" ""What about?" stammered Daisy. ""Perdita told Simpson Hastings in Florida yesterday that she'd no idea who her father was." Nothing prepared Daisy for the horror of The Scorpion next day. ""Gang, bang, thank you, Mum," said huge front-page headlines. ""Poor old Daisy," said Bas Baddingham to Rupert. ""Didn't we used to know a creep called Cosgrave? Used to give wild parties in the sixties?". Jackie Cosgrave hadn't prospered in later life. Women were no longer so keen to buy his paintings, nor girl students to sleep with him. Picking up The Scorpion, Jackie looked long and hard at Daisy. Picking up the telephone he rang The Scorpion news desk. ""I'll tell you who Perdita's father is, but it's going to cost you."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF ARTIST'S urn:contentItem:4P8H-NF40-TXN5-S0CR-00000-00My husband's ghost1999-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisNEWSFeaturesPg. 9My husband's ghostMY MOST MEMORABLE HOLIDAYSusan Johnson

On holiday in Corsica, in the early summer of 1993, I felt air moving freely in my chest again. It was as if my eyes had suddenly remembered how to see.

I was a freshly divorced woman, momentarily released from pain, and everything I was struck me as flawlessly clear and fantastically colored: rocks, mountains, ocean, sky reared up in front of me, fiercer than dream.

My divorce had been finalised weeks before and, although I had been physically separated from my former husband for some time, it was not until the moment that I stepped on to Corsican soil that I suddenly felt a rushing sense of release. A sadness was loosed from me, some inner catch sprung open.

I remember the anticipatory spasm of joy I felt as the plane from Paris swooped dangerously low over Corsican mountains. Calvi's Sainte-Catherine airport is famous for its death-defying approach, where planes and mountains engage in a complex choreography. All around me French women and men laughed nervously, some bracing their feet against the floor in unconscious preparation for collision.

From the air Corsica was a delirious smear of colors and shapes, but the looming mountains held no terrors for me personally. The minute I stepped from the plane and the rich smell of summer and fruit and pine trees rushed to meet me, I felt loose in my skin again.

Simone, my friend from Paris, was waiting in the terminal, brown from the sun, all untied like a girl. She had clearly abandoned the slick of the city and as she led me outside to her old white battered Volkswagen with the hood folded back, I noticed that her feet in her sandals were cracked and weathered. She had paint stains on her fingers.

Before I got into the car I took off my cotton sweatshirt: it was at least 10 degrees hotter than Paris, The car didi not go fast, or rather Simone didn't, and as we moved along the road I tipped my head back and looked up at the soaring shape of Monte Grosso and the perfection of the Mediterranean sky. The smell of burning was in my nostrils.

Simone was wearing a hat turned up at the brim and I thought only her driving betrayed her age: she sat too close to the steering wheel, clutching it tightly as if it had alternative powers she had not yet divined.

"This is a place of violence," she announced in English, "violent people, violent beauty. Regard." She indicated towards distant mountains where smoke was rising from a forest fire. "Every summer, Corsica burns."

The rushing air in my face smelt sweet to me, of oranges and fire and escape. As the car began to climb towards the mountains, we passed olive groves, the sensuous green of orange and lemon orchards and I could see, high above us, walled towns built into cliffs. Here and there a church spire was visible.

I knew that Simone was lucky enough to own property in Corsica only because her late husband was a Corsican. Complicated laws usually prevent anyone but Corsicans from owning or inheriting property (with the glaring exception of fabulously wealthy Italians with names likes Agnelli whose house regularly get bombed by Corsican patriots).

Nothing Simone had told me had prepared me for the beauty of her house. Monte Grosso sat immediately behind it, looming, beautifully preposterous, a cartoon mountain, while the house itself was made of several different cubes, joined together by passages and walkways, ponds, rock gardens, and each section of it had a distinct and memorable character.

On top of one cube was a roof garden, which led to all the other roofs, with 360-degree views. The mountain behind, the sea far, far away, the folds and sweeps of the valley below. In the garden around the house(s) were fig trees, grapes, cherries, insects, birds: the very air was quick with life.

Inside the house, Simone's drawings and collages hung from the walls. And everywhere there were mementoes of her late husband: an old raincoat, still hanging behind the door; all his jazz records; his books. He had spent a complicated working life writing parliamentary reports for the French Parliament, but I immediately knew what Simone meant when she said he was a peasant at heart.

In Corsica they had lived a life of the body: swimming, climbing the enormous mountain in both summer and winter, skiing in the depths of winter when all the tourists had gone home. They had no children and he had died skiing on a different mountain back in France, falling down dead in the snow.

Together, and separately, they had many friends and invited guests to the house in Corsica every summer. The summer of 1993 was no exception and we ate every meal on the roof, hearing the peal of church bells from the town perched on top of the next hill. We ate hard local cheese, sharp on the tongue, and drank Corsican wine tasting of fruit and earth.

In my memory, every day after that was perfection. We travelled to little town and ate cabrettu a l'Istrettu, a kind of Corsican tomato stew with kid; we swam in water so clear and blue I could not have imagined it (I saw my toes and the depths of the sea far beneath them); we travelled to the tops of mountains and swam in freshwater streams so cold and transparent they might have come from freshly melted ice.

We drank diabolo menthes in tacky tourist cafes in Calvi and in Ajaccio, Napoleon's birthplace, and took long walks along white sandy beaches. I had never seen a place of such extremes: near-desert, alpine forests, beaches, ancient towns, lush farmland.

I fell heedlessly into the arms of one of Simon's other guests, a man I had known before in Paris. Because he was Italian-American he could understand the local dialogue, a mix of French and Italian, and together we walked through browned summer fields, speaking of our lives as if they belonged to other people.

At the time I wasn't really living anywhere. I had left Australia for Paris in 1989, inadvertently ending up in Hong Kong, married to a British lawyer. The marriage was brief and incendiary: I had gone back to Paris, back to Sydney for a while, returned to Paris.

I couldn't decide where my life was. On those long walks with the Italian-American, I talked about wanting to live in Australia, about wanting to live in France, about wanting someone else to decide my life for me.

I willed myself to fall in love with my companion but his lips were too thin and every time I kissed him it felt wrong. My lost husband was physically gone from me but my lips remembered the imprint of his mouth.

Still, my husband's ghost was not at that summer's feast. Corsica had somehow banished him and when I dozed in the after noon heat I felt only weightless. And once, when my new lover and I were walking in an abandoned village, an old man insisted on accompanying us, telling stories of an Australian sea captain who fell in love with a local woman and never went home again.

I wondered if Simone would let me live in her house forever, until I grew old like some wizened monk in a cave. I would clean out the fireplaces in winter, prevent fires and learn to talk like a peasant.

But when everyone went home it was just here an dme and she sadly informed me of plans for a mineral-water plant right next door. "I intend to fight," she said, looking out over the hills, a tanned general preparing for war.

I thought of the film Manon des Sources and the metaphorical implications of water. "A factory," Simone said, "a factory of water, Can you imagine?"

I looked out over the trees below to the land next door where the mineral spring had been found. There was a kind of buzz in the air, wasps perhaps, busy French bees. I could not imagine.

The next morning it was my turn to leave. As I climbed the stairs to the plane I actually had tears in my eyes, whether from joy or grief I could not tell. I was 34 year old, but I felt my life was beginning.

Even now, all these years later, whenever I think of Corsica I fell free again.

Susan Johnson is a novelist and editor of Saturday Extra.

urn:contentItem:7V1B-29R0-YB64-408J-00000-00LESSONS FROM THE ASHES2009-02-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisSUPPLEMENTPg. 3LESSONS FROM THE ASHESA NEW DAWN - THE INQUIRYMICHAEL BACHELARD and MELISSA FYFE

Were the fires a freakish combination of unavoidable circumstnaces, or could their impact have been less lethal? Michael Bachelard and Melissa Fyfe explain the key questions facing the royal commission.

1 BURNING OFF

Royal Commissioner Bernard Teague does not know what heâ€™s in for. His inquiry must make sense of one of the most complex and ideological debates that has dogged Victoria since the 1939 Black Friday fires: how to reduce the â€œfuelâ€ in the bush to prevent or mitigate fires.

The last person to try to make sense of it was the current Emergency Services Commissioner, Bruce Esplin.

After the Alpine fires of 2002-03, Esplin found that between 1988 and 1998, the governmentâ€™s fuel reduction burning - lowintensity fires that remove flammable bush build-up such as bark and leaf litter - had dropped off. He concluded that fuel reduction, or prescribed burning, was not a panacea, would not necessarily prevent bushfires and its effectiveness was almost impossible to measure. But more should and could be done.

The rub was this: his inquiry found that governments faced real constraints. Expert advice concluded that the government had a window of only about 10 to 12 days each year in which to safely conduct fuel reduction burns. It needs to be cool enough, with benign winds, the correct humidity and conducted when the forest is not too wet and not too dry.

If any of these factors goes awry, houses and other assets can be burnt, fires can race out of control across private land and national parks can be accidentally crisped.

Some say that on those days of opportunity a massive effort should be put into starting safe, low-intensity fires across the state. Since Esplinâ€™s report, the Department of Sustainability and Environment has boosted its resources for burning opportunities, but this is where another major constraint comes in: human health. The smoke generated by fuel reduction burning affects peopleâ€™s respiratory health, particularly asthma sufferers. Another constraint is the environment itself. Despite claims last week that green groups were â€œecoterrorists waging a jihadâ€ on prescribed burning, many environmentalists have no problem with it. Many of the stateâ€™s grasslands, woodlands and forest systems have evolved with fire and need it to regenerate. The problem for conservationists is the frequency of prescribed burning. And this is a complex matter. As Esplinâ€™s inquiry pointed out, some forest types need five-year cycles of burning, others 12, others 30.

Despite the constraints, after Esplinâ€™s report, the government ramped up its burning regime.â€

We want to do more, thereâ€™s no doubt,â€ the departmentâ€™s chief fire officer, Ewan Waller, told The Sunday Age. â€œBut we have to have the weather with us.â€ Last financial year, the department burnt 153,578 hectares of land.

This was the largest amount burnt in Victoria since 1993 and 18 per cent more than the departmentâ€™s annual target of 130,000 hectares. While it is comforting to look at figures, Esplin noted the numbers of hectares was not necessarily a good measure; it was how strategic the burning program was in protecting community assets.

In the Royal Commission, it is likely Justice Teague will need to find answers to these key questions: did the Government do enough burning off in the fire-destroyed areas and would that have made any difference to the number of people killed?

Waller said he was yet to look at the fuel reduction maps but some areas burnt on Black Saturday had been either burnt in previous bush fires, or the target of fuel reduction burns.

Other areas had not been, he said.

2 COMMUNICATION

THE stories emerging from some of the most devastated towns of Marysville, Kinglake and St Andrews are similar - there was precious little warning of the devastating fires.

Victoriaâ€™s emergency communications - from the 000 line, to CFA internal radio and paging services, to emergency notifications on CFA and Department of Sustainability and Environment websites, and then ABC Radio - were inadequate to the task of last weekendâ€™s emergency.

Even those listening avidly to ABC Radio for official risk warnings were often not warned in time.

Bushfire experts also query whether the warnings that did get out were sufficiently detailed and personal enough to engage individuals under threat. A key issue for the Royal Commission will be a close forensic study of warnings and delays.

The problems follow years of procrastination at a state and national level about whether to introduce a telephonebased warning system for individuals. The system could have the potential to contact each of Australiaâ€™s 22 million mobile phones if needed.

Victoriaâ€™s Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin has promised a large state-based trial of SMS warnings to mobile phones within three months.

A senior emergency services source told The Sunday Age that, in the midst of Saturdayâ€™s crisis, people were ringing 000 to report emergencies, but not every call was answered.

Emergency radio channels for internal communications also were stretched. â€œThe operators did a fantastic job, but the pressures were enormous.

The question is whether they had enough channels. It seemed to be asking too much from each operator - they couldnâ€™t cope with the volume of calls coming in from the (fire) trucks.â€ The source said the CFAâ€™s internal paging system was so slow that some messages came through hours after they were sent.

CFA Kilmore fire captain Greg Murphy was less critical of the communications system, saying it was going â€œas well as could be expected with the fire intensityâ€.

Records of CFA warnings issued on the day are no longer available on the website, and DSE was reluctant to give briefings on the subject.

But a Sunday Age analysis of records on the Twitter website (which re-broadcast official CFA warnings within minutes of them going online) shows that warnings for the Kilmore- Kinglake fire were sparse at crucial times.

The first warning of the fire hit the Twitter website at 12.15pm on Saturday, 25 minutes after CFA officers arrived at the scene on a country property outside Kilmore and reported the fire was out of control and growing fast. There were long gaps between warnings during the afternoon as the speed of the fire, at up to 100 km/h, outpaced the CFAâ€™s communications ability.

For long periods, the DSEâ€™s website and fire maps were inaccessible.

Risk and community safety professor John Handmer has launched a research project into the timeliness of warnings.â€

The system definitely got overloaded, and there are a lot of internal issues there,â€ he said.â€

You canâ€™t escape the fact that people need to get notice and warnings.â€

3 STAY OR GO

DR DAVID Packham has spent years spreading the word about bushfires: if you stay and defend your house, your life and your property are more likely to emerge unscathed. But, after last weekâ€™s inferno, Packham, one of the policyâ€™s originators, believes it should be reviewed by the Royal Commission.

Since 2005, the â€œgo early or stay and fightâ€ approach has been official Australian policy.

The impetus came from a 1991 analysis of the deaths in the 1983 Ash Wednesday bushfires.

Australiaâ€™s approach is unique. In the United States, for instance, evacuation from a looming wildfire is the norm and houses are often sacrificed to save lives.

Packham, a bushfire scientist, based his view partly on his own experiences during the Ash Wednesday fires. He and his wife, along with two friends, saved their Upper Beaconsfield house.â€

If it turns out the analysis is that the conclusions of 1983 are wrong, then either it should be scrapped or modified.

The key is the work should be done carefully and extremely honestly,â€ Packham says. He believes â€œstay or goâ€ will be vindicated but â€œundoubtedly things can be refinedâ€.

Previous scientific work showed that whether the house is occupied and defended is the second biggest factor in whether it will survive. The most important factor is the fireâ€™s intensity and, according to Packham, the positioning of houses. Dwellings with trees close to them, on north-facing slopes, made of flammable materials are probably indefensible, no matter how knowledgeable or fire-prepared their occupants are. That message had not necessarily been understood.

Survivors of the fire, as well as Premier John Brumby and the CFA, are also calling for a thorough study as to whether the â€œfight or flightâ€ policy still works in changing climate conditions.

Risk expert Professor John Handmer, from RMIT, said the approach to staying and protecting property from bushfires emerged as early as the 1930s when, in rural communities, it was the best (if not only) option.

A 1940 CSIRO report into the Black Friday fires in 1939 found that most houses burned down from ember attack, not from direct flame contact. Then, through the Hobart fires of 1967 and the Ash Wednesday fires in 1983, studies were made of those who survived, and those who died, and the stay or go policy emerged more strongly.

But the reality of Saturdayâ€™s fire, when well-prepared people were overwhelmed by flames and others only narrowly escaped, now puts a big question over the previous evidence.â€

â€˜If we are heading into warmer, drier conditions, then weâ€™ve got a serious problem,â€ Handmer said.

4 CLIMATE CHANGE

IN THE wake of the tragic fires, Januaryâ€™s heatwave has been almost forgotten, but it is this event - not the record heat on Black Saturday - that climate scientists are most interested in.

The heatwave, they say, is the climate change clue behind why the fires were so ferocious.

Two caveats need to be declared before any discussion of climate change and the events of last weekend. The first is that experts agree that blazes would have been sparked whether people pumped greenhouse gases into the atmosphere or not.

The mix of weather - hot day, huge northerly wind followed by a dry, cool change - was unusual, but has happened many times in Victorian summers. The second is that no climate scientist will say that one event, no matter how extreme, is the manifestation of climate change.

But the royal commission will study the role of climate change in the fires. The question is: did the changing climate make the fires more lethal? One of the stateâ€™s top fire experts, the Country Fire Authorityâ€™s chief officer Russell Rees, believes the answer is that climate change had a big role to play. â€œThat is my belief, 100 per cent.â€ The fires came after 12 years of the stateâ€™s hottest and longest drought, a string of the hottest years on record in the last decade, a 35-day dry spell for Melbourne through January that was equal second-longest in history, one of the most severe heatwaves on record and the hottest day ever recorded in Melbourne and Victoria. Also, places to Melbourneâ€™s north and north-east that were hit by the fire, especially the Marysville area, have had more significant declines in average rainfall than many other parts of the state.

Monash Universityâ€™s Professor Neville Nicholls, who has spent 35 years researching climate, said the scene for Black Saturday was set with the â€œchronic dryingâ€ of the environment due to the 12-year drought. Then came the January heatwave which, in terms of temperatures - with recordbreaking jumps of more than two degrees in places - was so extraordinary Nicholls describes it as â€œmind-bogglingâ€.â€

The really crucial thing linking this to climate change is the three-day heatwave rather than the really hot temperatures on the day of the fires. By then, the situation was already primed . . .â€

I think it is beyond reasonable doubt that global warming and the enhanced greenhouse effect has exacerbated the severity of this tragedy,â€ said Nicholls, who for decades worked at the Bureau of Meteorology as a senior principal research scientist.

On the day before the fires, the bureau did its calculations for one of many predictions it provides, called the Forest Fire Danger Index. This is a calculation based on how dry forests are, air temperature, relative humidity and wind velocity. This calculation then gets converted to the fire danger ratings heard on the radio. Low is up to 5, high is 12-25 and it goes through to extreme, which is 50-plus; Ash Wednesday was 102.

The reason Premier John Brumby told the state that February 7 would have the sort of fire danger to make it â€œthe worst day in Victoriaâ€™s historyâ€ was because areas of the state had values of 150 to 180.

Kilmore, where at least one fire started, had a fire danger index of around 180.

In 2007, a group of fire and climate researchers from CSIRO and the bureau studied what will happen with fires and climate change in south-east Australia. The headline from this analysis is often reported as the usual increases in extreme fire days. But the research also looked at what has happened with fire danger indexes in the past few decades. They found that from 1980-2000 and 2000- 2007, the increase in fire index ratings was around 10 to 40 per cent. They found we could be in a natural cycle of high fire danger made worse by climate change and two new categories of fire risk needed to be created: 75-100 should be called â€œvery extremeâ€ and more than 100 â€œcatastrophicâ€.

The most disturbing thing about the research was that the number of extreme fire danger days being seen now equal or exceed what the climate change models predicted for 2050 - in other words, this is what living with fire in a climate changed world is like, 40 years early.

urn:contentItem:4P84-VBT0-TXN5-R3DY-00000-00Super scene1999-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisTELEVISIONPg. 10Super sceneMiranda Wood, Rob Lowing, David and Sophie Hodges

Cool blondes

From chat room to chart boom? The Internet has put three girls on the superhighway to success, writes MIRANDA WOOD.

BLONDE, beautiful and bound for stardom, the Real Blondes are out to prove they are more than just a trio of pretty faces and platinum tresses.

The three Sydney teenagers, Kristy Peters, 15, Kelly Webb, 16, and Rachelle Medley, 16, discovered they all loved singing after their first meeting in a chat room on the Internet.

Now they are preparing for national stardom with their first single We B Cool.

Written by Kelly's mum Cheryl (who has worked with Girlfriend and John Farnham), the song was released only a year after that fateful Internet meeting.

The youngest member of the group, Kristy, spoke with Super Scene about her new found success.

When and how did it all start?

I was friends with Rachelle and we used to talk over the Internet and when we went into an open chat room we met Kelly. Kelly's mum owned a recording studio and she said why don't you come and play. Eventually we met and sang for her mum and we sang really well together.

Do you see Kelly and Rachelle often?

We talk a lot over the Internet and we write e-mails. That's our main communication source and I try to do it every day. The Internet's just so handy.

How long have you been singing?

I've been singing, dancing and acting my whole life. I go through stages of wanting to be an actress or a singer in a band but it's always been my dream to perform. I used to do amateur musicals and I love doing theatre

What are working on now?

We're recording an album at the moment and we've got about six songs recorded. It's great fun. I've learnt so much about the business and the people. Plus I get heaps of free stuff.

Will you tour?

We might be going on a mini-tour of Perth via Melbourne. We haven't done any big shows yet.

KIDS VIDS

Pippi Longstocking

(G) Voices by Melissa Altro, Catherine O'Hara (Columbia) 74 mins ***

THE songs are woeful but it's hard to resist the straight-out perkiness of this animated musical adventure. The story is based on Astrid Lindgren's famed books about the irrepressible Little Miss Mayhem, 9-year-old Pippi Longstocking. Pippi has grown up at sea, travelling the world with her ship captain dad. When he's washed overboard, Pippi isn't depressed - oh, no, she and her pet monkey decide to wait for dad to wash up in a coastal town. There, Pippi promptly makes friends with the local kids and falls foul of two bumbling crims.

Available to buy for $19.95.

Excess Baggage

(M) Alicia Silverstone, Benicio Del Toro (Columbia) 100 mins

***

SILVERSTONE is rich gal Emily who's devised an audacious plan to catch the attention of her money-obsessed father (Australia's own Jack Thompson). But Emily's plan backfires when her car is stolen by a good-natured thief (Del Toro). Emily doesn't know whether to turn her kidnapper in - or kiss him. A good soundtrack and terrific support from Christopher Walken and Harry Connick Jnr. $24.95.

- ROB LOWING

WATCH THIS SPACE

THE true story of four boys who experimented with homemade rockets in 1957 - the year the Soviet satellite Sputnik blasted into orbit - is coming to the big screen.

Based on the book by Homer Hickam, October Sky follows Homer and friends - Quentin, Roy Lee and O'Dell, who were determined to make a rocket that would soar.

Homer's teacher, Miss Riley, was the only adult who supported and encouraged his dream.

But Homer's efforts seemed doomed as rocket after rocket exploded on the launch pad until one day, the boys discovered the secret to building a successful rocket.

The boys became local celebrities - that was until one of their rockets was suspected of starting a forest fire.

But with Miss Riley at his side, Homer and his friends went on to win the national Science Fair.

In real life, Homer Hickam became a NASA engineer and this is a movie for anyone who believes in the power of dreams.

Super Scene is giving away 20 double passes to see October Sky. For your chance to win, phone 1900 969 435 and give your details. (Lines close midnight today. Legion Telecall max call cost 50¢, more from payphones and mobiles. NSW TC99/0035, ACT TP98/2350.)

- MW

BYTE THIS

ONE of Australia's leading teenage websites, Dolly Online has everything from fashion to the latest music news. The website, developed from the best-selling teenage magazine Dolly, only recently introduced a new look to keep its young audience entertained. Dolly Online, which is aimed at 11- to 17-year-olds, features segments called fashionflash, beautyspot, babewatch, girltalk and more. At fashionflash, you can find out what's cool to wear this summer and how to bargain shop. There are competitions, an astrology love guide and a quiz at funhouse. Catch up with the best buys at beautyspot and what's in and out this season for hair, lips, eyes and skin. You can even submit your own beauty questions for Dolly's Beauty Editor to answer.

- MW

SUPER SCENE ON THE NET

WE still love to receive your wonderful drawings, poems and photographs. We now post them on Super Scene's website. Check it out.

CHANNEL SURFING

Zooventure Marathon

Animal Planet, Saturday, October 16, 2pm to 10pm

WHAT does a porcupine sound like? Which is larger: the pygmy or regular chimpanzee? These are some of the questions you can expect on Zooventure Marathon, an exciting game show for kids.

Taped on location at the world famous San Diego Zoo, Zooventure tests contestants' knowledge of the natural world while taking

them on a wild adventure through the animal kingdom.

Host J D Roth leads contestants aged 11 to 13 through trivia questions, fast-paced matching games and puzzles. And like any zookeeper, contestants are asked to "get down and dirty" by completing physical tasks including putting a nappy on a gorilla, feeding baby birds and kangaroo-hop races.

Animal Planet is the world's first and only channel devoted to people and animals.

REVIEWS

Wipeout 3

Sony PlayStation

Price: $79.95*****

PLAYSTATION'S Wipeout 3 has arrived. It's the follow-up to the coolest game ever - Wipeout 2097.

Like its predecessor, it is an anti-gravity futuristic racing game with intense gameplay.

All the quality has been retained in this version - the amazing graphics, the wicked tunes and the style of racing. But there are also some new and exciting features to keep the pulse racing.

The game features eight amazing tracks around a high-tech Japanese metropolis.

All the tracks are smooth and wide, which means even faster racing. You are propelled at exhilarating speeds, taking the tightest corners with ease. Most of the tracks also have alternative routes.

Thanks to improvements in computer game technology over the past two years, Wipeout 3 offers vastly improved handling and is the fastest in the series.

Analogue controls make it harder at first but over time you can learn to overtake, corner and jump better.

You have 12 weapons at your disposal, but this game is really all about the racing. You can even go into the pits for a full overhaul.

There are several modes to choose from including tournament, single race, a time trial and catch-the-exhaust. You can also play split screen racing against a friend.

The soundtrack is great with DJ Sasha, The Propellerheads, Orbital, Underworld and Paul Van Dyk featuring. They have made Wipeout 3 even more consuming than 2097.

- DAVID and SOPHIE HODGES

The Olympic Games: Sydney 2000 Special Edition

(Dorling Kindersley $39.95)

*****

TO celebrate the millennium Games coming to Sydney, a special edition book has been produced to bring to life the drama and spirit of the modern Olympics. This guide covers more than a century of competition with an in-depth look at every summer and winter Olympic Games and a listing of all medal winners from those Olympics. It features an 18-page section on the Sydney Games, including information on the venues and the athletes. If you want to be up to date on Olympic Games facts and figures before next year, then this collectors' item should be on your shopping list.

Today I Feel Silly & Other Moods That Make My Day

By Jamie Lee Curtis, Illustrated by Laura Cornell (HarperCollins Publishers Australia $22.95)****

EVERYBODY knows what it is like to have moods. We can swing from joyful to angry, excited to sad all in just one day. This book, by US actor Jamie Lee Curtis, explores the world of emotions. With colourful illustrations by Laura Cornell, the book assures readers that whatever they're feeling inside, it's OK. MW

He is the author of Traders, Guns & Money: Knowns and unknowns in the dazzling world of derivatives (FT Prentice Hall, 2006).

After a year of turmoil when capitalism was shaken, two essays explain what's changed and what happens now

Essay: Mike Hanley

We need a more evolved form of finance than one carried by sentiment and rampant self-interest

ACCEPT, FOR argument's sake, that the global financial crisis is an epoch-shifting event. Don't compare it to the events of the past decade or so: the Asian financial crisis, the bursting of the dotcom bubble or 9/11 - all of which are fading from economic consciousness much faster than anticipated. Accept, instead, that this is a huge dislocation, an earthquake that has cracked the landscape apart so that the freeway of progress must take a different route.

Accept that the financial markets will be utterly transformed, that trust between counterparties needs to be rebuilt using new and yet-to-be-invented structures and that the way we do business in the future will be different to that of the past.

If that's the case, what ideas will we be using to build the new world, and who are the most articulate proponents for change?

Over the past three months, column inches devoted to analysis of what happened and where to now would reach the moon and back. But through all this, several strands of thought have emerged as having strong explanatory power and providing ideas for leaders concerned with both risk management and regulation. A key premise is that capital markets are characterised by two interconnected facts. On the one hand, cutting-edge finance is disproportionately populated by intelligent people with powerful tools - they are good at growing their business; on the other hand, they are just people.

RATIONAL SELF-INTEREST

In 2007 finance took up four times the proportion of the US economy than it did in the 1960s (up from 10 per cent to 40 per cent), but the sector doesn't actually produce anything.

In The Ascent of Money, a timely exposition of the rise - and now crash - of finance, Harvard economic historian Niall Ferguson writes: "In 2006, the measured economic output of the entire world was around US$47 trillion. The total market capitalisation of the world's stockmarkets was $51 trillion - 10 per cent larger. The total value of domestic and international bonds was $68 trillion, 50 per cent larger. The amount of derivatives outstanding was $473 trillion, more than 10 times larger. Planet Finance is beginning to dwarf Planet Earth."

Dr Paul Woolley, a former fund manager and IMF economist, believes it is the "agency problem", or the inside knowledge of financial professionals, that has caused such capital misallocation. It's the disproportionate grab on growth by financial intermediaries. These intermediaries include corporate executives who, according to Standard & Poor's in the US, claimed stock-option-based remuneration in 2002 equivalent to 20 per cent of reported profits. They also include investment bankers, fund managers, trading commissions, fees and the rest. According to Woolley, by the time the money gets to your super account, returns that should have gone to you and other shareholders have shrunk to less than 1 per cent. It is no surprise then that politicians are looking at ways to reign in this excess.

All is not lost for the free-marketeers, however. Bill Emmott, former editor of The Economist, believes the swing towards state intervention has been overblown, if only because the cost of intervening in the financial markets has been so high that governments won't be able to extend themselves any further.

IRRATIONAL SELF-INTEREST

The growth of Planet Finance might be less of a worry if its rise had corresponded with a smooth upward growth curve. It would be less worrisome if more people making decisions about price and value had actually led to better calculation of risk, capital allocation and a tempering of speculative excesses - if, in other words, markets had been efficient.

But 2008 provided clear evidence that this is not the case. Billionaire George Soros puts much of it down to reflexivity - the idea that markets react to what has happened in the markets themselves, rather than to any underlying analysis of value.

Joseph Stiglitz won the Nobel Prize in part for showing that investment practitioners have little incentive to actually do any original research themselves, relying on the wisdom - or madness - of others. It's known as momentum investing. Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, a psychologist and an economist respectively, won the Nobel Prize for showing that people have a lopsided and perverse approach to risk-taking: we are risk averse for positive prospects, but risk-seeking for negative ones.

Planet Finance, in other words, is populated by human beings. We base decisions on facts we remember or data that is close to hand, rather than information that might actually have a bearing on the issue. We look around for confirmation of our biases, accept confirming data and reject ideas that speak against our prejudices. As humans we are subject to a host of fallacies, overconfidence issues and logical missteps. This grates against the base assumption driving capital markets: that the aggregate decisions of a large number of people are a more or less accurate indicator of value.

"Orthodox economic models are not wrong, as such," says economist Pete Lunn, author of Basic Instinct: Human nature and the new economics, "but rather sloppy, biased approximations of how our economy works. They present a cartoon characterisation of economic life, greatly exaggerating one side of our nature at the expense of others."

REAR VISION

Nobody could argue that a financial crisis was unforeseeable. Many did foresee it: Nouriel Roubini of New York University had been sounding the alarm for years before events proved him correct - he has now found world fame as he shuttles between global economic summit and commentary gigs. It is the precise circumstances, the chain of events, and the implications and severity of those events - the all-important details - that are the modern-day black swans, as expressed in Nassim Taleb's book The Black Swan: The impact of the highly improbable.

The tools that we use to predict the future - from weather models to revenue forecasts to capital markets trading systems - are inadequate because they are unable to take into account what their creators never imagined. But the unimaginable happens far more often than we give it credit for.

Our propensity to rely on yesterday as a predictor for tomorrow is built into just about every form of analysis western business uses every day. Corporate quarterly profit forecasts, banks' daily value-at-risk models, insurers' earthquake and hurricane models, strategic plans and budgets, performance and remuneration systems - each of these uses techniques developed to extrapolate the future from the past. But what if the future is much less predictable? This is Taleb's Ludic fallacy, or "the misuse of games to model real-life situations".

Still, statistically, the best predictor of tomorrow's weather is today's. It may be that the only tool we have is the rear-view mirror, and all we can do is invent innovative ways of using it.

Reinventing the species

Financial historian Niall Ferguson says that financial history is an evolutionary one, governed by the laws of Darwin. The financial world shares a number of features with the natural world, including "genes" that preserve organisational memory; spontaneous mutation; competition for resources within species; natural selection through the market allocation of capital and human resources; scope for the creation of new species, and for extinction.

Ferguson predicts the death of the global banking dinosaurs because economies of scale and scope are not always the driving force in financial history. "More often, the real drivers are the process of 'speciation' - whereby entirely new types of firm are created - and the equally recurrent process of creative destruction, whereby weaker firms die out."

Essay: Satyajit Das

Deleveraging is the only means of restoring the body financial to full health, but it will take time

In the classic tale, The Arabian Nights, the beautiful princess Scheherazade buys one day of life at a time by recounting fantastic fables that enchant the King who has condemned her to death. Investors and traders are currently telling each other fairytales to buy one day at a time and stave off the inevitable.

The drama and tumult of recent events are not symptoms of the disease but the cure. The "disease" is the excessive debt and leverage in the financial system, especially in the US, the UK, Spain and Australia. In the lyrics of the Bruce Springsteen song - many have "debts that no honest man could pay".

The "cure" is the reduction of the level of debt known as the great deleveraging". In 1931, US Treasury Secretary Andrew Mellon explained the process to President Herbert Hoover: "Liquidate labour, liquidate stocks, liquidate the farmers, liquidate real estate. Purge the rottenness out of the system. High costs of living and high living will come down ... enterprising people will pick up the wrecks from less competent people."

There is widespread acknowledgement that an extraordinary level of debt and leverage precipitated the current financial crisis. However, there is limited understanding of how the deleveraging purge works. Leverage is the tool that amplifies returns; it is also the means of accelerating losses.

Deleveraging requires willing buyers with capital and the liquid cash to purchase the assets. Selling inevitably results in more selling as lower prices trigger additional margin calls and further reduction in debt levels. Ultimately, prices of risky assets must adjust to market clearing levels as the system reduces debt. The initial phase of the cure is the reduction in debt within the financial system. The overall loss to the financial institutions (net of re-capitalisation via new equity issues) is $400 to $600 billion and may well go higher. This requires reduction in financial sector balance sheets through reduction in lending and asset sales.

The second phase of the cure is the higher cost and lower availability of debt to the real economy. This forces corporations to reduce leverage by selling assets, reducing investment and raising equity. This also forces consumers to reduce debt by selling assets (where available) and reducing consumption.

Feedback loops mean reduction in investment and consump-tion lowers economic activity, placing stresses on corporations and individuals, setting off defaults that trigger losses for the financial system, which further reduces lending capacity.

RACE TO THE BOTTOM

Deleveraging continues through these repetitions until overall levels of debt reach a sustainable level determined by lower asset prices and cash flows available to service the debt. The process of destruction echoes WB Yeats' words: "All changed, changed utterly: A terrible beauty is born."

Within the financial sector, deleveraging is well advanced. In the real economy it is in its early stages.

Fairytales in financial markets focus on the "superhuman" abilities of regulators and governments to avoid the deleveraging under way. Central banks and governments have taken progressively more aggressive actions to try to influence events. Central banks have aggressively supplied liquidity to the money markets, accepting an increasing range of collateral types in return. Governments and central banks have also bailed out a number of financial institutions using a variety of strategies to limit contagion. Most recently they have resorted to injecting equity into selected banks and providing extensive guarantees supporting bank borrowings.

Banks are being forced to write-off bad loans without delay. Banks' capital needs are being addressed by forced mergers and restructuring, new equity issues and (in the absence of other options) nationalisation or liquidation.

Central bank guarantees of all major borrowings and other transactions to reduce solvency risk for banks are designed to enable normal transactions between parties in the financial market to resume. The necessary co-ordinated global action appears at last to be under way.

Lower interest rates and increased government spending have also been used to try to reduce the effects of the financial crisis on economic activity in the "real" economy. The initiatives are sensible short-term measures to stabilise markets. In the longer run, they transfer the problem onto the government and the taxpayer balance sheet.

CAPITAL IDEA

It remains to be seen whether these global initiatives achieve the required re-capitalisation of banks, improve the normal supply of credit to sound borrowers and reduce fears of default allowing normal activity between institutions to resume. The key issues remain the availability of capital and liquidity. The perceived abundance of liquidity was, in reality, merely an illusion created by high levels of debt and leverage. As the system deleverages, it is becoming clear how little capital there really was.

The risk of a severe dislocation in global capital flows remains a real risk in the present environment. As China's Premier Wen Jiabao observed, the US financial crisis may affect the whole world. As Wen noted: "If anything goes wrong in the US financial sector, we are anxious about the safety and security of Chinese capital..." All creditors have much to lose if the deleveraging process becomes disorderly.

Ultimately, "all the king's horses and king's men" cannot prevent the deleveraging of the financial system under way. The extent of deleveraging is substantial and likely to take time. In recent years, money was cheap and other assets were expensive. As each of the global economy's credit creation engines breaks down and systemic leverage reduces, money becomes scarce and more expensive, triggering substantial adjustments in asset prices in a reversal of the process.

David Roche, principal of the London consulting firm Independent Strategy, estimates that $4 to $5 of debt is now required to generate $1 of economic growth. As credit creation slows and debt levels fall, the sustainable level of global economic growth may fall as well.

At best, the government and central bank actions can smooth the transition and reduce the disruption to economic activity in the transition to a lower debt world. The risk is that well-intentioned steps prevent the required adjustments from taking place, delay recognition of problems and discourage action that must be taken by financial institutions, corporations and consumers.

Like a giant forest fire, the deleveraging process cannot be extinguished. Thoughtful actions can create firebreaks that limit preventable damage to the economy and the international financial system until the fire burns itself out.

The Arabian Nights had a happy ending. The King, after 1,001 nights of enchantment and three sons, pardons the beautiful Princess Scheherazade, who becomes his queen. Despite the fairytales that investors are putting their faith in at the moment, the deleveraging at the heart of the current financial crisis may not have such a happy ending. B
