urn:contentItem:4FVS-NTV0-0045-5115-00000-00<published>2005-04-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>It's crunch time FEATURE STORY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>The Canberra Times</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HE PLACE where Sister Dorothy Stang was assassinated is marked by a simple wooden cross pushed into the mud of a track that runs deep through the jungle. The cross is covered in the wax from melted candles. A few plastic flowers are scattered on the ground, along with a young sapling in a plastic grow-bag. Other than that, there is just the constant sound of birds and the chatter of insects on an afternoon so damp and humid that one's clothes stick to the skin like cling-film. Deep inside the rainforest the trees are so huge, the soaring canopy so dense, that there is an echo that makes noises ring out. Vicente Paulo Suera, a small farmer who scrapes by growing rice and manioc on a tiny plot nearby, heard gunshots on the morning of February 12 when the Catholic nun was shot to death by gunmen allegedly hired by a local rancher. The rancher, Vitalmiro Moura, has just surrendered to police, claiming he is innocent. She was left face down in the mud, her Bible at her side. "We have lost a great defender. No one else will help us," said Suera, leaning against an upright timber in his mosquito-infested shack. The Amazon rainforest is an extraordinary and other-worldly place. Vast, dense and hugely rich in plant and animal life, there is nowhere else like it on earth. When you stand inside it, beneath vast trees that chase up into the sky, you can feel it pulsating -vigorous, alive, untamed.</p><p>It accounts for 40percent of the world's remaining rainforest and the Amazon basin contains perhaps a fifth of its fresh water. It is so rich in flora that an average hectare contains more than 100 different species. Critically, it absorbs much of the planet's greenhouse gases and produces 20percent of its oxygen.And yet it is under threat like never before. Since 1970, perhaps 20percent of the Amazon rainforest has been lost to logging and development. Campaigners say that 6500ha are being lost every day. The unceasing and illegal devastation of the Amazon rainforest of Brazil is best seen from the air. Flying west from the regional capital, Belem, the forest stretches ahead like a vast, black-green carpet that races to the horizon. Yet when you look straight down you cannot miss the strips and patches of bare brown earth where the logging has eaten into the jungle. Around 80percent of the logging is believed to be illegal. On the ground, when you actually visit these slash-and-burn sites in what was once pristine forest, fire-scarred rocks and debris of the burned timber stand forlorn and alone in the middle of what are now grassy paddocks grazed by white cattle. It is like being at the scene of some terrible arson in which nothing and no one survived. Stang, 73, a lifelong activist, was apparently murdered as a result of the latest land dispute in which she had become willingly involved in this remote part of north-eastern Brazil. Her murder, like that of Chico Mendes in 1988, was quickly seized on by environmentalists around the world as a sign of the bitter land battles still being fought here. And yet her death six weeks ago represents a great deal more than that. Her murder did not take place in a vacuum. Economic and social forces are battling over the future of the Amazonian rainforest and the left-leaning government of Brazil is struggling to balance a desire for "sustainable development" with domestic and international demands for economic growth. Given the role of the Amazon as a provider of oxygen, it is no exaggeration to say the outcome of that tussle will effect all our futures. We all have a stake in the battle that cost Stang her life. Originally from Ohio, the nun spent the past 30 years on the front line. Having joined her order after leaving school, she arrived in the Amazon in the mid-1970s. She worked as an educator but after witnessing what was happening around her, her focus turned to environmental and lands-rights issues. In Anapu, 30 hours by dirt road from Belem, many people turned to her for help. The small town, all but unreachable at the height of the rains when the unpaved Transamazonian Highway becomes rutted and churned, is one of the flash points in the battle over the forest. In Anapu, as elsewhere across the state of Para, loggers and ranchers are pitched in an often deadly fight against small farmers and environmentalists. The deforestation and the development of ranches all around Anapu show which side is winning. Stang's case was far from unique: since 1985, 1400 people have been murdered in land disputes -half of them in Para. Death threats have become a way of life. "They apparently have lists of those they want to kill," said Sister Mary Gillespie, another nun from the order. Francisco de Assis dos Santos Souza knows all too well about threats. The 36-year-old, known as Chiquinho, is president of the local branch of the Rural Workers Union, which worked with Stang to stop the illegal occupation of land set aside for the poor. Before the latest murder, Chiquinho had received plenty of threats. Two days after his friend was shot, he received a letter that read, "Dorothy has been killed -you are next". When Chiquinho spoke to The Independent at the union's simple headquarters a thick-set armed policeman sat next to him. He has apparently been instructed never to leave his side. "When you are against the financial interests you are a target," he said, explaining that the small farmers had no way to resist the intimidation of the land thieves, or grileiros from the Portuguese word for cricket. But here the crickets carry guns or arrive at the homes of peasants shaking handfuls of ammunition. "The small ones cannot say no. If they do they eat bullets." Luiz Inacio 'Lula' da Silva, Brazil's President, hoped to put an end to such violence. In a country where the poorest 20percent own just 2percent of the wealth, Lula campaigned during the 2002 election as a champion of environmental protection and promised to provide land for 400,000 landless peasants. Despite the devastating recession he inherited, he was also critical of taking international loans from groups such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF). So far, Lula has failed to match rhetoric with deeds. Rather, say analysts, he has had to confront the political reality of Brazil's recession and the pressure for growth. As a result, instead of acting convincingly to protect the rainforest, he at least tacitly encouraged the development of it. In the days after the killing, Lula announced new logging restrictions and the establishment of 4 million hectares of new reserve. But nothing has altered the pressure to maintain economic growth and to maintain the jobs that the ranchers and others provide. Though he was opposed to an IMF loan, Lula inherited a decision made by his predecessor to take the $A39 billion which came with a series of stringent austerity demands and a requirement for Brazil to control the ratio between public debt and GDP, as well as to pay off its huge international debts. Last year Brazil's economy grew by 5.2percent. The Amazon is inextricably linked with Brazil's economy. Logging may only account for a fraction of Brazil's export earnings, but the rainforest is also a source of gold and minerals and has provided much of the land for the recent expansion in cattle production and agriculture. Agriculture, including the rapid increase in soy bean production, is now a $A194 billion business and accounts for more than 40percent of exports. Meanwhile, the country last year overtook the US as the world's biggest producer of beef. Annual overseas sales of beef earns Brazil $A3.2 billion. A recent paper by the council on Hemispheric Affairs, the independent, inter-American think-tank, said: "The issue [of Brazil's environmental and economic situation] are interdependent and unfortunately, one's success is the other's loss." Around 15percent of Brazil's total external debt is owed to the IMF. When The Independent contacted the fund, a spokesman scoffed at the suggestion that fiscal requirements attached to its loan, such as the need for Brazil to produce a primary surplus of 4percent, in any way contributed to the struggle over land use in the rainforest. William Murray, a spokesman, said such a suggestion was "outrageous" and "harebrained". He said Brazil's economy was widely diversified and the country's "economic growth [was] not significantly linked to logging". "Deforestation is not something we support. It never has been." Others see the situation differently. Carlos Rittl, a Brazilian-based Greenpeace campaigner, said there were historically two important debts faced by the Lula administration. "One is the international debt and the other is the social debt," he said. "Both are very important but it seems the international one is more urgent. This causes all the problems we face in the Amazon. Policies to pay external debts promote the development of agriculture and cattle ranching, which are quickly advancing into the heart of the Amazon. This is increasing forest destruction and causing social disruption." Stang wanted it both ways. The white-haired woman believed it was possible to use the forest's resources without destroying it. She was an outspoken champion of sustainable development. She promoted reforestation and worked to educate local people about the rainforest and its value. She tried to make them feel they had a stake in its survival. She also tried by every means she could to obtain land for small farmers and to help them and their families make a living. "I don't know what she was not involved with," said her brother, David Stang, who recently travelled to Anapu from Colorado to visit his sister's grave. "I'm very proud. I never dreamed she did so much." In theory at least, Dorothy Stang's views had the support of the Brazilian government. Everton Vargas, the country's foreign minister with responsibility for the environment, said his government's policy was based on sustainable development -a seemingly magical mixture that would allow economic growth without leading to deforestation."Promoting preservation when at the same time promoting economic growth and better social conditions for the people, you will imagine, is a very complex and difficult challenge," he said. "There are no simple responses for this problem and for the challenges we have in that region." In regard to international pressure for growth, Vargas said that foreign debt had "historically been an important pressure on Brazilian fiscal and economic policy". He also said that US subsidies to products such as cotton were a factor on the development of land for agriculture. Another problem is the difficulty of policing so huge an area and the corruption within the police. -The Independent</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P84-VK40-TXN5-R213-00000-00Let us prey1999-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisSUNDAY LIFEPg. 30Let us preyPhillip Game

Several thousand birds of prey converge on Hawk Mountain - yet trying to spot one is an act of faith, says Phillip Game.

Within an hour or so of the steel towns of eastern Pennsylvania (remember Billy Joel's Allentown?) is Hawk Mountain -

a forest-clad limestone ridge in the central Appalachian Mountains that offers a superb vantage point for North America's autumnal migration of birds of prey.

Reach for the atlas and you'll be struck by the regularity of these ancient folded ranges, ribbed across the map like a rumpled carpet. North-westerly winds and the ridge topography generate the updrafts that transport hawks, eagles and falcons southwards over the ranges.

Alarmed at the decimation here of hawks by the merciless hunters of the day, in 1934 Rosalie Edge set up the world's first refuge for migratory birds. The aims of the non-profit Sanctuary Association have since widened to encompass the conservation of the central Appalachian environment. A private initiative has been harnessed to the public good - in the land where the pursuit of profit has been elevated to an art form.

Typically some 20,000 raptors of 14 species are tallied during the four-month autumn migration season, peaking about September/October. The reserve has also become a crossroads of naturalists: more than 80,000 people visit each year including many biologists, authors and artists of note.

Hawk Mountain Sanctuary's 963 hectacres straddle the Kittatinny Ridge, within three kilometres of Bill Bryson's never-ending nemesis, the Appalachian Trail. Panoramic views unfold from commanding overlooks, sharp-edged ledges of limestone - some looking on to densely forested valleys, others out over a very Germanic patchwork of fields, forests and streams. This is PennsylvaniaDutch country, and "Dutch" is a corruption of the original "Deutsch" or German.

Habitat gardens and a bird-watching hide near the visitor centre have been meticulously planned and planted out. A soaring eagle frozen in bronze honours charter members of the Sanctuary Association, whose membership has reached 8500.

At South Lookout, eager young interns (graduate trainees) in khaki ranger garb greet visitors who have made the short stroll uphill from the main gate. An engraved plaque set into a cairn depicts the silhouettes of species most likely to be seen soaring above. Amid the trees, high-rise timber "restrooms" complete with panoramic balcony views offer a wry amusement to the foreign visitor unused to such earnest attention to detail.

Across the valley below spreads the River of Rocks, a glacial boulder field reached by a rough, rocky train down from the ridge.

From South Lookout, the track forks out along the ridge line, one arm looping around the former quarry workings. On a busy autumn day, there may be close to 100 people at North Lookout, all armed with binoculars and telephoto lenses.

Some way further on, Sunset Overlook is reached after a boulder scramble. The peaceful landscape unfolding below recalls immediately those lush, populated valleys of western Europe's heartland: manicured tongues of forest, rectangular fields in variegated shades of emerald green, stitched into an agrarian quilt with the bare brown of fresh-ploughed land.

There are forest-rimmed river banks, distant ridges fading into the haze. Compact settlements - houses are no more than dots yet the church steeples remain distinct - appear at crossroads wherever the ridges part to offer a passage.

But the grandest views of all unfold from the 500 metre-high North Lookout, an escarpment commanding the valleys to the west, the forested Appalachian ridge stretching north east then the sweeping, shallow valleys to the south east, fecund farmlands unfolding a cornucopia of the fruits of the earth.

In spring there are relatively few birds of prey to be seen but city dwellers can revel in the fresh apple-green forest foliage. On the ground the grass is as soft as an overgrown lawn; moss covers many rocks. A fortunate few may spy the pink lady slipper, a delicate and endangered pitcher plant.

It takes precise timing to catch June's full-bloom display of native rhododendron and mountain laurel, the Pennsylvania state flower. Blooms or not, the deciduous forests are dazzlingly green - a dense mosaic of oak, maple, hemlock, beech and rhododendron. Small red berries adorn the bushes. Chipmunks scamper up and down tree trunks. Fallen leaves form a soft, dense floor. American robins, common flickers and blue jays all dart by.

Down in the valleys below, roadsides are fringed with the spheroidal heads of clover, en masse a pinkish purple haze, the day lily, a garden escapee distinguished by its tawny red colouring, and sweet peas, profuse in purple, indigo and white.

From the Sunset Overlook, golden strips of corn are now interleaved with the wedding cake layers of green below. Turkey vultures soar overhead, an extraordinary ugly bird at close quarters yet graceful in equal measure in its own element.

August, the beginning of the migration season, is traditionally heralded by the flight of the first bald eagle, that avian icon of America. By September, Hawk Mountain welcomes the arrival of ospreys and thousands of broad-winged hawks.

By returning in October to admire the autumn foliage as well as the migration flights, we may reasonably expect to witness the greatest variety of species, including sharp-shinned and Cooper's hawks. Autumn colours are speckled but lightly across the hillsides: golden birch, rose-red maple. The leaves are mostly burnt orange, just waiting to fall and the effect is almost like the aftermath of a low-intensity bushfire in Australia.

Now the Sanctuary is crowded on weekends; arm-banded volunteers with walkie-talkies marshall traffic along the narrow main road. Forty or more eager bird-watchers crowd the boulders at North Lookout but today the changeable, gusty weather must have deflected the south-bound bird formations.

On a clear, crisp November Monday, I hope to experience the ridge-top in an agreeable solitude, before winter really sets in. No chance. It's cold enough to see your breath or to regret sitting still too long on a bare boulder, yet the car park is almost full and the trails are spotted with people; school groups and seniors are out in force.

Local newspapers are reporting an excellent start to the flight season after six years of mysterious no-shows. Once more I take to the trail to join 20-odd enthusiasts at North Lookout. November's chill winds should draw red-tailed hawks and golden eagles, yet today, despite calls of "three birds ... four ... above number two ... just above the hump" from hopeful voices, there never seems to be more than a solitary black dot visible with the naked eye. Nearest thing to a bird in sight is the plaster decoy on its pole like some pagan totem invoking the eagle spirit.

I'll pick my way instead to the Sunset Overlook, there to spend 10 minutes entranced by the gentle tapping of a black and white, red-crested woodpecker, which eventually thwarts me by retreating to utter instead a high-pitched chirp.

A young woman approaches cautiously: she is trying not to alarm the songbird but no, she can't confirm the bird's identity. For her this is just "such a neat place to hang out". The hacking cough of a ruddy-faced older man spoils our shared reverie. Both newcomers agree the autumn colours are not the best this year, probably because of the long, dry summer. Just a few specks of gold or rust remain to dispel the forest fire image. Where are these famous raptors? Better to have enjoyed a brief intimacy with a more humble songbird than squint in vain for these elusive monarchs of the skies.

HOMEX - Melbourne - Half Yearly Report 3. EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES PPL 189 - Papuan Basin, PNG (14.141% Interest) During the half year, additional processing was undertaken on the 13 kilometre Pit Pit seismic line over the Barikewa gas field. The line ties the Barikewa-1 and 2 wells. A reassessment of other structural leads in the licence was completed and preparations were begun for a geological survey over the north-western part of Barikewa and the Kopi lead in southern most PPL 189. PPL 190 - Papuan Basin, PNG (10.535% Interest) During the half year, the landowner dispute over ownership of the Healy-1 drilling site remained unresolved. The Minister, at the request of the Joint Venture, suspended the licence conditions for a minimum of twelve months. Consequently, the Parker Rig 125, which was to drill Healy-1 was demobilised and an alternative rig will be used, possibly around mid year 1999. PPL 193 - Papuan Basin, PNG (7.5% Interest) In October 1998, Cue announced that it would earn a 7.5% interest in PPL 193 Papua New Guinea and would participate in the drilling of the Kimu-1 and Koko-1 wells. Subject to necessary PNG Government approvals, Cue is obtaining a 3.75% interest from Oil Search Limited and a 3.75% interest from Gedd Inc by paying 15% of the costs of drilling the Kimu-1 and Koko-1 wells up to a total Cue share of US$1.651 million.</p><p>Any drilling costs above a gross cost of US$11,006,667 for the two wells will be paid by Cue at its earned equity level of 7.5%. The Kimu-1 well spudded on 21st November 1998. Subsequent to the end of this half year Kimu-1 encountered a 32 metre gas column in the Alene sandstone. Drill Stem Test (DST) 1 was conducted over the interval 1620-1642 metres in the Alene sandstone using open hole straddle packers. The well flowed gas at a rate of 7.79mmscfg/d through a 0.5 inch choke with a well head flowing pressure of 1205psia. The well flowed with a draw-down of only 2.7 psi showing a highly productive sand with an interpreted permeability of approximately 8,000md. There was no pressure depletion as a result of the test with the initial pressure agreeing with the final shut-in pressure (2316.4psia). Samples taken during the course of the test will be analysed for compositional information. The results of the DST indicated that the Alene sandstone is a highly prolific gas producer at the Kimu location. Based on the results of the DST the Alene sandstone has the potential to produce at rates well above 50 mmscfg/d from an optimised well bore. Due to the small hole diameter in the Kimu well over the gas zone, which limits the ability to effectively produce gas, the well was plugged and abandoned. A series of pressure date points (SFT's) and sidewall cores were collected over the open hole interval. The pressure data indicated that the Kimu-1 well had penetrated a 32 metre gas saturated Alene interval with an interpreted gas/water contact coincident with the shale break at the base of the Alene sand at 1649 mKB. Updip potential remains at the Kimu location. Samples taken from the deeper intervals confirmed that the Toro, Hedinia and Iagifu sandstones were water saturated, however, one sample from the top of the Hedinia Sandstone at 1873.5 metres recovered formation water with an oil film. The wireline logging and DST program in the Kimu well has confirmed the well as a new gas field discovery in the Alene sandstone. Kimu-1 tested a prospect in the northern Omati Trough within the foreland basin of Papua New Guinea. The gas saturated Alene sandstone and the fluorescence noted in the Hedinia and Iagifu reservoirs while drilling and during sampling after the well reached total depth has confirmed the Omati Trough area as an active petroleum system. Kimu-1 is the first of a two well program in PPL193, Koko-1 will be drilled immediately following Kimu-1 and will test a large old structure on the leading edge of the Komewu Fault that bounds the southern margin of the Omati Trough. Koko-1 is located substantially updip and 28 kilometres west of Kimu-1. Subsequent to the end of the half year, Koko-1 was drilled to a total depth of 1,363 metres. Natural gas was recovered by wireline sampling from the Upper Hedinia Sandstone and natural gas and 200 cc of heavy oil were recovered from the Lower Imburu Sandstone. The well has been plugged and abandoned as a sub-commercial oil and gas discovery. The oil and gas accumulations defined in Koko-1 and the Kimu-1 gas discovery, demonstrate that an active and significant hydrocarbon charge is present in the Foreland of Papua New Guinea, which further upgrades the prospectivity of the licence and the eastern Foreland area as a whole. Additional studies will be required to fully understand the results of the Kimu-1 well and Koko-1 drilling program and the impact on hydrocarbon potential in this lightly explored area. PPL 194 - Papuan Basin, PNG (100% Interest) In November 1998, the Minister granted Toro Oil Pty Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Cue Energy Resources No Liability, Petroleum Prospecting Licence PPL 194 in the Papua New Guinea highlands. PPL 194 covers 6,200 square kilometres and is situated to the north east of the Paua and Moran oil fields in the central fold belt. Tanjung Jabung PSC - South Sumatra Basin, Indonesia (76% Interest) The Tanjung Jabung Production Sharing Contract is nearing the end of Contract year 2 (15 May 1999). The contract requires the expenditure of US$15.2 million on seismic and drilling in the initial three year period. Despite being content with its 42.2885% holding, during the half year, Cue involuntarily increased its not effective interest in the PSC from 42.2885% to 76% by virtue of a default by Wirabuana Petrolindo Ltd. At the end of the half year, the planned initial seismic survey had not been undertaken due to access being denied by the Department of Forestry and Plantation, to acquire seismic over the two most promising prospects which lie within the Berbak National Park. The Park occupies the most prospective portion of the contract area. The existence of the National Park was not disclosed at the time the Production Sharing Contract area was offered and was not known at the time of the award to the Joint Venture. The Berbak National Park is the first wet land area in Indonesia designated as a Wildlife Reserve and is bound by the Convention on Wetlands and on the Protection of Weiland Birds and other Migrating Birds. The National Park is home to some three hundred species of permanent and migrating birds as well as river mouth crocodiles, tapirs, rhinoceros and several species of monkeys. Within the National Park an integrated swamp development project is being funded by the World Bank and a forest fire control project has attracted international funding. The custodian of the National Park, the Department of Forestry and Plantation, has stated categorically that it will not grant a permit for any exploration (or exploitation activities within the National Park areas (see copy of translated letter attached). Cue is examining various options for its interest in the Production Sharing Contract, including the possibility of withdrawing from the Tanjung Jabung Joint Venture, in order to concentrate the Company's energy and resources on other areas that have more potential to increase shareholder value. Sampang PSC-Madura Strait, East Java, Indonesia (15% Interest) During the half year, a 564km in-fill grid of new seismic data was acquired in the contract area. Processing of the new 1998 seismic data and reprocessing of the existing seismic data continued during the half year. A biostratigraphic review of wells in the Sampang PSC area was completed and a geological field survey was conducted on Madura Island and onshore East Java. The survey was designed to examine selected rock outcrops and to sample oil and gas seeps to gather information that could impact on the prospectivity of the offshore Sampang block. EP 363 Carnarvon Basin - Western Australia (17.65% Interest) In July 1998, Apache Energy exercised an option to acquire an additional 25% interest in the permit. Apache will acquire its additional equity by paying 37% of the costs for the acquisition and processing of 3D marine seismic to a cap of AUD2 million. Apache also assumed operatorship of the permit as of 1st September 1998. As a result of the exercise of the option Cue's interest reduced from 25% to 17.65%. The Joint venture is considering the acquisition of non proprietary 3D seismic data over a significant portion of the permit.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1999</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3W02-5X20-0048-T23H-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1456"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1999 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5565-VN41-F0J6-J45S-00000-00RIDING THE EAST EUROPE ROLLERCOASTER1994-12-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisWEEKEND REVIEWPg. 4RIDING THE EAST EUROPE ROLLERCOASTERTONY FEATHERSTONE

In their rush to embrace Asia many investors are ignoring the sharemarkets of Eastern Europe. As TONY FEATHERSTONE reports, this could be a costly oversight.

GO EAST young man, Eastern Europe that is.

With the roar of the Asian tigers beginning to slowly fade, this emerging market is letting off a scream so loud it has foreign investors flocking in droves.

However, if Eastern Europe is one of the world's few remaining investment frontiers, its cries of massive investment returns have, for the most part, fallen on deaf ears here.

Even local fund managers specialising in emerging markets have given it a tiny portfolio weighting, while most investors are more comfortable with Korea than the Czech Republic.

This may soon change, with bourses in Warsaw, Prague and Bratislava, having gone through gruelling corrections this year, rewarding investors with hefty returns.

For punters keen on Eastern Europe, it appears the markets have bottomed. But caution must still be exercised. Bourses there are young and volatile, the quality of investment information is generally poor, insider trading is still rife and currency risks major.

That's not to say sophisticated investors should overlook Eastern Europe, with smart operators finding ways to get solid exposure while minimising risk. "In Eastern Europe it's like wildflowers coming up after a forest fire," says Tom Presby - in Australia for the international representatives meeting for Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu hosted recently by chief executive Ian Blair.

As the head of Deloitte and Touche Eastern Europe SA, Presby, having watched the downfall of communism, knows better than most the pitfalls and possibilities.

Investors at the Warsaw Stock Exchange earned around 2,000 per cent in 1993 and while some economies are slowing, most argue the boom on Eastern European bourses is far from over, despite being weaker this year.

"It's not too late to make big opportunities or big mistakes there," says Presby. "Both are still available in abundance."

But it's the volatility that concerns most. The Czech sharemarket, for instance, fell from a high of 1,002 points in May to around 560 points in November. The fast-moving Polish bourse hit 20,760 in March but is now languishing around 7,150, while the Hungarian exchange has jumped from 667 points in May to about 1,550 now.

Even debt-laden Russia has jumped from 100 points in December 1993 to around 1,000 in November. "The potential for big profits is clearly there,"says Presby.

"But it's not for the faint-hearted. And it's certainly not for mum and dad investors."

Indeed, a vice-president at Bankers Trust Australia, Mark Burgess, says small investors should avoid Eastern European markets - or at least only place a small asset weighting there - in preference of Asian and Latin American economies.

"The thing investors often forget," says Burgess, "is that while Eastern Europe is an emerging market it's not like South-East Asia where the markets continue to grow.

"The region is going through a major readjustment process and so growth is going to be much more volatile."

Burgess says the bourses may also be held back by an oversupply of privatisations as Eastern European Government rush to sell off their"silverware".

Certainly, research supplied by GT Management Australia shows the private sector's share of gross domestic product in Eastern Europe has soared since 1989.

In the Czech Republic and Russia, private involvement rocketed from below 10 per cent to more than 60 per cent, while Hungary and Poland have also roughly doubled in four years.

GT director Andrew Hutchings says cheap labour and infrastructure are behind much of this growth.

Indeed, average gross hourly wages range from US63c in Russia to $US2.35 in Slovenia, while cement at $US40 per tonne in Central Europe compares with$US162 in Western Europe.

GT Australia describes itself as an emerging economy specialist but has only 2 per cent of its emerging markets portfolio in Eastern Europe although this may rise to 5 per cent within a year.

"There is a possibility for large speculative gains but there a number of risks in Eastern Europe that investors should not discount," Hutchings says. "It is really only for speculators."

For those prepared to lose the lot in search of astronomical gains, the question is then whether you should should invest directly on an Eastern Europe bourse, buy shares in a company with a heavy focus on the region or go through a managed fund.

Deloitte's Tom Presby says punters should have an investment horizon of three to five years due to volatility.

He breaks the area down into three regions: the fast movers including Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic which have attracted most investment; the slow movers like Romania, Bulgaria and the former Yugoslavia; and the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), which includes Russia.

But in many of the economies it's not what you know but who you know, he explains. "These companies often have information that investors are simply not privy to. You really should not even consider investing directly in an Eastern European company."

There are pitfalls, he says, in investing in Western companies doing business there.

Presby says investors should, for the most part, avoid companies involved in joint ventures there due to the high proportion that fail.

"Many of these arrangements don't work because you have differing levels of expectations between the companies and different practices," Presby says, adding that Western companies are no longer legally obliged to form joint ventures.

"You should only invest in a company that has its own people there calling the shots."

The Eastern European expert also says investors must consider carefully any purchases in formerly State- owned enterprises. Other commentators believe these organisations are "genetically" defective because of outdated business practices and vague accounting methods still deeply embedded in the culture. At the same time, implicit and explicit subsidies "which are invisible to the naked eye" may distort the organisation's true performance.

Another trap, Presby says, is investing in large ventures with long-run loss forecasts.

"You have to be careful of anything big over there," he says. "The difficulty of doing business is geometrically related to size. If something is twice as big in Central Europe, particularly Russia, it will usually be four times harder. And companies with big loss forecasts usually realise them. I have seen companies come in and agree to lose money as a matter of good faith. You really don't need to invest in a company with big future losses on its books."

It all gets down to having good people "on the ground" with a solid understanding of how Eastern European business is evolving, Presby says.

"Success in this part of the world is directly related to your knowledge of the area."

So much so, that the only viable route for most investors appears to be managed funds, where experienced investment professionals do the legwork.

The problem is that there are no funds in Australia with a specific Eastern European bias, although many local investment houses have exposure through their emerging markets or European funds. There are, however, overseas funds that invest solely in Eastern Europe.

It's understood some players such as Morgan Stanley, First Boston, Credit Suisse, Baring Securities and Deutsche Bank are setting up Eastern European funds.

Some Austrian banks - due to their close ties to the region - have had funds in place for three years, most notably the GiroCredit Bank, Creditanstalt Bank and Bank Austria. *

urn:contentItem:4P85-19V0-TXN5-R23J-00000-00BURNING ISSUES OF LOGS AND DROUGHT1994-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 14BURNING ISSUES OF LOGS AND DROUGHTBOB BEALE, LEIGH DAYTON and DAVID JENKINS

Huge wildfires are not uncommon in Indonesia's vast forests: indeed, the largest forest fire in recorded history burnt an enormous area of the nation's most productive timber province, East Kalimantan, during the disastrous 1982-83 drought.

The total area of forest destroyed was 33,000 square kilometres - equal in area to the whole of The Netherlands, and almost 20 times as extensive as the Ash Wednesday bushfires in south-eastern Australia around the same time.

As in Australia, however, human activity has greatly added to the burdens of Indonesia's natural ecosystems, on top of the extremes of climatic cycles that subject the region to periodic droughts.

The forests of South-East Asia are taking a beating, and the most recent projections suggest the next two decades will see further losses of forest cover, and consequent soil erosion, river siltation, land degradation and threats to water supplies

and food production are easy to predict.

Indonesia's islands still boast extensive tropical rainforests - about 10 per cent of those left in the world - but the present deforestation rate has been second only to that in Brazil.

A recent International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources/World Conservation Union (IUCN) assessment noted that Indonesia's original forest cover had been "considerably reduced, and much of the remaining forest has been seriously disturbed by logging and shifting agriculture".

Exact figures are hard to acquire, but Indonesia's forests are thought to have been reduced to 57 per cent of their original cover by the late 1980s.

Its Forestry Department blames "slash-and-burn" farmers clearing land for 99 per cent of fires, but many environmentalists say some of the most damaging blazes have been lit by illegal loggers attempting to cover their tracks.

The deforestation rate in Indonesia has climbed in the past two decades. From 1976 to 1980, it is estimated that the national deforestation rate was about 5,500 square kilometres a year.

Between 1981 and 1985, it climbed to 6,000 a year. More recently, rates of 7,000 square kilometres have been reported, and there are fears the rate may have gone as high 12,000 a year.

Fire is wreaking such devastation because more than just rainforest is burning, says Mr Phil Cheney, a forester with the CSIRO Bush Fire Unit in Canberra. Much of East Kalimantan, for instance, is covered by tropical grassland.

Normally, the grassland can retain enough moisture to stay green even through the dry season. But after three years of below-average rainfall, it's now bone dry.

"The problem with the grassland is that it provides a source of fire running up to the rainforest," Mr Cheney says. Once a grassland blaze reaches the rainforest, it burns along the forest floor, fueled by dried leaves, dropped by the trees during the drought.

The persistent dry weather guarantees dry grasslands and stop scorched rainforests from regenerating. As a consequence, increasing numbers of thin-barked rainforest trees are killed.

As the trees die, more sunlight reaches the forest floor, encouraging potentially flammable grasses and shrubs to invade the rainforest in a process called "conversion".

Shifting agriculture, too, hastens conversion. Similarly, logging promotes conversion because fires burn through the "slash" left behind by loggers and grass and shrubs quickly fill the void.

Vast coal seams close to the surface also contribute to fire and conversion. "These coal seams catch alight and can persist from year to year as a constant source of new ignitions," says Mr Peter Moore, a fire management expert with NSW State Forests.

Huge peat swamps are additional sources of "ignition", Mr Cheney says, with dry "pockets" of peat catching alight.

Peat and coal fires are hard to detect and stop since they often burn under the ground. Fire breaks to the surface through cracks in the soil, triggering a major fire.

Mr Moore says battling these Indonesian blazes is a two-stage process. First, the fires must be tackled and then a management strategy must be developed for fighting future outbreaks.

On the ground, firefighters face technical and organisational difficulties. For instance, many fires are virtually inaccessible.

Further, coal and peat fires can only be stopped by cutting off oxygen, using heavy earthmovers or sophisticated - and dangerous - systems for squirting fire-retardants underground.

Firefighting is further complicated by poor co-ordination, Mr Moore says.

"Unlike NSW or other States, there is no structured force to fight fires and the training provided to people who do fight fires is not well organised,"Mr Moore says.

This state of affairs is exacerbated by a thriving - and self-interested -logging industry. Logging concessions have been granted over about 540,000 square kilometres but because the concessions are granted for only 20 years -less than the 35-year harvest cycle - some loggers have used crude and destructive techniques, apparently because they think they are unlikely to be able to take a second harvest.

This, too, has promoted fires and conversion to grassland. Less than half of Indonesia's forest land (49 million hectares) is set aside as rain-catchment areas and parks in which, theoretically, no logging is permitted.

But 53.6 million hectares of prime tropical rain forest have been allocated to more than 540 logging companies, many run by ethnic Chinese businessmen with high-level political connections.

One of Indonesia's most prominent ethnic Chinese businessmen, Mr Prajogo Pangestu , has 5.5 million hectares of forest concession area. Another, Mr Bob Hasan , controls two million hectares.

Many concessionaires have been felling timber at an unsustainable rate, a problem that is only now being addressed.

As well, shifting cultivation by small landholders is on the rise. It is now the dominant form of agriculture - notably in Kalimantan - with an estimated one million families carrying it out.

Population pressure is another major threat. A 1989 World Bank study says half a million hectares are lost each year to agriculture as land-hungry settlers and shifting cultivators encroach on forests in Kalimantan, Sumatra and Irian Jaya. And this pressure is growing.

Indonesia's population has doubled to 180 million since 1960 and is expected to reach 300 million before it starts to level out.

The picture in Irian Jaya is better. About 86 per cent of the mountainous province is still relatively undisturbed. However, extensive logging concessions have now been granted and Indonesia has substantial transmigration plans, the IUCN notes.

Irian Jaya's freshwater swamp forests of sago palm and its mangrove forests are under threat by woodchipping proposals.

Papua New Guinea still had about 85 per cent of its original forest cover by the late 1980s, but the logging rate has edged above that required for a sustainable harvest: by 2010, Papua New Guinea's forest cover is expected to have fallen to 68 per cent.

World Bank forecasts suggest this pattern will be repeated in the region because forests are not being harvested sustainably.

The list details how much of their original forest cover other nations in the area are estimated to have had left by 1990, and what they were expected to have left by 2010 (in brackets) if present harvest rates continue: Malaysia, 51 per cent (20 per cent); Philippines, 20 (4); India, 11 (6); Vietnam 23 (0); Burma, 49 (17).

Australia is working to help Indonesia solve its forest problems. In 1991, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau sent a "rapid assessment team" to Indonesia, headed by Mr Michael Watts of the NSW Department of Bush Fire Services.

Recommendations were produced, covering methods to remove the threat of coal seam fires, ways to light "hotter" controlled fires which produce less of the smoke plaguing Malaysia and Singapore, and schemes to better organise firefighters.

urn:contentItem:459P-KK20-0197-T3V8-00000-00<published>1998-04-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Proliferation of the rabbit</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JULIAN LEWIS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE first of many domestic rabbits brought to this country, a grand</p><p nitf:lede="true">total of five, arrived on the First Fleet back in 1788.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By the 1820s, "wild grey" rabbits had been introduced to Tasmania</p><p nitf:lede="true">and the first reports of large numbers of them running loose on some</p><p nitf:lede="true">estates were being printed by 1827.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The mainland's problems with the furry critters began in 1859 when</p><p nitf:lede="true">Thomas Austin released two dozen, specially imported from Britain, to</p><p nitf:lede="true">run wild and propagate, near Geelong. This they most certainly did,</p><p nitf:lede="true">requiring the building of rabbit-proof fences and the introduction of</p><p nitf:lede="true">artificially-induced epidemics to control their numbers.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But for most of us, the rabbit still elicits warm and fuzzy feelings,</p><p nitf:lede="true">helped along by liberal dollops of mythology and mass appeal through</p><p nitf:lede="true">literature and the mass media. So, in honour of Easter, we salute some</p><p>of the stars of the rabbit world.</p><p>THE EASTER BUNNY: Given that the Easter egg is the emblem of renewed</p><p>life after death and of resurrection, and the rabbit has always been</p><p>considered a symbol of, shall we say this politely, fertility, then</p><p>the northern hemisphere tradition of eggs and rabbit seem to be</p><p>associated with pre-Christian pagan spring festivals.</p><p>The rabbit symbolised birth in ancient Egypt. Chinese children</p><p>traditionally believe in a rabbit who lived in the moon and a</p><p>well-known legend in the East says that the future Buddha was once</p><p>born as a hare and offered his life to help a hungry Brahman. As a</p><p>reward he was transported to live on the moon, which, you will</p><p>remember, determines the date of Easter.</p><p>A German belief of a poor woman's dyed eggs being discovered by</p><p>children during a famine, just as a rabbit hopped away, further spread</p><p>the idea of rabbits bringing Easter eggs.</p><p>Nineteenth century Poland saw the advent of the chocolate Easter egg.</p><p>On behalf of the world's chocaholics, thank you.</p><p>THE WHITE RABBIT: Lewis Carroll's contribution to the world of bunnies</p><p>dates back to 1865 when the lecturer in mathematics at Oxford</p><p>published his classic story Alice's Adventures In Wonderland. His real</p><p>name was Charles Lutwidge Dodgson and he was shy and withdrawn, while</p><p>the real Alice was Alice Liddell, daughter of the dean of Christ</p><p>Church, whom he first met when he was 23 and she was a mere three</p><p>years old.</p><p>Preferring the platonic company of little girls, he enjoyed taking</p><p>them out and entertaining them with fantastic stories. On one such</p><p>excursion in 1862, the tale he told the then 10-year-old Alice would</p><p>include the character of the White Rabbit who took a watch out of its</p><p>waist-coat pocket. When Alice went after the bunny, a legendary story</p><p>would begin. It took eight months to write and was published at</p><p>Carroll's own expense.</p><p>Alice would later be courted by Prince Leopold, son of Queen Victoria,</p><p>and eventually marry one of the author's pupils, Reginald Gervis</p><p>Hargreaves. Carroll would write some 255 books on many subjects and</p><p>nearly 100,000 letters before his death in 1898, aged 66.</p><p>One probably apocryphal story tells of Queen Victoria requesting</p><p>another book by him, anticipating something as enchanting as</p><p>"Alice," but receiving Dodgson's Syllabus of Plane Algebraical</p><p>Geometry instead. Presumably she would have remarked, "We are not</p><p>amused".</p><p>PETER RABBIT: Beatrix Potter was born in London in 1866 and her</p><p>sheltered early years were most happily relieved when she and her</p><p>brother would escape into the Scottish woods on the family's annual</p><p>holidays. This love of nature sustained her through a lonely childhood</p><p>and her first story The Tale of Peter Rabbit, was originally written</p><p>as a letter to a sick child. The classic tale sees the high-spirited</p><p>bunny disobey his mother and almost end up as rabbit pie. You probably</p><p>remember the names of the other three rabbits _ Flopsy, Mopsy and</p><p>Cotton-tail _ who lived with their mother under the root of a very big</p><p>fir-tree. You'll have to read the book to know what happened next.</p><p>OSWALD THE RABBIT: Before Walt Disney created Mickey Mouse, there was</p><p>the lesser-known Oswald the Lucky Rabbit. Born out of a desire to</p><p>compete with the highly successful Felix the Cat series, the Disney</p><p>studio came up with a black rabbit that bore a not-so-coincidental</p><p>resemblance. Early in 1927, Universal Pictures released the first of a</p><p>project series of Oswald the Lucky Rabbit cartoons, called Trolley</p><p>Troubles. Initially mistakenly identified as Oscar the Rabbit, the</p><p>cartoon received rave reviews and merchandising soon followed.</p><p>According to their contract, though, the name Oswald and the tag "The</p><p>World's Luckiest Rabbit" belonged to the Winkler Film Corporation.</p><p>Faced with defeat, Walt relinquished all claims to the Oswald</p><p>character and went on to create a new character based on a real mouse</p><p>that used to live in his old Kansas City office. Wald thought to call</p><p>him Mortimer, but his wife, Lillian, suggested Mickey instead,</p><p>insisting Mortimer sound "too sissy." Showbiz history has recorded</p><p>which character became the more successful.</p><p>THUMPER THE RABBIT: The Disney studio was in trouble by early 1944,</p><p>with no features scheduled and the 1942 release of Bambi proving a</p><p>disappointment at the box office. Described by one wag as "the</p><p>ultimate stag movie," the anthropomorphic cartoon feature created a</p><p>great comic character in Thumper the Rabbit and a genuinely thrilling</p><p>climatic forest fire. It took a few years, but the film eventually</p><p>made money, earning $2,000,000 on its re-release in 1957, vindicating</p><p>Walt's faith in it.</p><p>CRUSADER RABBIT: The creators of Rocky and Bullwinkle, Jay Ward and</p><p>Alexander Anderson, originated the long-eared rabbit, Crusader, and</p><p>pal Ragland (Rags) P. Tiger in 1948, becoming the "first cartoon</p><p>serial" and "first limited animation series" made for television.</p><p>Test marketed on local US TV stations that year, the series went</p><p>nationwide the following year. Initially, 130 five-minute</p><p>cliff-hanging episodes were produced in the 1949-51 series, while a</p><p>new color serious was produced in 1957. Episode titles included</p><p>"Tales of Schmerwood Forest" "Apes of Rath," and "Gullible's</p><p>Travels."</p><p>HARVEY: James Stewart earned an Oscar best-actor nomination for his</p><p>portrayal of Elwood P. Dowd, a middle-aged drunk with an imaginary six</p><p>foot three inch invisible rabbit friend named Harvey, in the 1950</p><p>movie of the same name. As Elwood, James describes his first meeting</p><p>with Harvey in this way: "I'd just helped Ed Hickey into a taxi. Ed</p><p>had been mixing his drinks, and I felt he needed conveying. I started</p><p>to walk down the street when I heard a voice saying: "Good evening,</p><p>Mr Dowd." I turned, and there was this big white rabbit leaning</p><p>against a lamp post. Well, I thought nothing of that! Because when</p><p>you've lived in a town as long as I've lived in this one, you get used</p><p>to the fact that everybody knows your name..."</p><p>Stewart also tells his doctor, "I've wrestled with reality for 35</p><p>years, and I'm happy, doctor, I finally won out over it."</p><p>THE "WATERSHIP DOWN" COLONY: Nature-loving novelist Richard Adams,</p><p>originally a civil servant, scored a smash hit with his 1972 tale of a</p><p>colony of rabbit who seek a new home following a vision of the</p><p>destruction of their warren. The 1978 animated film version featured</p><p>the voices of celebrities such as John Hurt (Hazel), Richard Briers</p><p>(Fiver), Sir Ralph Richardson (Chief Rabbit), Denholm Elliott</p><p>(Cowslip), Zero Mostel (Kehaar) and Nigel Hawthorne (Campion). Art</p><p>Garfunkel also sang two songs.</p><p>ROGER RABBIT: The star of the 1988 movie Who Framed Roger Rabbit?</p><p>proved endearing, but nowhere near as memorable as the sexiest cartoon</p><p>character ever in Jessica Rabbit, voiced by Kathleen Turner (speaking)</p><p>and Amy Irving (singing). Some disrespectfully dubbed the flick "Who</p><p>Rogered Jessica Rabbit?". Frank Sinatra played the Singing Sword and</p><p>Mel Blanc voiced Daffy Duck in this unparalleled technical achievement</p><p>for its time.</p><p>BUGS BUNNY: Voiced by Mel Blanc as well, this wise-cracking cartoon</p><p>character first appeared in A Wild Hare in 1940, but evolved from a</p><p>rabbit seen in the 1937 Pork's Hare Hunt. One of Bug's creators</p><p>claimed that the character was inspired by the sight of Clark Gable</p><p>eating a carrot in the smash film, It Happened One Night from 1934.</p><p>However it happened, his catchphrase, "what's up Doc?" and his</p><p>ability to maintain his aplomb in all situations has contributed to</p><p>his ongoing popularity. He even became an Oscar winning rabbit for</p><p>real in 1958 with Knightly Knight Bugs, putting an Academy Award on</p><p>his burrow's mantel.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CT0-TXN5-R2RX-00000-00The END of the world (as they knew it)2003-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:59:28ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMPg. 4The END of the world (as they knew it)cover storyJared Diamond

Societies don't just collapse, they come to grief through disastrous decisions based on denial, ignorance and self-interest. But sometimes it can be hard to see the wood for the burning trees.

Why is it that some societies in the past collapsed while others did not? I am thinking of such famous collapses as those of the Anasazi in the south-west United States, C lassic Maya civilisation in the Yucatan, Easter Island society in the Pacific, Angkor Wat in South-East Asia, Great Zimbabwe in Africa and Fertile Crescent (a strip of land stretching from Jordan to Iraq) and Harappan Indus Valley societies. These are all societies that we've realised, from archaeological discoveries in the past 20 years, hammered away at their own environments and destroyed themselves in part by undermining the resources on which they depended.

For example, the Easter Islanders Polynesian people settled an island that was originally forested, and whose forests included the world's largest palm tree. They gradually chopped down that forest to use the wood for canoes, firewood, transporting statues, raising statues and carving. Eventually they felled the forests to the point where all the tree species were extinct, which meant they ran out of canoes and could no longer erect statues. There were no more trees to protect the topsoil against erosion, and their society collapsed in an epidemic of cannibalism that left 90 per cent of the islanders dead.

The question that most intrigued my students was one that I, a geography professor, hadn't registered: how could a society make such an obviously disastrous decision as to cut down the trees on which they depended? For example, my students wondered, what did the Easter Islanders say as they were cutting down the last palm tree? Were they saying: "Think of our jobs as loggers, not these trees"? Were they saying: "Respect my private property rights"?

Surely they must have realised the consequences of destroying their own forest. It wasn't a subtle mistake. One wonders whether if anybody is still around 100 years from now people in the next century will be as astonished about our blindness as we are about that of the Easter Islanders.

This question why do societies make disastrous decisions and destroy themselves? also astonishes professional historians. The most cited book on the subject is The Collapse of Complex Societies, by the historian Joseph Tainter . He rejected the possibility that these might be due to environmental mismanagement because it seemed so unlikely to him. "As it becomes apparent to the members or administrators of a complex society that a resource base is deteriorating," he wrote, "it seems most reasonable to assume that some rational steps are taken towards a resolution. With their administrative structure and their capacity to allocate labour and resources, dealing with adverse environmental conditions may be one of the things that complex societies do best. It is curious that they would collapse when faced with precisely those conditions that they are equipped to circumvent."

Yet it is now clear that those ancient societies did make bad mistakes.

My students, and Tainter, identified a surprising phenomenon: namely, failures of group decision-making on the part of whole societies, or governments, or smaller groups, or businesses, or university academic departments. The question of failure of group decision-making is similar to that of failures of individual decision-making. Individuals make bad decisions they enter bad marriages, they make bad investments, their businesses fail. But there are some additional factors in failures of group decision-making notably, conflicts of interest among the members of the group.

I suggest there is a road map of four factors in failures of group decision-making. First, a group may fail to anticipate a problem. Second, when the problem arrives, the group may fail to perceive it. Third, after they perceive the problem, they may fail even to try to solve it. Finally, they may try to solve it but may fail.

The first item is that groups may do disastrous things because they don't anticipate a problem. There may be several reasons for this. One is that they may have had no experience of such problems, and so may not have been sensitised to the possibility. For example, consider forest fires in the American west. My family spends parts of the summer in Montana and, each year when we fly there, I look out the plane window to see how many forest fires there are.

Forest fires on that giant scale are unknown in the eastern US and in Europe. When settlers from those places arrived in Montana and a forest fire arose, their reaction was to try to put out the fire. The motto of the US Forest Service for nearly a century was: our goal is that every forest fire will be put out by 10 the morning after the day it is reported.

Easterners and Europeans had that attitude about forest fires because they had no previous experience of them in a dry environment where there's a big build-up of fuel. The idea that you should let a fire burn, and destroy valuable forest, was so counter-intuitive that it took the US Forest Service 100 years to realise the problem and to change strategy.

That's not the only reason, though, why a society may fail to anticipate a problem. Another is that they may have had experience but forgotten it. For example, a non-literate society is not going to preserve oral memories of something that happened long ago. The Classic Lowland Maya eventually succumbed to drought about AD800. There had been previous droughts in the Maya realm, but the Maya could not draw on that experience because, although they had some writing, it preserved only the conquests of kings, not droughts. Maya droughts recurred at intervals of 208 years, so the Maya in AD800 could not remember the drought of AD592.

Even in modern literate societies, we don't necessarily draw on our experience. We, too, tend to forget things. Americans, for example, behave as if they've forgotten the 1973 Gulf oil crisis. For a year or two after the crisis, they avoided petrol-guzzling vehicles, then quickly forgot that knowledge.

In the 1960s, Tucson, in Arizona, went through a severe drought, and the citizens swore they would manage their water better. But, within a decade or two, Tucson was back to its water-greedy ways of building golf courses and watering gardens.

The remaining reason why a society might fail to foresee a problem involves reasoning by false analogy. When we are in an unfamiliar situation, we fall back on reasoning by analogy with familiar situations. That's a good way to proceed if the old and new situations are truly analogous. But reasoning by analogy can be dangerous if the old and new situations are only superficially similar.

An example was the society of Norwegian Vikings who started settling in Iceland circa AD871. Their familiar homeland had heavy clay soils ground up by glaciers. Those soils were heavy enough that, if the vegetation covering them was cut down, they would not be blown away. Unfortunately for the Viking colonists of Iceland, Icelandic soils were as light as talcum powder. They arose not through glacial grinding, but through winds carrying light ashes blown out in volcanic eruptions.

The Vikings cleared the forests over those soils in order to create pasture for their animals. Unfortunately, the ash that was light enough for the wind to blow in was light enough for the wind to blow out again when the covering vegetation had been removed. Within a few generations of the Vikings' arrival in Iceland, half of the island's topsoil had eroded into the ocean.

The second step in my road map involves a society's failure to perceive a problem that has arrived. There are at least three reasons for this, all of them common in the business world and in academia. First, the origins of some problems are literally imperceptible. For example, the nutrients responsible for soil fertility are invisible to the eye, and only in modern times measurable by means of chemical analysis.

In Australia, French Polynesia, parts of the south-west US and many other locations, most of the nutrients had already been leached out of the soil by rainfall. People arrived and began growing crops, which quickly exhausted the remaining nutrients, so that agriculture rapidly failed. Yet such nutrient-poor soils often bear apparently lush vegetation; it's just that most of the nutrients in the ecosystem are contained in the vegetation rather than in the soil, so that the nutrients are removed when the vegetation is cut down. There is no way the first colonists of Australia and French Polynesia could have noticed that problem.

An even more common reason for a society's failure to perceive a problem is that it may take the form of a slow trend concealed by fluctuations. The prime example in modern times is global warming. We now realise that world temperatures have been slowly rising in recent decades, due in large part to changes in the atmosphere caused by humans. However, it is not the case that the climate grows inexorably warmer each year. Instead, it fluctuates widely and unpredictably from year to year: three degrees warmer in one summer than the previous summer, then two degrees warmer the next, down four degrees the following summer, and so on.

It takes a long time to discern the upwards trend within that noisy signal. That's why it was only a few years ago that the last professional climatologist who was sceptical about global warming became convinced. The medieval Greenlanders had similar difficulties in recognising that the climate was becoming colder, and the Maya of the Yucatan could not discern that the climate was becoming drier.

Politicians use the term "creeping normalcy" to refer to such slow trends concealed within noisy fluctuations. If a situation is very slowly getting worse, it is difficult to recognise that this year is worse than last year, and each successive year is only slightly worse than the year before, so that one's baseline standard for what constitutes "normalcy" shifts almost imperceptibly. lt may take a few decades of a long sequence of such slight year-to-year changes before someone suddenly realises that conditions were much better several decades ago, and that what is accepted as normalcy has crept downwards.

The other frequent reason for failure to perceive a problem after it has appeared is distant managers, a potential problem in any large society. For example, the largest private landowner (and largest timber company) in Montana is based not in that state but in Seattle, Washington. Not being on the scene, company executives may not realise that they have a big weed problem on their forest property.

The third step in my road map of failure is perhaps the most common and most surprising one: a society's failure to even try to solve a problem that it has noticed. Such failures frequently arise because of what economists term "rational behaviour" arising from clashes of interest between people.

Some people may reason correctly that they can advance their own interests by behaviour that is harmful for other people. Economists label such behaviour as "rational", even while acknowledging that, morally, it may be naughty. The perpetrators are often likely to get away with their rational bad behaviour because the winners from the bad status quo are typically concentrated (few in number) and highly motivated by the big, certain and immediate profits they will receive. The losers are diffuse (the losses are spread over large numbers of individuals) and are unmotivated because they receive only small, uncertain, distant profits from undoing the rational bad behaviour of the minority.

A characteristic of rational bad behaviour is, to put it bluntly, "selfishness". A few individuals may correctly perceive their self-interests to be opposed to that of the majority. For example, until 1971, mining companies in Montana typically dumped their toxic wastes of copper and arsenic directly into rivers and ponds because the state had no law requiring mining companies to clean up after abandoning a mine.

After 1971, Montana did pass such a law, but mining companies discovered that they could extract the valuable ore and then declare bankruptcy before going to the expense of cleaning up. The result has been billions of dollars of clean-up costs borne by taxpayers. The mining companies had correctly perceived that they could advance their interests and save money by making messes and leaving the burden to society.

One particular form of such clashes of interest has received the name "tragedy of commons". That refers to a situation in which many consumers are harvesting a communally owned resource (such as fish in the ocean, or grass in common pastures), and in which there is no effective regulation of how much of the resource each consumer can draw off.

Under those circumstances, each consumer can correctly reason: "If I don't catch that fish or graze that grass, some other fisherman or herder will anyway, so it makes no sense for me to be careful about overfishing or overharvesting." The correct rational behaviour is to harvest before the next consumer can, even though the end result is depletion or extinction of the resource, and hence harm for society as a whole.

Rational behaviour involving clashes of interest also arises when the consumer has no long-term stake in preserving the resource. For example, much commercial harvesting of tropical rainforests is carried out by international logging companies which lease land in one country, cut down all its rainforest and then move on to the next country.

The international loggers have correctly deduced that once they have paid for the lease, their interests are best served by clear-cutting the rainforest on their leased land. In that way, loggers have destroyed most of the forest of the Malay Peninsula, then of Borneo, then of the Solomon Islands and Sumatra, now of the Philippines and, coming up soon, of New Guinea, the Amazon and the Congo Basin. In this case, the bad consequences are borne by the next generation, which cannot vote or complain.

A further situation involving rational behaviour and conflicts of interest arises when the interests of the decision-making elite conflict with the interests of the rest of society. The elite is particularly likely to do things that profit it but hurt everybody else, if it can insulate itself from the consequences.

Such failures to solve perceived problems are less likely in societies where the elite cannot do this. For example, the country with the highest proportion of citizens belonging to environmental organisations is the Netherlands. I never understood why, until I visited the Netherlands a few years ago and raised this question to my Dutch colleagues as we were driving through the countryside.

My Dutch friends answered: "Just look around you and you will see the reason. The land where we are now is 6.5 metres below sea level. Like much of the area of Holland, it was once a shallow bay of the sea that we Dutch people surrounded by dikes and then drained with pumps to create low-lying land that we call a polder. We have pumps to pump out the water that is continually leaking into our polders through the dikes. If the dikes burst, of course, the people in the polder drown. But it is not the case that the rich Dutch live on top of the dikes, while the poor Dutch are living down in the polders. If the dikes burst, everybody drowns, regardless of whether they are rich or poor.

"That was what happened in the terrible floods of February 1, 1953, when nearly 2000 Dutch people drowned. After that disaster, we all swore `never again' and spent billions of dollars building reinforced barriers against the water. In the Netherlands, the decision-makers know that they cannot insulate themselves from their mistakes."

In contrast to that so-called rational behaviour, there are also failures to attempt to solve problems that economists consider "irrational behaviour"; that is, harmful for everybody.

Such irrational behaviour often arises when we are torn by clashes of values within us all. We may be strongly attached to a bad status quo because it is favoured by some deeply held value that we admire.

Religious values are especially deeply held and hence are frequent causes of disastrous behaviour. For example, much of the deforestation of Easter Island had a religious motivation to obtain logs to transport and erect the giant stone statues that were the basis of religious cults.

Irrational failures to try to solve perceived problems also frequently stem from clashes between the short-term and long-term motives of the same individual.

Billions of people in the world today are desperately poor and able to think only of food for the next day. Poor fishermen in tropical reef areas use dynamite and cyanide to kill and catch reef fish in full knowledge that they are destroying their future livelihood, but they feel that they have no choice.

Governments, too, regularly operate on a short-term focus: they feel overwhelmed by imminent disasters and pay attention only to those problems on the verge of explosion. For example, a friend who is closely connected to the current US Administration told me that when he visited Washington for the first time after the 2000 elections, Government leaders had what he termed a "90-day focus": they talked about only those problems with the potential to cause a disaster within the next 90 days.

Economists rationally justify these irrational focuses on short-term profits by "discounting" future profits. That is, they argue that it may be better to harvest a resource today than to leave some of the resource for harvesting tomorrow, because the profits from today's harvest could be invested, and the accumulated interest between now and a harvest of that same quantity of resource in the future would make today's harvest more valuable than the future harvest.

The last reason for irrational failure to try to solve a perceived problem is psychological denial. If something you see arouses an unbearably painful emotion, you may subconsciously suppress or deny your perception in order to avoid the unbearable pain, even though the practical results of ignoring your perception may prove disastrous. The emotions most often responsible are terror, anxiety and sadness.

For example, consider a narrow deep river valley below a high dam, such that if the dam burst, the resulting flood would drown people for a long distance downstream. When pollsters ask people downstream of the dam how concerned they are about its bursting, it's not surprising that that fear is lowest far downstream and increases among residents closer to it.

Surprisingly, though, the people living immediately under the dam who are certain to be drowned if it bursts profess unconcern. That is because of psychological denial: the only way for them to preserve their sanity is to deny the finite possibility that it could burst.

Psychological denial is a phenomenon well established in individual psychology. It seems likely to apply to group psychology as well. For example, there is much evidence that, during World War II, Jews and other groups at risk of the developing Holocaust denied the accumulating evidence that it was happening and that they were at risk, because the thought was unbearably horrible. Psychological denial may also explain why some collapsing societies fail to face up to the obvious causes of their collapse.

The last of the four items in my road map is the failure to solve a problem. There are obvious possible explanations for such an outcome. The problem may be too difficult, and beyond our capacities to solve. Or our efforts are too little, too late.

For example, Australia has suffered tens of billions of dollars of agricultural losses, as well as the extinction or endangerment of most of its native small mammal species, because of the introduction of European rabbits and foxes for which there was no close native counterpart. Foxes prey on lambs and chickens and kill native small marsupials and rodents.

Foxes have been widespread over the Australian mainland for more than a century, but until recently they were absent from Tasmania, because they could not swim across the wide, rough seas of Bass Strait.

Unfortunately, two or three years ago, some individuals surreptitiously and illegally released 30-odd foxes on the island, either for their fox-hunting pleasure or to spite environmentalists. Those foxes represent a big threat to local lamb and chicken farmers, as well as to wildlife. When Tasmanian environmentalists became aware of this problem early last year, they begged the Government to exterminate the foxes quickly, while it was still possible. The fox-breeding season was expected to begin within a few months.

Once the foxes had produced litters and once those litters had dispersed, it would be far more difficult to eradicate 120 of them. Unfortunately, the Tasmanian Government debated and delayed, and it was not until last June that the Government decided to commit $1 million to eliminating the foxes. By that time, there was a considerable risk that the commitment of money was too little and too late, and that the Government would be faced with a far more expensive and less solvable problem.

These reasons for making disastrous decisions may sound pessimistic, as if failure is the rule in human decision-making. Of course, that is not the case. Many human societies have anticipated, perceived, tried to solve, or succeeded in solving, their environmental problems. For example, the Inca Empire, New Guinea Highlanders, 18th-century Japanese, 19th-century Germans and the paramount chiefdom of Tonga all recognised the risks that they faced from deforestation, and all adopted successful reforestation or forest management policies.

By recognising the signposts of failed decision-making, I hope, we may become more consciously aware of how others have failed, and of what we need to do in order to get it right.

Jared Diamond is professor of geography at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the author of Guns, Germs, and Steel (W. W. Norton).
