urn:contentItem:4597-JG90-0197-D34P-00000-00<published>1998-01-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:59:28Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hindenburg; Exploding the myth</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By MARIETTE DiCHRISTINA</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">May 6, 1937. The sky still appears moody after a stormy day. A</p><p nitf:lede="true">stately, silvery shape, the 240-tonne Hindenburg airship glides 60m</p><p nitf:lede="true">above New Jersey about 7.21pm. In a six-knot wind, the zeppelin is</p><p nitf:lede="true">attempting its first "high landing". The crew throws the spider</p><p nitf:lede="true">lines out, preparing for mooring. The gigantic ship nearly three</p><p>football fields in length would slowly be winched down . . .</p><p>IF you think you know exactly what happens next, Addison Bain has a</p><p>surprise for you.</p><p>Six decades after the infamous Hindenburg disaster, when 36 of 97</p><p>aboard died in the horrific blaze that halted rigid-airship travel,</p><p>Bain has revealed a stunning new explanation for what started the</p><p>fire.</p><p>Bain, a recently retired engineer and manager of hydrogen programs who</p><p>spent more than 30 years at NASA, recently ended several years of</p><p>scientific sleuthing work for the reason behind the disaster.</p><p>He combed thousands of pages of original testimony and materials at</p><p>four archives in the United States and one in Germany, he interviewed</p><p>survivors and airship experts and, ultimately, tested original</p><p>materials from the model LZ-129 Hindenburg and its contempories.</p><p>Contrary to what investigators ruled at the time, asserts Bain, the</p><p>fire did not start with free hydrogen lit by natural electrical</p><p>discharge or sabotage.</p><p>The hunt for the truth about Hindenburg began in the late 1960s for</p><p>Bain, who was working on a hydrogen safety manual for NASA. Bain</p><p>recalls how he read the literature on hydrogen.</p><p>"Invariably," he says, "the topic of Hindenburg would come up. At</p><p>the time, I didn't think a lot about it."</p><p>Over the years, however, as he continued his NASA work on hydrogen</p><p>systems, the references began to accumulate in his mind.</p><p>"What I was starting to notice was that the authors were</p><p>inconsistent," he says. Hydrogen detractors said the gas was so</p><p>flammable it killed everyone on Hindenburg, which was not true: about</p><p>one-third of those aboard died.</p><p>"On the other hand, hydrogen promoters rubbished safety concerns and</p><p>claimed that those who perished did so only because they jumped from</p><p>the burning airship, which also was not true.</p><p>"I thought, 'wait a minute! Where are they getting their</p><p>information'?"</p><p>Bain had also seen the famous photos of Hindenburg's bright,</p><p>blistering, hot fire and knew that hydrogen did not burn that way.</p><p>A hydrogen fire radiates little heat and is barely visible to the</p><p>unaided eye.</p><p>As a hydrogen expert, he knew that the pure gas does not explode. That</p><p>was enough. He donned a pair of protective gloves, and lost himself in</p><p>decades-old original documents in Washington's National Air and Space</p><p>Museum.</p><p>His research soon became something of a obsession.</p><p>He speculated that, perhaps, some of the airship's materials had</p><p>played a role in ignition. But, maddeningly, he could not find the</p><p>exact formulations used.</p><p>"I had the idea of the problem, but needed enough evidence to back up</p><p>my story," Bain says.</p><p>That was as far as he went, until 1994, when he ran into Space Shuttle</p><p>technician Richard van Treuren, at a conference on hydrogen. Van</p><p>Treuren was a self-avowed "helium head" and member of the airship</p><p>aficionados' group called the Lighter-Than-Air Society, in Akron,</p><p>Ohio.</p><p>Through van Treuren, Bain learnt that pieces of Hindenburg's skin</p><p>still existed. Bain went throughout the US to procure them, also</p><p>spending hundreds of dollars buying original materials, books and</p><p>papers.</p><p>"What I was trying to find out," he says, "was what did they use</p><p>specifically in the coating?"</p><p>Hepburn Walker, who had been stationed at Lakehurst in the early</p><p>1940s, was among those with pieces of Hindenburg. Walker had found</p><p>them in the soil. Another sample, a part of the swastika painted on</p><p>Hindenburg's side, was kept in a safe by Cheryl Gantz, head of the</p><p>Zeppelin Collectors Club in Chicago.</p><p>Materials in hand, Bain headed to NASA's Materials Science Laboratory</p><p>at nearby Kennedy Space Centre. Over the next 14 months, he carefully</p><p>laid out a systematic testing protocol involving about 14 researchers</p><p>who volunteered their spare time to assist in what became known as</p><p>Project H.</p><p>What was in that fabric? An infra-red spectograph and a scanning</p><p>electron microscope provided, respectively, the chemical signatures of</p><p>the organic compounds and elements present.</p><p>A startling variety of highly flammable compounds proved to have been</p><p>added to the cotton fabric base.</p><p>"They used a cellulose acetate of nitrate as a typical doping</p><p>compound, which is flammable to begin with a forest fire is a</p><p>cellulose fire," says Bain.</p><p>"OK, you coat that with cellulose nitrate nitrate is used to make</p><p>gunpowder.</p><p>"And then you put (on) aluminium powder. Now, aluminium powder is a</p><p>fuel used in the solid rocket boosters on the Space Shuttle."</p><p>The wood spacers and fibrous ramie cord used to bind the structure</p><p>together, along with the silk and other fabrics in the ship, also</p><p>would have added to the fuel-rich inferno. Even the duralumin support</p><p>framework of Hindenburg's rigid skeleton was coated with lacquer,</p><p>ostensibly to protect it from moisture.</p><p>In a flame test, a fabric section ignited and burnt readily. The arc</p><p>test, in which 30,000 volts were zapped across a piece of fabric</p><p>several centimetres along, was even more revealing.</p><p>"Poof, it disappeared. The whole thing happened faster than I can</p><p>explain it," Bain says. "I guess the moral of the story is, don't</p><p>paint your airship with rocket fuel."</p><p>However, Bain is quick to point out it is not that the Germans and</p><p>other airship and aircraft makers of the era were simply foolish in</p><p>doping the fabric the way they did. They had a number of technical</p><p>problems to solve using the materials of the time.</p><p>The cotton or linen fabric skin was swabbed with the chemicals to make</p><p>it taut and reduce flutter for aerodynamics, and then painted with the</p><p>reflective red iron oxide and aluminium so the sun's heat would not</p><p>expand the gas in the cells, to help prevent gas escaping.</p><p>"I'm not saying hydrogen didn't contribute to the fire," adds Bain.</p><p>It is, after all, a fuel, he notes and one he is hoping will develop</p><p>into a replacement or supplement to natural gas.</p><p>"But it was a fuel-rich fire already, the hydrogen just added to</p><p>it."</p><p>Decades of speculation about the causes behind the start of the</p><p>zeppelin fire are academic, he says. All have blamed hydrogen, with</p><p>various ideas about how the gas became free and ignited.</p><p>One popular theory has it that a wire punctured a gas cell. Bain finds</p><p>this doubtful.</p><p>"If that happened, it should have occurred during one of the final</p><p>manoeuvres." But, he says, the ship was stationary for four minutes</p><p>before fire was evident.</p><p>What about the possibility of loose hydrogen from the vents? Hydrogen</p><p>was released to help maintain level flight, and others have theorised</p><p>that a valve may have stuck open.</p><p>Bain says Hindenburg had an excellent venting system, with vents</p><p>between cells that measured about 60cm high and 200cm wide.</p><p>If hydrogen accumulated difficult to imagine for the lightest</p><p>element, which has the greatest dispersal rate in the universe why,</p><p>he asks, were none of the fires observed at the vent sites on top of</p><p>the ship?</p><p>What is perhaps most stunning about Bain's research is that what he</p><p>has discovered comes 60 years after some German airship experts</p><p>already knew it. While visiting an archive in Germany, he copied two</p><p>1937 letters, handwritten in German, that had not been seen by earlier</p><p>investigators.</p><p>Their contents were revealed to Bain only after he returned to Florida</p><p>and had them translated. They were written by an electrical engineer</p><p>named Otto Beyerstock, who had incinerated pieces of Hindenburg fabric</p><p>during electrical tests conducted at the behest of the Zeppelin</p><p>company.</p><p>In the notes, Beyerstock testily dismissed the idea that hydrogen</p><p>could have started the fire, stating that it could only have been</p><p>caused by the fabric's flammability in a charged atmosphere.</p><p>"I beg you to kindly inform me about the corrective measures to be</p><p>taken or that have already been taken," Beyerstock wrote to Zeppelin.</p><p>"They knew," Bain says simply.</p><p>But soon after the Hindenburg disaster, and probably because of it,</p><p>the great zeppelins were removed from service.</p><p>None of what Bain has learnt has diminished his admiration for the</p><p>engineering achievement in creating the great airships.</p><p>"With all due respect," he says, "the Germans did a fantastic job.</p><p>"I admire their technology.</p><p>"It was just an unfortunate little flaw, just like the flaw on</p><p>Titanic and the flaw in Challenger," he says, referring to the</p><p>"unsinkable" ship's sulphurous, brittle steel and the Space</p><p>Shuttle's O-ring both of which failed under prevailing weather</p><p>conditions.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
